content:
Posted: September 19, 2016
												Oh, The Last Remnant...how could you fall into such oblivion being such an awesome game? Maybe I'm the weirod here for having put so much time in this game, but I've enjoyed it like I have enjoyed no other RPG since Final Fantasy X.Good graphics, music and voice acting (at least the japanese voice acting...didn't check the english one), innovative tactical gameplay (we'll get onto that later), good story (the characters may be a bit lacking...except for the Enlightened Seven, a group of ¿villains? who kick absolute♥♥♥♥♥ and the bad guy who is one of the best villains Square has pulled off in years) and hours...HOURS to spend on side quests and grinding , which hardly ever get tedious, really.As for the battle system: friends and foes are tossed in the a turn based system on a battlefield. Your party is divided in several groups or formations, each led by one character. Each turn, a not-so-randomly generated command list will appear for each formation. The commands will depend on the build of the leader of each party, and this adds a lot of strategy, variety and richness to the battle system and build of your characters. It may sound complicated at first glance but hte game introduces new elements gently so you can keep up with it.Finally, special mention to Superbosses: they ARE CHALLENGING. So good luck trying to complete the 100% of the game.This may be a bit too much for your first experience in a JRPG but experimented players shouls look up to this game and give it a try. To me, it was a major surprise and has become one of my favourite all-time games.9/10

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												An extremly well made J-RPG. It starts very conservative and slowly, but once it get rolling it is extremly awesome.Cool characters - although the main character is a  little bit annoying from time to time - , well-written story and a really complex fighting system, in which the battles are really intense. It look a bit like final fantasy, but it doesn't play that way. It has a unique moral system, which increases or decreases the damage of your unions, depending on how you position them, and how you perform actions.  You can totally customize your union, and there is a huge amount of differenct characters, mercenarys, soldiers and questcharacters to choose from. There a a lot of boss monsters, whom are very different from each other, and are most of the time really hard to actually beat. The game looks absolutly stunning. The performance is extremly smooth, and i have yet to find a place, where i have lags or where the games stutters. It is pretty unique and an experiment which you either love or hate.  Be prepared, the game is not easy, and if you don't plan ahead in a fight, you will find yourself loading the last save file. However i would definitly recommend playing this game with a Xbox Controller. Although the keyboard layout is pretty good, you have to first activate the tooltips to show the keyboard-commands instead of the gamepad commands. Some reviews have claimed, that you cannot skip cutscenes, which is rather bullocks. Pause the game, and then there is an option to skip them (on the Xbox-Controller Start+Back).All-in all in my honest opinion, i think this game is absolutly brilliant. It has the classic J-RPG feel, with a very complex combat system, an incredibly well written story ( i am not even half through and it has already blown me away), and stunning graphics. And although there are some annoyances with the keyboard commands, i would definitly recommend this game to everyone who loves J-RPGs or who always wanted to play one. It is under my Top 5 of my favourite RPGs and that means a lot. 9.5/10

number of helpful: 19 of 29 people (66%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 8
												Recommended: "Sort of".It is a nice JRPG, that tries to do something different with its battle system. But it is deeply flawed in the following ways:1. Graphics optimisation is poor. Textures pop in a lot, which is annoying. Sure you can mess around with certain files to fix it, but most people won't want to bother doing that.2. You really do need to force V-Sync outside of the game, otherwise expect some messy screen tearing.3. The plot is generic enough, but it does the job. Where it sort of falls away is you could probably blow through it quite quickly. The real meat of the game seems to be over the other side, with side-quests. And there's a ton of them, lengthy ones, quick ones, and so on. A few of them get closed out reasonably early on in the game, so if you're a completionist, you'll be spending lots of hours getting through these at the expense of the main story.3b. The main story progresses at lightning pace. Honestly, sometimes all you have to do is go to the main story location, watch some cutscenes for 20 minutes and then maybe have a boss fight, and repeat. (At time of writing I've got to the halfway point with 30 hours, about 28 of those hours were doing side-quests and travelling imho.)4. Battle system is interesting but horrendously flawed and frustrating. Basically you create armies or battle groups of up to five people per unit. And they all share the same health pool and action points. You give them commands to attack certain enemy units. Usually you want to keep physical and magic users separate so they can all use either physical or magical attacks together as mix and matching doesn't always allow characters to act together. Also, you generally put a healer in the unit so they can heal when they get hurt. Here's a ridiculous example of a frustrating battle:I fought a battle and ended up with 1 unit left vs 1 boss monster. They were far apart, so couldn't attack each other. My unit had just beaten everything else on the battlefield, but it had a mere 90 hp left out of thousands. That unit had several healers. The enemy unit was almost dead. All I needed to do was heal, and own it. But the game refused to show the heal command, instead my choices were close in to attack next round, or wait. So I waited three times. No dice. The game then took away the command to wait, and forced me to move in. I had lots of Action points, at least three of my characters in the unit knew how to heal in various ways. In the end, the game gave me one choice; Attack physically (or attack with physical skills). No heals. So I attacked, and I died.Here's the kicker, when you die it is game over. So reload time, wait through cutscenes all over again and retry the bloody fight. All this could have been averted by healing, but the game stubbornly refused to allow me to do so. And this is exactly where it becomes so frustrating, here is another hour to be wasted fighting the same battle, a particular pain in the butt if it is a difficult one anyway!5. Levelling is apparently a no-noEvery guide out there suggests avoiding to grind, as enemies scale somewhat and will just ruin your day. Although it's not as bad as people make out, it can add to the frustration.I realise this sounds like a very negative review, and really, I wanted to give this a mixed rating. There's a decent JRPG in here. Probably one could argue that The Last Remnant was an early warning sign of Square-Enix overcomplicating their games and making them somewhat silly. Still, it is a workable game, it just requires a lot of patience. Worth taking a risk for fans of the genre, but it certainly isn't a JRPG for the JRPG-newbie.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3
												To put it simply: this is one very decent JRPG if not for the combat system, which although quite novel can be excruciating at times.Story: meh. Nothing exciting happen and the plot goes far too slow to be enjoyed. Kinda funny for a  game titled The Last Remnant when most of the time the remnants only appear as uninteractable background objects. Characters: okayish somewhatMost of your party characters are mercenaries who have no contribution at all to the main plot. Some of them are (awesome) unique characters with nice side quest tho. It's hard to beat a 4-armed catman armed with dual halberds.Music: okayish somewhatThe battle theme is nice to get your blood boiling but it get repetitive after a thousands battlesGameplay and Mechanic: revolutionary? Yup. Frustating? Hell yeah it isAt first you'll be presented by a bunch of combat mechanic (deadlock, flank, rear assault, etc) that sounds awesome on paper but hardly useful on real battle. Most mooks are weak enough to be killed from just a simple deadlock while enemies who truly need strategy to be downed HAVE a high deadlock threshold to even be flanked. This game also has one weird level scaling (kinda like TES IV: Oblivion) wherein your enemies level growth is high. The more you grind the more unkillable the enemies are until you can't do anything beside restarting the game. So, minimize your grind.And the most frustating thing is the combat command. In this game, you can only give your squads vague ideas about what they're supposed to do next ("Use combat  arts!!!" "support them!!!" etc) and the ai will pick his action from his assorted abilities. The problem is it's fuken random, as in at critical time the command you need won't even appear.Example: You need to heal without breaking the deadlock?  Nah, this time the game only giving you an option to break the deadlock, heal, get raidlocked by enemies, BAM your squad downed  Let's use some strategy! Squad A to tank the damage while squad B attack from afar -> the command "Attack from  afar!!!" on squad B does not appear + the idle command does not appear  -> Your weak defense, high magic squad must fight the giant behemoth head on -> squad B downed.Technical wise surprisingly (compared  to other SE jrpgs, at least. *cough *cough* FF XIII series) this game has a superb port. Nice graphic options (not just simply low, medium, and high), good translation, good keyboard support (mouse support is meh but you don't really need a mouse for this game), and most of all no random CTD.Buy this game if you love JRPGs and can't stand not to play one. If you're not, only buy it when discounted.

number of helpful: 16 of 24 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												On the surface this game has a lot to offer, a nice art style, seemingly interesting characters and storyline and dungeons to explore. There is much to get acquianted with but long-time rpg players will quickly get the hang of it. However, personally I feel that any of the game's good ideas have already been done far better in the past. After playing for a fairly long time, around 50~ hours and sort of enjoying most of it, the game's faults finally caught up with me and the battles, farming for stuff in caves and the general gring of it all became too much. The battles seem huge and action packed at first but when you get familiar with it, it's just quick jump cuts to out of context scenes of one character striking another, looking at floating numbers and on to the next jump cut. Understanding that the fighting area of the whole world is really just the same huge flat space with no sense of distance or scale ultimately put me off and removed the little fun I had in the action of this game.The characters are akin to the Final Fantasy tactics games' lineup of mostly silent non-story characters who are just a part of your squadron and are ultimately replacable. In those games you could micro manage and customize them very specifically to your needs and sometimes new characters would be available to you for story reasons, however, again in The Last Remnant cutstomizability is turned down to telling each squadmate what to focus on, physical or magical attacks.The cities have some uniqe appeal to them with special scenery here and there, but as the game moved along it seemed as though the time spent on design diminished to the point where I couldn't tell the difference between the last 3 cities I was in. After playing through the first 5 or so dungeons/field levels you also start to see repeated patterns and quite frankly lazy and boring design choices, for example the floor is always completely flat with no elevation.There are a few good things with the game though, to be fair. The aggro and chaining system was fun and worked fairly well, deciding how many enemies at a time you could fight and try to get them to chase you around. The graphics were okay, the fighting effects were rewarding to watch the first 1000 times or so, and the world seemed open and interesting on first glance.Ultimately the game's faults outweighed its strengths and it became a boring, repetitive waste of time for me. There are already tons of good JRPGs just like this out there, and more to the point, I'd say play any one of those over this.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2016
												If you can forgive it's flaws, this game is quite unique and potentially very enjoyable. However, it has a ton of shortcomings. I'd give it maybe a 7/10. I'm only recommending the game because it's $10. If it were anymore, I don't think I could recommend it because there are just so many flaws.You can't properly control what your units do. There are many mechanics in the game that are way too convoluted and not at all well enough explained or explained at all. The story is meh. The dialogue is meh. You can't run away from battles. Many mechanics don't make sense or are just plain wonky. You can't equip your units! You have to buy stuff and hope somebody asks to wear it. What if you bought something that cost 900 million gold and hours worth of crafting components and nobody asks to use it? Well you're♥♥♥♥♥♥out of luck. The crafting system is tedious and a joke wth a gazillion different parts. The same enemy models are reused over and over and they jump in difficulty like crazy for no apparent reason sometimes in adjacent zones even though they have identical models and names and are right near each other. You explore the same zones over and over for side quests. If you're trying to be a completionist and do all the side quests, it can take a long time and can at times feel tedious and grindy. For me, I wanted to try an all-female party run, but there are not enough female characters to recruit, most of the female characters are generics, and they all have bad stats compared to the unique male characters so you end up really gimped and a lot of bosses are like HP checks so if you don't have the required HP you get rekt. Thankfully this game has auto-save in the PC version though.Some great, unique ideas in this game that just sadly weren't properly well done. The graphics are pretty good, especially for a 2009 game. A TLR 2 or a spiritual successor that takes this game's concepts but fixes its flaws would be amazing. Square Enix would never invest in such a gamble though I don't think. Especially not while they're just focusing on milking Final Fantasy series.

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2016
												An experimental game from Square Enix. Essentially it's a squad based semi-tactical JRPG. Why semi? Because unfortunately it heavily relies on RNG component rather than real tactics. You'll command a mini-army of 18 characters (units) divided by 4-5 squads, the problem is that you can only give them a set of commands (like, "attack with all you've got", or "help the others") and which skills/spells to use they'll decide on their own, for example if you want to bombard a certain enemy with a certain spell than you'll have to rely on luck, your units may decide to use them, use something else or even just simply attack with their weapons. There are few workarounds (essentially just having 3-5 people in a squad with a desired spell will boost chances of casting it or switching targets to get another set of commands) but sometimes it could lead to a very unfortunate results in your battles. I think it's the main reason why this game was not very well received.Despite all that it's still a very fun game to play, there are a lot of everything in this game: characters, weapons, skills, equipment etc. Believe me - quantity of everything is just enormous. Skill system is pretty complex but once you get a grip over everything you'll be pretty satisfied. There are also a lot of customization options for your army, you can hire generals, soldiers, make different formations, farm rare monsters for materials to upgrade weapons of your soldiers or simply craft them yourself.I guess you have to try it to understand whether it suits you or not, cause you wont be able to answer that question for yourself by watching related media and at this price I can certainly recommend this game, especially if you're into JRPGs and not afraid to try something new.My final score is 7/10.

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 27, 2016
												The Last Remnant.It's one of those rare games that compel you to keep on playing. A one off a kind JRPG created by Square Enix that focuses on skill based tactical combat rather than simple select action>hit enemy with playable characters as in the FF series. With several Hero characters & a lot of generic soldiers to choose from,each with their own styles & weapon sets,the amount of replayability is quite high while trying out the different teams & formations. Plus the ability to control the flow of battle by raising morale,inflicting status effects or simply bludgeoning through the enemies is an added bonus.  Plus there are guild tasks which can be completed to earn new formations,items,money & new certificates that unlock even more tasks & prizes.One drawaback of the game is its tendency to get repetitive as it heavily depends on grinding to build up skills & find materials to upgrade weapons & accessories. Plus monster spawns.especially the rare kind are randomly generated & sometimes it gets extremely frustrating to get a monster spawn at a specific area to get it killed & unlock new items & magazines that helps in getting previously unavailable monster drops.Overall,It's a great game to have for both RPG & JRPG fans as well as tactical gameplay lovers. The bosses are great & have a few hidden bosses(DLC) that are extremely tough to beat & requires careful planning & approach.It's also one of those few games that I have played & possessed as a torrent download,a disc & finally a digital distribution.My rating for the game will be a 8-8.5/10.

number of helpful: 13 of 19 people (68%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												I have beat the game and put in over 100 hours of active playing (I have a padded time in steam because of leaving the game on while doing other things) so I think I can give this a fair assessment.This was a bit of a let-down.The rich world and combat system had amazing potential, which fell woefully short on execution.Lets start with the world; you are given this great mystery of the remnants and trying to find an answer to their existence, but we are given a short and terrible story to progress through the game with. Towns and surrounding areas are all but-nonexistant because of the way they designed the maps to be enclosed and small. We are given a protagonist who is an utter idiot, and we are supposed to believe all these hyper-competent leaders want to follow this stupid kid who does nothing but mess up and make stupid on-the-fly decisions? The antagonist had potential. in the first disc whenever he shows up he is a pure badass, but then he keeps showing up randomly and leaves randomly. They were stretching it, it seems they just wanted him to do something badass and then disappear again, even though him being at that place and his subsequent actions make no sense. The voice acting is far below par, they have decent VAs but it seems the direction they were given was poor. The worst of it is the character animations during conversations and cutscenes. I read they had motion capture work done, and it seems ALL of it went into the combat animations which were amazing, but cutscene and conversation animations are so bad it is jarring, and it took me right out of what was happening. This is saying something, I have a high tolerance for mediocre character animation, this game crossed a line somewhere.Now the combat... Oh the combat, how you had the potential to be a JRPG game changer. "Lets take something tactical and add randomness and take away most of the player control, that would be brilliant!" No SquareEnix, no, stop it, stop... it... stop it. Side tangent; has noone in this world heard of ranged weapons? Are bows and crossbows too complex of an idea, do they have to cast most of their magic in melee range? The combat system of unions and leaders was an amazing idea, but once you get to the actual combat, it becomes garbage. I have 60+ AP to spend, why are all the actions available under 16? The best you can do is remove options you dont want showing up to increase the chance of getting something good, which doesn't work enough to not be very frustrating. All of your unions will want to bunch up when fighting enemies, only way to stop this is to make them stay back. But as I said, there is a distinct lack of ranged options. Most of the magic in this game does NOT have a ranged option, not even healing. The magic that DOES have a ranged option will greatly limit what that union can do that turn, and the best magic is ALL melee range. Worst of all, you can not then control your union positioning, you can spread out these tightly packed unions all attacking the same thing, which leaves rare monsters and bosses with wide area AoE attacks to really really really suck.So lets talk about what I did actually like about the game, the things that kept me interested enough to keep playing so long -- All the side things in the game. Hunting down rare monsters, getting my party members stronger, finding new unique leaders, toying with formations and union composition (especially for the really difficult opponents.)The main quest line might suck, but all the side things to do in this game are what provide content worth experiencing. I absolutely love the SaGa system of character progression, no more grinding out levels to overpower your opponent, you have to be smarter about how you approach bosses. This can be exploited of course, no leveling system is perfect, but for your first play through, you are unlikely to manipulate the system. There is another downside - where SaGa frontier games allow you to build a suitable party early, the unique leaders in Last Remnant are spread out. So, leaders you get early will be a lot stronger than ones you get later, they did not scale recruits to your Battle Rank (your level as it were) they merely gave them starting stats which they think is sufficient for that point in the game.Hunting down rare monsters and crafting materials... at points frustrating, very frustrating, but that just makes the pay off of getting them all the sweeter. Could have been handled better, sometimes the RNG really kicks you in the mouth.I can not honestly recommend this game, what it does well, others do it better so you are better off with those. I was strangely compelled to keep playing to the end, but too much was not enjoyable. I will not be coming back to this game at a later time like the vast majority of my other games, I will not feel like playing this game again, it will collect dust in my steam library. Best I can say is that I really got my money's worth, as I bought it during a steam sale.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												TLDR:The game is great, but a controller is near mandatory.Long version:Game Mechanics-This game's combat is really customizable, but at the same time it isn't. Let me explain. The core basics of the combat mechanics are to fill "unions" (think small parties of around 3-5 warriors) which are handled as 1 unit, and then use a "formation" (exactly what it sounds like) that complements what you would like them to achieve. Want them to hit things hard and fast? Use melee formation... Mage? Support? Use magic formation etc.. . There is also a "tactical" feel to combat, Unions can flank, intercept, deadlock... And do a lot of other things  which will influence how much damage is done to you, or the the enemy. Alongside the fact that you are usually controlling 2-3 "unions", the combat screen looks ♥♥♥♥ing great since that translates to around 15-20 warriors killing things.The downside of combat is as follows:-you can't change the equipment of your party. There are lots of weapons to be made and found, many which are race specific, but you can't equip it on the NPCs. In order for an NPC to change their weapon(s)  you A) have to have the weapon and B) the NPC has to ask you to use the weapon. -There are also a lot of classes/jobs but you are not told what their stats growths are, nor their upgrade paths. Sure you can look at a character's stats but apart from the obvious differences between a mage and warrior, it be hard to place an unit into a role - which is significant when forming an union/formation. Story- The story, and much around it, just feels O.K...- The characters are O.K -  I personally dislike the MC (think cliche dumbass anime protagonist)- The voice acting, save for a few characters, is O.K. - If you don't go back and re-explore towns after certain events, you can miss A LOT of side quests. Don't get me wrong, it is not a bad story but its not a great one either. Visual, Sound & Performance.- I have experienced very few bugs, and the ones that I have seen have been visual ones. (helicopter capes) - I have played on max settings, with no fps drops. The world looks good, but the combat screen is definitely much better. - The music is great. There are lots of different tunes for different towns, and different stages in combat. - A controller is a must. Keyboard/Mouse is supported but it felt somewhat clunky,  there are quick time events that trigger higher speed/dmg - these can be nightmares for keyboard users. There is an option to make them automatic at the downside that they computer can actually miss the trigger (probably for balance purposes)Overall a great game for its price.

number of helpful: 29 of 50 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												This is a Square made Final Fantasy style game that I never even heard about until I saw it on Steam.  Instead of 1-5 party members like most JRPG's, you get to have around 25 in a fight at a time.  Its broken into 5 man teams.  So each team gets a turn in combat each round. I'm on the fence about the game.  The quality is there because its a typical Final Fantasy world, which I love, but it seems that at a certain point the battles become a flip of a coin to win.  When one of your squads has a turn it has several options it can perform depending on how the party is set up.  Though these options are not stagnant options.  Out of the say 8 things possible that the squad can do only 4 options will randomly be chosen each turn.  This means that if your healer squad doesn't get the healing option for multiple turns it can mean game over.  You can mitigate this by removing options that a team can perform so that they don't clog up the limited action bar.  While that helps, you still often have to rely on luck and a coin flip to get an important action to occur at the right time.  This is the part that I can't get over.  There is little precision to the battles.  In normal fights the chaos can be really fun, but when a boss fight comes it can lead to a large helping of frustration.  It's fun and playable.  If 5 were my recommend mark, it sits at 4.  Very close but with a heavy heart I cannot recommend it.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
												Going into this game I was hoping to find a classic JRPG made by sqeenix, with the acceptable grind, lovely characters and an enjoyable time. Well I got anything but that last part.The maing gripe I have with the game is the difficult combat system paired with the penalizing Battle Rank (BR) system. The combat is nice once you get the hang of it, though I find it very confusing that the only way to learn the combat normally; trying to get into as many fights as you can, is penalized heavily by the BR system.The BR system is not your level, but it's a rank that goes up according to the amount of fights you've had, the higher it gets the more difficult the enemies get. Not so bad right? Well if you manage to somehow get your BR high before a section of the game played in Nest of Eagles you may very well get stuck here, this only being the first half of the game leads you to redo the entire game up to that point, mostlikely following a guide telling you to keep your BR low. (Not what happened in my case, but I was close to doing this)Not only does the BR system make the fights harder it also makes powering up the later characters you get in part 2 harder to make useful. Now this happened to me. The workaround being farming a unique monster called Bai Ze or in this releases case you could also opt to farm insects at the cost of two unique units. This allows you to farm your characters up to an acceptable stat range or to help you in cheesing the game.The combat is done in unions; groups of characters in formations, different formations give different stat bonuses. The unions then have "random" actions that they can do. Herein lies the problem, the actions I want to do are the actions that, most of the time, are not readily available while I feel this takes away from the strategic point of view, it enforces defensive play and working with what you have; it does however make the difficulty of the strategy feel articficial since instead of giving a difinitive way to take on a fight, you have to hope you get those actions to pop-up.The problem comes from the combat and penalizing BR system, you try to learn the game and do all the sidequests once they're all available, raising your BR to a level the game didn't expect you to have and making the rest of the fights too difficult to progress. The sidequests may be optional but some of them become too much to handle, the solutions being to farm a unique monster, to spam hard to trigger arcana spells, and to change your formation into one that simply bumrushes the boss and hope that they die before you get killed. If you still think the game is a fair challenge after this go ahead and buy it, I know it's old but for a game to be unforgiving to a point where you cannot progress the story is just wrong.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												This is a great JRPG. At first, seems a sub-Final Fantasy title (and, concerning story, characters and the world, it certainly is), but the stellar combat makes it something special. Also, it's a +100 hours game, even if you don't do all the quests and guild tasks. I played it for 103 hours and got to level 92, without grinding or being too much of a completist. It took me almost 10 hours to get the hang of combat, but after I understood its system, the game became really exciting. At first seemed like the characters were playing by themselves, but you start to realize how important strategy is. The most important thing is keeping a high morale, by flanking and intercepting the enemy and not letting him do the same to you. And, as the characters learn new "arts", you have more options and the battles get way more interesting _ specially when you "link" several enemies and becomes outnumbered. You can also enable QTEs during combat, to perform critical hits and to parry or counterattack _ it takes a while to get them right and it will make you curse at the screen, but it's great fun.There were some boss fights that appeared to be impossible, but became a breeze after I changed strategy. This is a game that's not hard at all, but fair: play it well and you'll have a good time. Besides that, there's a lot of customization, from items to military formations.It's a pity the developers didn't add achievements and trading cards. I'd also love a sequel.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14
												Quest Based JRPG with an unconventional Battle System and drawn out plot. The plot is unique in that it's about political turmoil and backstabbings. Which isn't anything new, but certainly new enough for JRPG's. I enjoyed it well enough, but I can understand if the lack of drama might keep others from being interested in what's going on. Most JRPG's are character-driven, and here it's written with the main actors really being the states and the powerful remnants that reside within each (and the conspiracy fabricated to take control of them all). The title starts out with the simple task of you rescuing your sister, but it becomes quite evident that something much larger is at play and in rescuing her you become allied with a Duke (Nukem) and embroiled in his objectives. Some might get a little confused with some of the political bable and the various actors, but it's an easy wiki to get your mind back on track.That aside, this game is all about the battle system. A battle system the game doesn't bother to elaborate on.The short end of it is that you have unions each with a max of 5 members each. They're basically party members put into small companies that make a mini militia. The enemy is very much the same way, and battles play out between these companies, but since the company has one unified healthbar they're, for all intents and purposes, one ''unit'' in battle and its units attacking units trying to get their HP to 0. You don't control the units in the unions directly (max of 5 per union), rather you give commands to the entire union, like ''Hang in there!'' and ''Attack from afar!''. You can see what these commands will lead to, so it's not too bad. But it can be aggrivating not being able to prioritize what attacks come out with limited AP (regenerates every turn). You might choose for a union to go into heal mode, but the one unit that has a massive AOE heal ignores the command and attacks whilst the other two that can only use herbs that heal for a miniscule amount do the healing. Generally though the game does a really good job at making this a painless way to control your units and I never felt cheated.The game provides many options in setting formations for your unions, with varying effects for each. The problem is that they're not really explained in-depth and, according to most of the community at least, they're not required to play through the game. It's a nice addition but not required to get a grip on. Most of the side-game is doing quests that lead to new union members or simple money rewards, with some resulting in new weapons. There's two things about this game that are bull♥♥♥♥ though:-some quests disappear if you progress too far into the story. There's no warning of this.-You don't gain XP, but you gain Battle Rank (BR). There's no ''BR'' bar to show how close you are to your next rank, but gaining BR is bad as it makes the enemies stronger; lower BR increases stat gains per battle which makes your units stronger faster and it makes it a less grindy ordeal. In a game where you get party members as the game progresses this is bad, as they start out weaker and weaker the higher and higher your BR is and it becomes harder and harder to level them up. The second critique is this game's huge achielles heel. In many ways you're persuaded not to engage in battles until the midway point of the game where you will have most of the party members available to you. Whilst the entire party shares a culminative HP; the units can still be targetted and fall to instant KO spells or killed individually. If a party member is dead at the end of battle they gain nothing from the battle. Apparently this aspect of the game was rushed as they had to get it out. The fact that this isn't explained thoroughly in game is another sore point on this title: there is a severe lack of documentation. Seriously, some aspects of the game the community isn't fully sure of because it's not really explained. I have over 100 fuc*ing hours in this game and I'm still COMPLETELY IN THE DARK about some things. There's this quest where you get different rewards and people aren't sure what the HELL you have to do to get the best rewards. Something tells me the devs didn't really care if the player knew about some things or what exactly the mechanics or effects are and didn't think you needed to know. It's fine if you don't care but aggrivating if you do.Aside from that, with 100 hours in, it's a generally ''new'' feeling game for its story and how the battle system works. It's not ground-breaking and I wouldn't say it's a must-play, but it's not offensive and does tries enough different things for a JRPG that I'll give it a recommendation. I'd say skip it if you don't care for RPG's, but give it a shot if you need something to play/a JRPG and are feeling adventurous in how 'new' you want the experience to be. If there was ever a proper sequel with some fixes I'd be there in a minute.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												The Last Remnant is a bit different from any other SquareEnix games.  I almost quit playing about 6 hours in because I was still having trouble understanding the combat system and frankly, the main character was kind of annoying.  For whatever reason, I decided to keep playing just a little bit more to see if it got any better.  90 hours later, I'm glad I didn't stop.  The story really started to grab me.  The game world feels large and alive with each of the towns having its own varied population and scenery.  There's so many extra characters that start becoming available the further in you go.  There are ups and downs to the game, but I'd definitely give it a run if you're a fan of SquareEnix RPG's, even if this one's a bit different from what they generally put out.  I'll try to break things down a bit.Combat and leveling is definitely odd.  Without looking up any guides, I was probably around 20 hours into the game before it REALLY started to click how everything worked.  Fights take place by you giving a general command to each unit with things like "Attack with combat arts" or "Give defensive support" and your units will automatically use whatever abilities they decide to from that category rather than you specifically saying what each move should be.  This takes a little getting used to since most RPG's let you spell out what set of moves you want to happen.  Every battle you get through it seems like at least one character will level up at least one ability.  Which abilities get leveled up depend on what style of attacks those characters did during the battle.  The amount of XP each character gets is based on how strong you are versus the enemies, how many enemy units there are in the battle, and how quickly you defeat them.  You can also end up with different special attacks that become available depending on which character is in charge of each battle unit.  There's a lot of intricacies invovled in the battle and leveling system that can seem confusing in the beginning, but they'll become second nature once you're a ways into the game.  I've heard it's possible to end up in a spot where it's impossible to progress if you're at a "bad" level when you get into certain areas, so it's a good idea to keep a few different saves running.  I've found though that you can sometimes overcome what seems like an unwinable battle by just shifting around your team members to different units, changing their formations, or even changing your tactics for the battle to hold one or more units back from the fight.Weapons, armor, and accessories are kind of an odd thing in this game.  You can only directly equip them on your one main character.  All of your side characters will continue to automatically level up their own equipment as the game goes on OR if you happen to buy something they like enough, they'll ask you if they can "borrow it" when you're on one of the map screens.  For me, this lead to my buying virtually every weapon/armor/accessory I could afford in addition to upgrading them repeatedly throughout the game just to see if someone would want one.  Once in a while it actually pays off and you'll get something really good into another characters hands.  For the most part though, it seemed like they didn't care what I was buying, so I ended up with a massive pile of unusable equipment and upgrade parts by the end of the game.Side quests are plentiful.  I probably spent a good 2/3 of the time I played just working side quests, if not more.  You end up having to do a bit of back and forth on the world map at times to get those side quests to come up, but it's not a big deal since travel between sites is instant.  The side quests themselves seemed varied and fit in real well with the game world.  I found it was a nice way to get extra background info on the world lore and your characters themselves.  I'm not sure what percentage of the side quests I got through by the end of my 90 hour run, but I'm sure there were still a lot left to do since I didn't collect a large number of the other side characters that were available to be had, and a lot of them seem to have their own side quest lines you can do.Graphics, sound, and music are all good.  It's SquareEnix, so it matches with what they do in general for their other games, though the cut scenes aren't quite as ultra detailed as some of the Final Fantasy games that are out around the same time frame.  Nothing to be disappointed in there.  The battle music also changes around based on how strong you are versus the enemies and how well the flow of battle is going if things drag on, which keeps things from being too overly repetative since you can spend quite a while playing this game.Overall this is a great title to check out if you're into RPG games with light strategy.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												This game is 99% combat-based and the combat is uninspired.  Every turn, you only get five choices as to what to do and those choices appear to be predetermined.  This leads to frustration because, for example, in a boss fight your "union" (group of up to 5 troops) may lose half of their health in one attack.  Logic dicates you better heal up so you can survive another attack.  Game doesn't give you the option because your health isn't low enough.  Then there's random number generator (RNG)♥♥♥♥♥♥where the AI does their most powerful attack (sometimes capable of taking out multiple unions in one attack) repeatedly.  Game over, man, game over.  Even if you're leveled well beyond the enemy you're fighting, you may have to retry the fight many times before the RNG decides in your favor handing you a victory.  Games like this should be about knowing thy enemy and stratgizing, not random rolls.  In order to progress in the game without getting♥♥♥♥♥♥♥all of the time, you have to grind, and grind, and grind some more.  I'm asking myself why?  I've got two other games I'd rather play right now and it's not like this game has convinced me the story is worth finishing.  It's disjointed and explains little.  I started feeling apathetic towards the plot about 30 hours ago.  The only reason why I care about the plot is because it is the only way to command more unions and get more troops to put in said unions.I could go on a long time nitpicking about lots of things from the bland environments (pathetic for a 2008 game) to the repetitive music (I think there's only one combat song and that only changes if morale gets to the bottom) to the quick-time-events (you want to look at health guages, attacks coming up, etc. but if you do that, you'll miss the QTE which could easily translate to losing the battle) to the inability to change troop equipment (they ask to "borrow" equipment from your unequipped inventory).I suppose there's some people out there that love this kind of game but I am not among them.Edit: The above was written after 37 hours of playing the game.  Because I was long past tired of the combat, H4X0R Mode Engaged! (one hit kills on unions) and the game still took 65 total hours to finish.  I think this would be a pretty darn good game if it ended in ~40 hours but the combat...just...drags...on...forever...and ever...and ever...  it gets in the way of everything else that is otherwise passable.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												Honestly, this is the worst RPG I have ever played. I checked the Wiki and managed to get about halfway through the game and about 1/3 done with all side-quests. I've simply given up on this game; I was going to try to 100% it, but I simply can't. It's too bad.For starters, the writing is incredibly bad. Rush Sykes is, by far, not only the most one-dimensional main character but also is by far the most annoying in any video game I've ever played. His only motivation is his sister; of course, it's charismatic and very noble that he wants to go so far to save his sister, but that's it. No other interests, nothing in his life. Hell, none of the other characters really have anything going on in their lives either. It's all "for Athlum" this or "for Rush's sister Irina" that. All the characters are incredibly flat and unbelievable; usually I'm able to find a character I love, but I simply couldn't here. I cared for absolutely nobody during my time playing. They all seemed to be pawn's for my battles, and that was it. Nothing more.You have no control over any of the characters during combat - you can specify what sort of action you want them to take (heal, spells, skills, etc), but ultimately you aren't able to change the order these things happen in. This is very frustrating - for instance, I know one of my characters has an attack that can silence enemies, but I can't have him actually use that spell. It's randomized whether he'll use it or not. It's seriously moments like these that lead me to, not only dying, but getting game over over and over again. The game is punishing me for not being able to control my damn characters. You also can't customize their equipment; you're completely limited to changing the main character's equipment throughout.To be honest, the world was fascinating at first. I enjoyed how this world did not have the standard human/elf/dwarf paradigm that many RPGs seem to have nowadays. The races constructed here are very unique and unlike anything I'd ever seen in an RPG before. It was truly a nice breath of fresh air. However, I realized that this world feels practically dead. The only real life that seems to be going on is the beasts prowling around the linearly frustrating dungeons or the vastly open, yet still dead, landscapes. NPCs in cities seem to just stand there and really don't offer anything intelligent, or exciting, to say. All the cities in the game really don't have anything going on - they're simply there for getting side quests and for buying new equipment, but really nothing is going on. It all just really felt dead, like they were simply there, which is disappointing. The point of an RPG is to escape into some sort of fantasy world (and typically to save it), but what's the point of trying to escape into a world that doesn't even remotely feel real?All in all, I can't recommend this game. I bought it during the Steam Sale (I believe for less than $5) and didn't believe it was worth it for me. If you want a game that gives you no control over it's characters, is cumbersome, very bland, and has a good amount of content (but is only available at a limited time - after the halfway point a lot of the quests close), then this game may be for you. It, unfortunately, wasn't for me.

Posted: April 28, 2014
												I see not how this game is an RPG, you have no control over your units, you have no control over what they weild, you have no control over how they move, nothing. A game where 90% of it is controlled by an idiotic AI, a game where only luck would judge whether you win or lose. This, is one of the worst games I've ever played. 66/100 on metacritic? Bah, giving it 20 would be generous!I don't mind a difficulty, but I've discovered playing through this sad excuse of a game that there is a difference between being a difficult game, and a frustratingly annoying one. Though the like of demon/dark souls fit the former, this one takes the crown of being the latter. There is little difficulty in TLR except for the one inhereted from the player's lack of any form of solid control. JRPGs were never about skill, but to make one dependant nearly completely no luck? Seriously?The shoddy story, poor execution and sub-par coding aren't helping it either. Square Enix ruined Final Fantasy, and their attempts to create something new is even worse. Hell, if I had tried this one before FFXIII, I might have saved my self some of its disappointment. I can see the similarities. Why not just pull a FFXII or a Dragon Age and let the AI be customizable at least? Damn you, SE! Damn you!

content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												SquareEnix released this game back in 2011 for PC (on Steam) and 2009 for the XBox360 - and it shows. Below is a comprehensive list of Pros and Cons, as well as some Middling views after beating the game.PROS:+ Story     The story is fairly simple, as is the main character, Rush. He's introduced running into a battlefield while two armies fight - anybody that dumb is surely the main protagonist I want to root for. But, all kidding aside, the story has the basic elements to make it interesting enough to grab ahold of your attention.+ Graphics     The scenery is absolutely beautiful, and you can tell a lot of detail went into the water/background effects, the way that every city or town has their own unique architecture, and every cave or open area feels both wide open and yet closed off simultaneously, as if something is just over the horizon.+ Music     While the battle music does fluctuate randomly (more on that below) the tracks themselves are very good at what they do. The sad music is appropriately tear-jerking, the Uh-Oh music is ready to make you panic a little, and the fight music makes you want to swing a claymore through somebody's torso at times.+ Gameplay     A much-contested portion of this game, based on numerous Critic- and Reader Reviews online, is that the battle system is very interesting. I have to agree - "Interesting" being the operative word here. Some battles are over before they begin, for good or ill, and that makes some fights tedious but mostly it's fair enough to not have to re-re-fight something for the umpteenth time because that one character is too slow.MIDDLINGS:~ Travel     You start off the game by running through a cavern. And... that's the entirety of the game. At least, so it seems for the first hour or so. You run here, run there, watch a cutscene, run somewhere else, more cutscenes, finally explore a cave or castle and... more running. Thankfully, once you've discovered a city/cave/dungeon/area, you can just warp to the main entrance directly from the main map, so it's not a huge slog all the time.~ Areas     The scenery is beautiful, but it's so empty. Every open field is huge - really, really big - and you feel so small. Great, right? Well... no, not really. You can sit and stare at the walls for so long before you want to get to where the story or the fighting is going on, but first you need to run down huge expanses of empty field or desert to get there.~ Fighting     If the battle system is great, that means that something has to be wrong with the fights - they're interesting enough initially with a small number of people and a semi-large group of enemies (2-4), but that quickly becomes tedious. So they increase the amount of "unions" (groups) available, making the micro-managing element reappear in a shiny new suit. But it's still the Final Fantasy XIII method of winning most of the fights: Mash Enter/Space/X/A to win.~ Music     The cities and towns share music. The dungeons share music. The only places I know of that have their own musical scores are the optional places to go visit, and even then the music is pretty bland after three hours of it. Battle music especially is annoying, seeing as how it jumps based on how the fight is going. Going badly? Bad music; good fight, good music. Bosses are notorious for this at times, with notable exception being the final boss.~ Characters     Loads. Almost 300 named characters, each with somewhat distinct characteristics. That "mitra" (human) is a healer, this one's a sword-and-board fighter, and that one uses explosives. Varied and interesting enough for the Generals - that is, the Unique characters you can assign/recruit - to make it so you know who's who right off the bat.~ Voices     The in-battle and after-battle dialogue is especially tedious after the 20+ hour mark. You really start to hate the way somebody says something about "needing the other one, the other one!" every time they level up. To be fair, hearing Pagus (a main character) give you a backhanded comment on how that spell was "effective" is a nice touch.CONS:- Grinding     This game is tiring, and that's because about 85% of the game is running around killing the same enemies hundreds of times for that one item you need to make the one piece of gear that's a slight upgrade to the piece you're already wearing. Not to mention Mr. Diggs (albeit the best character in the game) is necessary to acquire the ores/metals you need to upgrade or create most of the gear you want, so that's also a factor.- Diggs     The aforementioned Mr. Diggs is a unique aspect to the mining process - a weird rabbit-like creature with huge pink round eyes that dances when it gains a level - but it only adds to the grinding nature of the game. You first acquire him with 5 digs available - he can mine grass or rocks 5 times before you need to exit to the world map and come back in. That, in of itself, isn't so bad; the bad part is that the digsites, and what you acquire from them, are randomized every time you load up the map.- Crafting     No game from Squeenix these days seems to be complete without some kind of Creation gimmick, and TLR is no exception. The gear you make is better than what you buy, and what you buy is the base for what you make. So you've done your 3+hours of Digging and killing monsters and finally have enough materials to upgrade your weapon for a... +3 attack damage output. That's just ludicrous, and not in a fun way, either.- Parties     You start out with a small party of about 3-5 people in it, reasonable enough when learning the game, but you don't actually increase the size of that initial party until a good two hours into the game. Seeing as how you go up against bosses and groups of enemies (6-7 groups at most, with about 3-4 enemies in each group) with your small team, it almost seems unfair the lengths you need to go to survive encounters.     So you've crafted that unique 2-handed sword for your beefy tough guy? Too bad, you can't equip it on him manually. Everything is done automatically for you, when the game decides it wants to let them have the item. And even then, without memorizing who's who, you may accidentally give that new weapon to your healer and not your damage dealer.     In combat, your main group could be near death and the others are at top health. There is no "heal me" or "heal them" option available unless the game decides it wants to give one to you. The micro-managing aspects that people said have disappeared from this game are what make it so annoying at the same time. There are times when yes, I really do want to use certain attacks by a certain character on a certain enemy, because I know it'll work really well - but the game decides that said character is going to try and level their fighting ability and not that healing spell I'm trying to increase.- Combat     The game already takes forever in terms of grinding, and thankfully, the PC port has given us the ability to speed up the fights. It is wonderful - and yet, the sheer volume of fighting negates that entire wonderful feeling. You're going to end up seeing the same monsters again, and again, and again, for nearly the entire game. There is only one part of the main quest where Giants come into play, and only in that one section. The rest of the time, it's generic enemy models.- Enemies (field)     As stated above, the types of enemies shown on the field are very few in distinction. What is very aggravating are their hit-boxes; the area in which they can start a fight against you. It isn't well defined or even shown, and a gentle tap from a flying enemy above you where you can't see it starts a fight where they get a free turn.BOTTOM LINE: If the game's on sale, and you like tactical RPGs, go for it. Otherwise, just play Final Fantasy.(Or Blue Dragon for the 360, it's like this but better.)

content:
Posted: April 13, 2014
												I wish I could give this game a recommendation.  It's got a solid foundation, with an interesting game mechanic, and it reminds of classic Final Fantasy games.  However, there are really serious flaws that make a possibly great game almost unplayable.  Unless you are a big nerd for JRPGs, stay away.Some of the flaws are as follows:1. This is a port of the XBox game.  They didn't even bother to change the quicktime icons that appear during battle, and they don't tell you what they are, either, but they are in the settings.  Still, it's a lazy job of porting it that undercuts the quality of the game significantly.2.  The battle mechanic is interesting, but ultimately flawed - it's almost like there wasn't enough playtesting.  Skills that target one enemy are the norm, and what the majority of both your characters and enemy characters use.  Unfortunately, the game is quickly dominated by AoE spells capable of killing multiple units.  Characters are organized into groups, which have a shared HP pool, and if they are hit by an AoE spell, it may just hurt one character, or it may hit them all (including characters in other groups).  Because the shared HP is much less than the sum of each character's HP, a group hit usually results in the group being seriously injured or killed in one shot, and too many enemies cast group attacks.  The group attacks should have been seriously nerfed.  On the bright side, you also get these spells - but then the game simply consists of you figuring out which action choice will lead to your character busting out one of these AoE spells and then doing that over and over.3.  Speaking of action choices: it's only possible to give up to 5 orders (per enemy) - this means that a unit that desperately needs to perform a certain act might not be able to, for reasons that are never clear.  Additionally, you can only ask for certain classes of actions to be performed, rather than specific abilities.  This is kind of neat, as it leaves only the larger tactics to you, but the problem is that the AI is flaky.  Your units will often do stupid things, like target a single unit with a group spell, or just fail to cast a useful spell because the enemy group has been defeated (but the battle is not over).   Also, you may have a TON of AP, but you may only get options to use a few, and so you waste a turn because of the game, not because of some mistake on your part.Additionally, the plot is some Square Enix gibberish that is completely unengaging.  Square-Enix used to be one of my favorite publishers, and I would really love a good Final Fantasy style game.  If they would stick with the stuff that worked instead of trying to innovate, they could really make some very good games.

												There is a lot to like about this game.  I definitely recommend the game, but I wanted to give a warning to potential buyers.  This is one of those games where you can run into a brick wall of difficulty in several places.  Make sure you take your time, get all the generals you can get, spend the time to get the best gear, and learn all the different aspects of combat.  If you aren't use to tactical positioning, you will end up crushed in a few places.  If you aren't use to using statuses (negative and positive) you will get stuck.  If you rely too heavily on ultimate attacks, you will lose.  Take your time and learn the game well, or you will get very frustrated.7.5/10  Fun, but you can get stuck very easily, leading to restarts.

content:
Posted: January 7
												This game is interesting and very unique. I am still conflicted about whether I really recommend it or not though. To be honest I have not finished the game yet, and am only writing the review now because I have stopped playing the game for now. There are many things to love and hate, and to be fair I recognize that this is a game that was made on a game engine that was brand new to the development team at SE. To put it briefly, for everything I liked about this game, there was a part of that feature that drove me nuts.So here's the deal, things to love about this game include the diverse and culturally rich world with lots of different characters that are all pretty cool. The graphics are awesome (as expected from an Unreal engine game). The story is captivating and enjoyable. There is plenty to do in this game. The battle system is a must see and is almost worth buying just to experience it because it is so unique, or at least it is not like anything I have ever seen before.Now, things that will get on your nerves... (unfortunately it is often easier to say more about the negative, but that doesn't mean the game is more negative than positive)While the world is amazing there not as much revealed about it as I wanted. You see many different races of characters and they all live together apparently peacefully, but why? They have diversity, but don't really use it very much in the story. The characters could have all been human and it would have made little difference. Their attributes in battle are not even that different.The story is great, but admittedly hard to follow (not a surprise from a JRPG really). It was easy to get lost because there is not always indication of where to go to advance the story. Side quests offer some fun side stories, but can be terribly confusing even when using a guide.The graphics look awesome, but the non-movie animations are awkward. Even some of the movies have parts where the voice acting do not line up with the expressions and movements (translation problem, maybe?)The battle system is very impressive in concept, but nigh impossible to figure out. After 60+ hours of gameplay I still don't know what I am doing. Simply stated, it is a convuluted mess that is overcomplicated and chaotic. There are so many variables and things to adjust that I was just overloaded and gave up trying to figure it out. Even forums of experienced players can't make a lot of sense out of it. It seems most players ignore the majority of it and for good reason. You can recruit from a huge assortment of characters, use over a dozen different formations, assign leaders, occasionally be given the choice to have them focus on magic or combat, all of it makes little sense though and possibly little difference. It is essentially information overload in an attempt to give the player the choice to devise their own strategy. Speaking of strategy though, actual battle gives you little control at all. You simply give a general command and the characters choose which moves to use themselves. This can be super frustrating because what you want to do is sometimes not an option. Also, there are so many different variables in battle that you could fight the same battle twice using the same commands, and you might lose terribly the first time and win by a landslide the next. So much for all the strategy... I used a stat grinding trick for about 6 hours from a guide I found online and my characters grew incredibly, but still I have battles that just end badly. Luckily there is an autosave feature on PC, but you must turn it on first. It is off by default.The character progression makes little sense. You know battling monsters makes you stronger and it would appear the stronger the monster, the greater the growth. Things like exp points are absent or invisible. Stats are shown on character views, but no indication of how far along the progress is or how to increase it. Each character also has a unique stat that no one knows what it actually does. There is a Battle Rank which would appear to be synonymous with Level in other RPGs, but it is not really explained what it means. Guides actually show that Battle Rank is better the lower it is because the battles get harder the higher it is. Monsters are stronger the higher your Rank is, which happens to be a feature of some RPGs that I absolutely despise because it makes all the time battling and grinding completely unsatisfying. Final Fantasy 8 works similarly, so if you have played that you might be familiar with it. As the story progresses you increase the number of characters you can use in battle, but you don't reach the max until late in the game, so your characters will end up heavily imbalanced because only characters you use will grow.Sometimes what I like most about JRPGs is the soundtrack. I will say this game's is a rather generic fantasy one though. It is ok, but nothing to write home about. Certainly not one I would listen to outside the game. I actually find myself playing on mute though, listening to my own music or watching a show while I grind. All in all, I give it a 3 out of 5. I stopped playing because I lost interest and after reading a ton of guides and forums I decided it is so unnecessarily complicated that I don't care to figure it out. I just want to see the rest of the story and have it be over. I guess I will recommend it because if you haven't played anything like it before, it is an interesting experience. I bought mine in a Final Fantasy bundle, so if you can find it in one of those for cheap, it is worth buying.

number of helpful: 26 of 47 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2016
												Personal Rating: I liked the game but it's flawed.Classic Rating: ★★★☆☆✓ Why did I like it?Well, this is the second JRPG game I played in my life, being FFVIII the first one - and I loved that, spent an insane amount of hours couch-playing with my PSX.The Last Remnant is not a masterpiece: graphics are not that good but not even bad - you can smell a console game a mile ahead; story is quite nice but I haven't completed the game yet, so I don't have a full view - I loved all of the cutscenes so far though, they add up a lot to the game; characters (mainly your party) are not so deeply developed but you get a quite well detailed picture despite everything.. Music, voice acting and sound effects are quite good too, they fit game play but also get repetitive (boring?) after a decent amount of hours spent in combat.✘ Why is it flawed?Because... You already know, don't you? This cannot be the first review you've read about this game.Anyhow, combat/inventory systems are flawed, it's not just a tough game.Fighting can be a PITA because the game offers you only a limited set of choices: what I found terrible is that most of the time I had to battle a Boss I couldn't heal, because there was no option to do that.. I could only fight. And you can believe me that when a Boss strikes, it can take away half of your HP and that's not all... There are attacks and counter-attacks, so you might receive additional damage in one turn and if you're not given an option to heal as soon as you need it, it's game over - no workarounds.Basically you'll have to grind in order to fight Bosses and I understand that's part of the game, levelling up while doing side quests and so forth, but it can be annoying too.


That's what I was talking about.. I can't heal :-( 
A Screenshot of The Last Remnant
By: roughnecks




Inventory is half broken too because you can't manage your party's. Say you have some objects sitting in your inventory - a potion, a weapon or anything else -  you can't trade it to another companion because it's not possible at all. They can only request you things after you have harvested or crafted them: I read about a hack which lets you edit/use inventories the way they are supposed to, but I personally didn't want to take that route.Most of my friends warned me about these issues I've been talking of, but I didn't want to listen before actually trying myself.. You know how it went, I have to agree with them.I won this game in a giveaway, so I am not regretting buying it but I can't recommend it anyway (especially if you're not a true fan of the genre) even if my actual feelings about The Last Remnant are mostly positive.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												I've been playing for a couple days now with 15 hours of gameplay and my initial opinion of the game is not that great. The world that is presented to you is interesting but many of the characters are incredibly annoying and story telling isn't particularly good either. The main character is a whiney little brat that makes stupid decisions one after another. The game also has a very deep character development system but it is muddled with hidden stats which make it difficult to tell if you're going the right direction.The combat system has potential to be great but it is very frustrating. Besides the extremely frustrating battle command system, it's not uncommon to run into battles where you can be instantly wiped out without anything you can do to prevent it so saving is your best friend. 1 union vs 5? Yeah, you don't even get the option to heal and round one you die. Boss fight? He's got an aoe attack that can 1 shot your party and uses it every other turn. Without using a guide, figuring out the battle commands is nearly impossible and even using a guide, it is often quite frustrating. Character development is also annoying because there are many hidden stats that are factoring into character class and development. If these stats were visible, it would make the game much better and if you could always tell your units exactly what to do it would make the game immensely better. But that is not the case so it lends itself to an incredibly frustrating learning curve. If I had paid full price for this I would have returned it in a heartbeat. At $4 I still feel annoyed that I spent the money on it. I feel like this game had a lot of potential that just wasn't capitalized on. If you do end up giving it a shot, don't grind early on. It only hurts you. And start reading a guide from the start to save yourself a ragequit. If you're not using a controller, in the game settings on the controller page, there is an option to change which buttons the tooltips show (xbox, ps3, keyboard, etc.). Change this to keyboard. And to skip cutscenes, hit Pause/Break and then S to skip.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Combat - likeable, a turn-based combat with unique squad designation systemBUTThe core mechanic - "Battle Rank" system is poorly executed. The more monsters you kill, the higher your battle rank goes. This will lead to bosses and other enemies scaling to your battle rank to be a lot more tougher to provide you with bigger challenge. That's fine, in fact, I like the idea as it seems similar to the Final Fantasy 8's level scale system. However, there is no real character level in this game and you are randomly given stat increases after certain number of battle based on how high your battle rank is as well as what kind of commands you have given out to your party members during combat. What this means is that your enemies may scale with your battle rank and grow stronger consistently while your own party may or may not and this can lead someone to completely stagnate themselves at certain points in this game. There is no real sense of progression, it's more favorable decision to avoid any side quests and field enemy encounters to keep things in balance. What kind of RPG does this?

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												Last Remnant is a JRPG with some good production values and it is worth buying cheap on that count alone. The 'thing' with Last Remnant is the combat system that lets you put up to an army of characters into battle for you. To do this however the game engine has a lot of complexity and much is this is shielded from the player by automation. If you let the automation do everything then you're not involved much and your characters won't improve. However the problems come when you naturally try to understand what's happening and manage the automaton. Unfortunately, it's just difficult to get past the automation and the manual doesn't help you to do it at all. For example there massive amount of detailed itemization in the game and it is important to equip your characters well, however you can't give them items unless they ask for it. They typically won't ask for stuff you want them to have, but if they do they ask for the wrong item, the wrong person asks for it, the same person asks for everything, and even if they take something they might discard it for something worse later. That's just one side of the itemisation problems as well.So anyway, there are a lot of good things in just playing Last Remnant but it encourages you look into the complexity and disappoints when it is frequently opaque.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												As a fan of RPGs new and old, I was tempted to purchase this game as I've heard many things about this "hidden gem". Sadly, I was disappointed to find out how big of a let down this game was.Jumping into the game without knowing anything about it aside from the title, I was pleasantly surprise and confused to see the game in action, jumping straight into the first battle. But seeing the game in action, it caught my interests and I was more than excited to continue and try to figure out how the game worked. Unfortunately, after 12+ hours of playing, the game felt like it was on a constant tutorial, only to find out the game really didn't have much to offer. As interesting as the game looked, the strategy within the game play comes off as extremely shallow, leaving little to no planning even in the most difficult combat situations. The idea behind the game play is extremely interesting and had so much potential, but alas falls short, lacking depth in every aspect behind it. In other words; what you see is what you get.The story itself is a complete joke, as it feels like it's parody of an old anime that I've never seen before. It makes senses, but the story is laughably lame, as with the behavior the main character is so unpredictable yet very forgivable regardless of the outcome.The dungeon design are completely lack luster, as it feels like almost every dungeon is design to be shaped like a Y or an L, and copy paste from there. I never felt lost, and had I come across a dead end, I back track over to a fork in the path I missed, pulled a trigger, and the dead end was averted. Funny thing is, that's basically every dungeon in the game.The Battle music in this game is great, fitting the tone and idle animations of the characters fighting off their opponents as they wait for you to make a decision on their next action. It's a nice touch, as it almost looks like the party members are hyped up with the music, which also gives out a great arcade-ish feel for each battle (which is not a bad thing for me). Sadly, all songs outside the battle tracks are completely forgettable.All in honestly, I'd say to avoid this title at all cost and play another RPG title instead... literally any other RPG. If you're still curious, I'd say wait for a sale.
