content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												It's too bad this game came out too soon for the Xbox 360 and ruined its potential. That version was buggy as all get-out and nearly unplayable and, as such, was reviewed with a very strong negative light. This version fixes pretty much every single graphical and technical issue that made that one unplayable and thus is allowed to shine.I'm mostly a console gamer these days(even though I've been playing PC and Console games both since I was 4 in 1987), so I live for Square Enix games and know their history very well. I worshipped at their feet in the glory days before the merger. They haven't been great since, but for me, The Last Remnant is one of the few standout IPs they've had since they left their old Squaresoft monicre behind them.This game is equal parts JRPG, strategy, and story-driven RPG. The combat is the main draw and probably the most unique form of turn-based I've seen in many years. Battles take place in a pseudo-strategic form where the player holds many groups of 3+ toons forming smaller parties broken off from the main group of up to 25 party members. You can fight groups of enemies as large as 75+ forming wave after wave and it really lends itself to the whole "continental war" vibe that the story tries to evoke. It's something you don't see often, if ever and it's very engrossing. There is well over 100 hours of content to explore from sidequests to mob hunting to the main story itself and it very rarely gets old. On the pc, t graphics shine and the art style and creativity of the world is awe-inspiring at times. It is, again, something largely unique in the world of JRPGs. It doesn't feel too much like Final Fantasy, but you can see the influence.One of the best aspects of this game, believe it or not, is the music. Take the best soundtracks of the FF franchise and combine it with hard rock compositions by some of Japans best and you have a soundtrack unlike any other out there. I bought the 3+ disc soundtrack I love it so much. It really heightens the impact during combat and brings you in that much more.All in all I'd say any lover of JRPGs will love this game. It didn't get it's fair chance because SquEnix botched their chance with the ill-adviced 360 version. Rest assured that this game is 100% playable and will be well worth the cost.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												tl;dr: This game is mostly RNG based despite what it tells you, so if you're fine with relying on luck, then you might enjoy it.If you like to win through clever tactical decisions or being overleveled and steamrolling enemies; this game has nothing to offer you.I got this game wanting a chill tactical JRPG where I could grind, explore and craft. After about 50 hours in I feel it delivered on the side quest, exploration and crafting side---HOWEVER:The combat is insanely RNG heavy. You don't have control over possitioning of your party and the game punishes you for bad positioning, you also don't have direct control over what attacks/moves your characters perform. Different moves have different modifiers that are strong against different types of monsters but you don't actually get to choose to use these moves, you just have to hope you get them.  There is also a chance you get a roll in combat where your mages only get to choose between Physical attacks and fighters only get to use Magic attacks. The combat can also otherwise completely screw you over when you get a bad roll out eg: you can end up in situations where you need to/want to heal but the game just doesn't let you because you get bad RNG (this has cost my alot of fights). Even if you get the heal option you only really get one of two options: "heal yourself" or "heal someone else" you don't get to choose who that someone else is so you'll just have to cross your fingers and hope.There is a moral system that supposedly rewards you for making good tactical decisions, increasing your damage and defense when you keep moral high. However most of these "decisions" are actually based on RNG and completely outside your control, and several mobs are immune to it anyway making the combat in general favoured towards enemies, especially vs bosses and Rare Enemies.There are no random encounters, so that's good, but there's a system where if an enemy sneaks up on you they get a combat advantage, however there is no way for you to get an early combat advantage over you enemy via something like a pre-emtive strike.If you're the kind of person who likes to spend a lot of time getting good gear for your entire team, this game doesn't allow you to do that either as you only have control of the gear on the main character, while everyone else has their own gear that can only be improved with (say it with me) RNG, as they may ask to have some of the gear you're not using if it's better than what they have. The other way to improve you're allies gear is to gather monster loot where your crew MAY ask to have some of it to improve their gear.Lastly all the enemies in the game scale with your "levels" so grinding isn't all that useful, pretty much taking all the point out of leveling. Further more you can't watch how much XP you gain to see how much more you need to get new moves or what you need for your stats to increase, which is just another annoyance in my already page long complaint.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
												TLR is a JRPG from Square-Enix with a few flaws and a predictable storyline but is beautifully done.From the get go, you might have control issues, I did and I had to google how to fix it, but after that it should be a breeze. There isn't a very steep learning curve, but you will most certainly miss things on your first play through than you would if you had known a few things. For example, there's some side missions that unlock certain playable characters that are amazing but they're only open for a limited time, and if you progress in your story you will miss the opportunity to recruit them.As far as battles go, the fighting is pretty simple, you can set up your characters to form unions (or squads) which pool stats, which I thought was a little disappointing because I really wanted to be able to attack certain characters differently and position mine differently. Not a bad point, just different from what I'm used to. They have a sort of Limit Break attack move for certain characters like most Square games.If you do get to check this game out, be sure to play through without a guide first, then check out what you missed, I had a load of fun this way. Incase you decide to check the guide out first or run through with a guide:


Things I Wish I Had Known.... 
A Guide for The Last Remnant
By: Zloth

			There are a lot of things in Last Remnant that I really think should have been explained to the player. In this guide, I try to cover those things without spoiling the story.		


In short, I would recommend TLR because it's different but still has a Square uniqueness of fun to it. It has some flaws but the flaws are overlooked by the game's overwhelmingly positive pro's to it's con's.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												After 190 hours of game time, I just finished my first playthrough of this game.To be fair I nearly did 100% of its content. But yeah, it has a LOT of content, if you do everything.So what is this game about? You assemble a team of people, put them together into units (called unions) and do battle in turns. Depending on who you put together into a union the actual commands they get in battle change and depending on which skills your guys/gals use they level different abilities and stats, which in turn affects which classes they will get into. There are also different formations for your unions to use, which affects the stats of the union.Well, that sure sounds complicated, but rejoice most of this game is easily beatable by just doing whatever sounds good to you.  So you don't have to get into the depth of it if you don't want to, though for me that was part of the fun. It is a really good easy to use but hard to master/really understand type of system. There are a few optional bosses that are very very hard and beating them may require some kind of special tactics. It feels incredible rewarding when you are finally able to beat them, though.Does the game have any drawbacks? To be honest the story is kinda "eh whatever", but there are tons of optional stuff to distract you from it. The story battles however are pretty awesome. Another negative point is that a few enemies have really really cheap skills, which can be quite frustrating.Overall I really liked this game a lot and might even start up a ng+ run of it. Yes, that is a recommendation.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												     TLR is a fantastic game. Sadly the game has an extremely poor reputation from the xbox world where I understand that it is sub par. On the PC however, the game is absolutely beautiful and suprisingly deep. The story won't win any awards for originality I suppose, but personally I really enjoyed it.      The main draw of the game however is the turn based combat with a twist. Instead of giving individual party members a command, you assemble small armies and assign them a general strategy to execute over the course of a turn. While this system can seem shallow and perhaps frustrating to those without the patience to learn its intricacies, it is one of the most enjoyable battle sysyems I have ever used in an RPG. Building and customizing each union and your overall team is a lot of fun. If you seek out the sidequests in the game (which easily adds more than 50% more content) you will often find yourself with access to many more allies with which to customize your team.    In all honestly if you have no interest in making a decent investment into learning the sysyem then this may not be the game for you. If, on the other hand, you enjoy learning and mastering an intricate combat system, turn based combat, hours and hours of sidequests and a beautiful world to explore, extremely challenging optional bosses, and beautiful looking combat, you will probably love TLR as much as I do.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												The Last Remnant is... interesting. I like it. Let's start with the components: Audio is good. the music is good. What you'd expect out of a JRPG without being... memorable, though. Certainly not like FF's "Zanarkand" theme, or Wild Arms' opening number. Still, it adds to the game. It gives it a bit of atmosphere and adds to the experience, without being intrusive. The voice acting is... decent. passable, though turnbased as if drawing samples from different characters' audio files and splicing them together noticably with a slight delay. There are a few quirks, and sometimes I feel some characters' inflections or timings are off, and wish Pagus would get on with it at some points, but he's old. Rush's line "Let's Kick Some A", for some reason, bothers me for a game with blood visuals and literally had an NPC use the word "B**chfit".Visuals are nice. They made a world with depth, and beauty, and very nice aesthetic appeal, as you'd expect from a relatively modern JRPG, without migrating into "OVERUSE BLOOM AND LENS FLARE" territory. Automatic camera movements in combat can take a little getting used to, and voiced cutscenes that weren't pre-rendered but are voiced, are a tad jerky in terms of character movement. Obviously cued and timed 'gestures' and 'animations', rather than flowing, fullly-choreographed stuff.  That said, they seem to have partly forsaken "Belts-and-zippers" design for actual symmetry in outfits, save for when it looks... Reasonable. Elements still exist, but they are less common, and favor symmetry more often.  Exceptions don't often become unreasonable. I still think Rush's "@$$-flag" is a bit silly though. It's the red-and-white hanging emblem off his beltline in the pictures the store page shows, but it offers a glimpse of an interesting move by the designers in giving most characters a mark. A symbol of some sort, that identifies their assumed class and role, if you look hard enough. From what I can tell, they actually appear to change as the story progresses. That being said, classes are... transmutable and flow together. It's not as strictly defined as the "Mage, beatface, healer" setup as it sounds.  You could turn Torgal for example, into a hexblade, or a combat medic, or just a DPS nuke, though keep in mind those are my own terms. Story: IT'S A JRPG. Yes, there's a story with depth in a world with depth, and relatively well-developed characters, each with their own amusing quirks. I've found it enjoyable so far, and can easily follow the plot. The game, while allowing you exploration, doesn't leave you going "uh... what was I doing again?" Because it's always followed by something like "Oh, right.  Saving 'my' sister from the [redacted] and [redacted], working together with the [redacted lots] to [redacted all over the place]"Mechanics:Out of combat: decent. Though you want to get a USB controller. Something with shoulder-buttons and sticks that can be pressed down. Like something that emulates a PS3 controller.  Also, while an interesting experiment, the system of engaging an enemy before they get to you is a littlte... well, it works, but might not be for everyone. It does however, offer chances for greater risk and reward, or to take multiple squads at once to save time and effort. The item customization and creation system, I think I like, as do I the system of helping your followers find components for their own upgrades. I just wish I could HAND THEM the mats and go "Here, now stop bothering me in each town! I've got like 50 of the things!" Though it does offer better incentive to train, as the difficulty class of some bosses starts to get away from you after a bit, further encouraging training, and perhaps even a touch of grinding. IN combat: While micro-managing to get the best out of a party's actions would be interesting, do you really want to give 15 separate orders before a combat starts? I think the system works well for squads, and is believable. You issue a general order. A "Smoke if you got 'em" call for mystic nuking, or a "Beat some face if you got the skills" call for combat arts, and other specialized orders based on situation, available party members in a squad, and their own talents. The remainder gets filled with standard melee strikes. You should go into combat with several squads, not necessarily light on party members, and here's why: They have a communal HP pool, as do their enemies. A large squad can be tanky, but slow. A small squad is squishy, but easier to do tactical b***hsmacks with. Couple that with the fact that you set troop formations and that they actually modify the troop's combat statistics, and you have an interesting, thought-invoking mechanic that lets you squeeze a bit more out of your characters, if you're not an idiot. However, even with all this, and added features like flanking, deadlock engagements, interceptions, and a nifty morale meter, it's still a turnbased JRPG at heart. I'm thoroughly surprised that they got it all to work so well together.In summary and serving as a TL;DR, Good story, decent graphics, very in-depth but enjoyable and well-orchestrated mechanics. You should buy this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												The Last Remnant is a really good attempt for Square Enix to establish itself on PC gaming ( though I still play it with PS3 controller since it's easier to control, I used a 3rd party controller program to disguise it as 360 controller ).   Graphics : The game's graphic is a little bit on the middle ground for PC ( and especially for SquareEnix ) though the game show much of its details and the true power of SE-animated on the battleground rather than the cutscene ( Maybe my PC sucks but the grame drop during some of the gigantic animation are quite bad ).  Control : The game is console controller friendly and I would suggest you to use one since It's much nicer to get around using controller.   Game's Mechanics : The game use its old and all popular turn base mechanics from the final fantasy series, with a really nice touch here and there. A big improvement though is apart from the main character, anybody else will be treated equally on the battlefield which make the game extremely interesting and fun to play.  Speaking of the amount of characters, the game offer you up to 25 chatacters to be on the battlefield at one time ( 5 team of 5 ), you will be controlling a team called "union", to give order to your troops, the action each troops can take are very situational base, since you are controlling up to 5 characters at one time, the game use a function to give each troops their own chance to use their skills. This might cone at a negative to some person since you can't directly control one particular character and command him to use certain skill at that specific time, but he/she will be using it automatically if the situation is met. The tutorial is there, though it doesn't go in depth of how and when is the appropriate time to use some of the function. The QTE they include in the fight are extremely nice, it make the game goes from spam Attack to win to you have to pay attention on the game in case some of those QTE come in so you can power up your attack or counter the enemy attack with your own for HUGE damage. Which of course have its down side on that it's more centered toward luck-base than strategy for the QTE. Speaking of QTE, another HUGE downside of the game came from the fact that it have the "turbo mode" option available for you to speed up the fighting progress of the game, it speed up the animation of the fighting scene and here is a problem that they might not noticed before, the QTE's speed in turbo mode is also much, MUCH quicker, so quick that it's impossible for any human to react to the right QTE sequence on time which in turns, making the QTE in turbo mode, impossible and thus, might lose you in the match that require some QTE action.   Sound : Oh my god, SE did it again with its awesome soundtrack that will capture anyone's heart.  In total, for the price tag of 10$, I would recommend this game to anyone that is a fan of RPG ( first timer are not the target audience of this game ). If you're a fan of ANY of the FF series, Dragon Quest series or  just any game from SE in general, you will probably love this game. I have no idea why metacritics critics have been giving this game a low score of 66 ( users at 82 ), I think it deserve better though the story line is, as you guess it, very final fantasy-like.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Very Final Fantasy-esque, but this fantasy setting does tend to get tiring after all these years. The main character is likable enough, but the supporting characters are the ones holding the somewhat flimsy story together.The controls are definitely made for consoles (I suspect the entire thing is just a weak port, though), so it does take some time getting used to them. Speaking of which, combat is fresh and it gets a bit tactical, but that's only if you can wrap your head around it. It does tend to get very confusing, but once you've gotten the hang of it, it's very rewarding.All in all, it's a pretty good game, neither groundbreaking nor complete crap. Could it have been better, though? Yes, definitely.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												This is a decent JRPG with plenty of playtime and sidequests to do, as well as a rather in-depth and interesting battle system. Unfortunately, much of the game is very poorly explained if explained at all, forcing the player to look up all of the game's numerous mechanics. So much of the game design is unintuitive and very strange, such as the idea that it's actually preferrable to avoid random fights to keep your battle rank lower and make important fights easier and the inability to easily directly choose which spells or skills to use in battle, that trying to play through the game without the use of any outside resources will probably be a very confusing experience. Nevertheless, if you're willing to invest time into learning how to play, this game can be rather enjoyable. 7/10

												God, this game is hard to describe. It's leveling system is extremely confusing. Basically you have to avoid getting your Battle Rank too high or else the game becomes impossible to beat. Aside from that issue, the game itself is gorgeous, unique and different. If you enjoy immersing yourself in a new world this would be the game for you. Not exactly GOTY material but it's definitely worth your money. If it's on sale consider getting it.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												Don't let the reviews crying "no grinding" and "impossibly hard" dissuade you. The Last Remnant is an excellent, turn-based RPG with a very unique battle system (that can even be sped up significantly). I found quite a few bosses that were frustrating beyond belief, but after taking the time to adjust formations, try different squad combinations, and yes, level up a bit, I'd get through them.The key to "grinding" is to pull multiple groups of enemies at once. This is clearly stated in the very beginning of the game and helps all of your NPCs level up with you.Very satisfying experience. Finished the game in less than 70 hours and that was with a lot of exploring and side quests (though I probably skipped/missed a whole lot more).

Posted: October 17, 2015
												Square Enix qualtity graphics, unfortunatelly there is where pros ends.Gameplay depends too much on luck and is FULL of bad implemented mechanics that RUINS your experience.I dont bother any longer with this game cause my time is just more precious and it is typical to find a battle way too difficult for the moment you decide to fight ( veteran player here, not kidding ). No much sense on coming back later, or grinding your level cause mobs escale with you and trying a typical sidequest to improve gear can get you to 30 min battle for reach a boss, just to have your whole party one-hit killed... no way to know the difficult an encounter can be until your teams are wiped on the 27 turn by one attack... you can get random monsters, random spawns, enemy reinforcements that appears and lay waste to your troops without you even having the chance to choice your next turn random comands... yup, there are long ( long ) battles , and for a development reason i cant fathom to understand, the choice of orders is random... so you can find yourself with no heal orders at all... and your party will be wiped on any turn.I dont use to give up with games but this one just dont deserve my time.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												10 hours into the game I can tell that this is an extremely interesting game. Aside from the lore which I barely understand in a game that I'm told runs for at least 70 hours more, I know that I'm plunged into a world that is about to hit the fan and feces will start flying all around.Gameplay wise it resembles FFXIII (rather, FFXIII resembles this game) on the world map and in "dungeons" but that is not always bad. The real difference comes in the combat scenarios which are extremely more complicated and tactical than FFXIII ever was. You have several units (made from 1-5 soldiers) fighting various assortments of units at the same time, and you have to coordinate who attacks what and if you make up the wrong choice, you'll have another unit intercept yours for a negative morale hit (morale is basically how well your forces think the battle is going. if it's going good, they'll do more damage, and vice versa)Storywise, it's what you expect from a Square(Enix, yuck) game. Extremely complex, lots of names to memorize at once, interesting cartography, etc.TL;DR: Got this game on a sale. I'm at 10 hours and I bought it for like 5$. That's a 2:1 ratio and I'm expecting 70 hours more of enjoyment. Good enjoyment at that. Do keep in mind that JRPGs are not things like Dragon Age, although you can keep a resemblance, you have to expect other things here.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												Well, this is a Square Enix game, turn based basic combat.I thought that the squad-based thing might remove some of the parts I find boring in the normal turn based systems, but overall, it makes for a fairly dull system.I only had the patience to go through the first two areas, so it might get a bit better later on, but so far, here is what I found wrong with it:- The movements on the map scenes are slow.- The environments are empty, adding to the slow movements.- Everything dies in a few hits, both you and the enemies (even in the first area), but the HP is restored to full after each fight.- Random chances to get critical hits in or to get hit by one.- No real control over the fights, making it seem like a merry mess of randomness.- Gain of "stats" after a few fights, seemingly unrelated to what action you chose (levelling up?).- No way to skip animations, and somewhat poor quality animations anyway, making the "watch what happens" phase boring to watch. Added to the fact that the camera switches all over the place instantly, and you get a messy presentation instead of a cinematic one that seems to be intended.All in all, I don't know what I was expecting, it's a Square Enix game, and I really am bored of those menu based combats with occasional QTE.I can get over it whan the games try to do things I find interesting, like the moe system in Mugen souls, or when your choices are a bit more varied, with actually reasons to defend and other similar actions.I guess this game can please some people, because it doesn't seem broken or bad per say, but it definitely is not my thing at all.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												Worst JRPG I've ever played. I really wanted to give this game a chance. 16+Hrs of playtime speak for themselves.The graphics are good, can't say anything against that. But the rest of this game makes me run away as soon as I try to play it. Didn't see that much of the story, or at least i hope so. So maybe the story is decent but the gameplay kept me from it.Now i start with what really makes this game the worst JRPG i've ever seen.1. The characters : The main Character Rush is a dumb, hotheaded but far to talented kid who just doesn't think about any consequence his actions could have. Too often I was sitting there watching him rush(no pun intended) into dangerous situation and i was left with one big question : WHY?!The cast of other characters makes even less sense. Rush meets them and after less than two lines of dialog : "I'm gonna help you." Again same question... WHY?! These characters never met before and just exchanged less words, than Hodor from Game of Thrones has in his entire repertoire, and they are acting like BFFs?!2.The character growth system: The game punishes you for ending your fights as fast and efficient as possible. As your character's hp don't grow if the they don't get damaged. This learning by doing stuff was allready bad in one of the older Final Fantasys back on the SNES. And that's not wine, it doesn't get better with age.3.The battle system/battle rank system/enemy scaling : The Battle system itself seems interesting at first glance.Especially the Unit-Formation-Leader stuff really has a lot of interesting and strong points. But then the atrocities begin. The Battle system itself is a lot of random, luck reliant stuff. Which is never good in a turnbased game.You get no indication which Unit moves when, you have no Idea of the enemy's speed. And you get no information on the enemy's movents at all. How is any human beeing supposed to formulate a strategy without even the most basic of information provided? How am I supposed to keep my morale up if the enemy Interferes with any of my moves?Your party strength plays no part in the enemy scaling to your party at all. As you fight more enemys, what you sometimes have to do, your battle rank rises. The higher your battle rank, the stronger the monsters. That system is supposed to balance itself out. But I tell you one thing: It doesn't because at some point enemys will start using Area of Effect Attacks which damage your Unitmembers Individually this is going to oneshot whole Units, at some occasions even the whole Army, as happened to me several times. making fighting impossible because there is no flee option. Then there are these Special Arts that some characters have. They can use them if a gauge on the Status screen of the Unit is filled. These gauges fill as you attack, and drop as you take damage. So these Special Arts are supposed to give you an even greater edge when you are allready dominating the fight. But anything like a strong "last resort" type of attack would maybe make many fights less frustrating.So I would not recommend this game, even if I would get paid for that.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												The game has an interesting take on turn-based combat (directing multiple parties of characters that share stats  and move as one unit rather than as individuals); however a lot of the nuances of the mechanics are not well-explained within the game itself. I'd recommend browsing a wiki on basic gameplay to get a better handle on the mechanics the game has. If you like JRPGs and turn-based games it's worth checking out, imo, though for people who prefer 100% control over every combat decision the variable nature (based on party makeup, party leader, and positioning) of combat commands in battle might be annoying. Basically, most of the strategic thought goes into setting up your parties' characters and their skills beforehand, and then adapting to whatever options you get during the actual combat turns. It may feel a little too random for some people, though you can stack the deck in your favor if you know what you're going for with your group/skill makeup. There are around fifty unique characters that you can choose to recruit into your parties -- some are linked to the main story while others are hidden and can only be obtained after doing certain side quests, as well as 'generic' soldiers that you can hire to pad your army.The art direction and music are top-notch -- the game looks beautiful on the PC. Areas themselves are linear, though there are many side quests and hidden regions available if you want a break from the main storyline. A lot of the side content can become unavailable permanently if you progress too far in the main story without exploring every area (though there is the benefit of being able to start a New Game + after your first playthrough). Despite the game's setting being original and interesting, the lead character is a bit of a dope and the main story is not that great, unfortunately (the writing is pretty weak). I honestly enjoyed doing the side content (which includes defeating rare miniboss monsters) more than following the main scenario.The Last Remnant is unique compared to any other turn-basd RPG I've played, so it's hard to make a blanket statement of recommendation; it really depends on your personal tastes. Basically, your mileage may vary; if you play JRPGs primarily as visual novels and prefer an epic cinematic storyline  with typical gameplay, then this may not be a game for you. But if you are a fan of turn-based combat and are open to investing the time to learn the nuances of this game's unique mechanics (and are a collector and completionist-type), then you might enjoy it.

												The Last Remnant is a great JRPG by Square. A unqiue battle system where you take control of a group of soldiers rather than individual units. Hours of quests and exploring. 												I think this is greatly under-appreciated game. It is unconventional in battles, having squads to control rather than classical 1-4 single characters. The squads give whole another level to tactics and strategies and a bit of a random element at times too. I loved the game, it has lots of grinding to do and challenging ultimate bosses. The story itself is fairly easy to complete and doesn't require grinding so it's a good for those who're in just for the story. The game has beautiful cinematics and the overall story is good. Also I consider grinding more fun in this game as the enemies get stronger(with battle ranks) so even as time goes by they won't just become target-dummies. Also for those who consider them getting too stong; there is new game+ which allows you to keep some stuff for new start.

This game will punish those who think you can just grind your levels to make up for a lack of skill, will limit your access towards many a thing if you aren't always activly exploring after every story event, and in general be hard as nails till you learn the full in's and out of it's battle system and dynamic nature quarks. For all of it's headbanging thought, this game offers quite a bit that nothing else really comes close towards. A battle system that simulates a 'war' like fighting style, the massive trainable roster to collect and gear up, and bosses that really do not hold back one bit. The storyline...is at least passible, yet was done around the same time FFXII or so, with Mr Skys feeling a BIT too much ( and forced ) like Vaan in turn because of such. Once you get good at everything thought, this is going to start to feel like FFT all over again.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2014
												Pros+Unique battle system+Challenging boss fights+Nice aesthetics as well as graphics+A lot of side quests which are generally interesting story-wise+A lot of secrets and extra stuffCons-A few mechanics are not well explained-Limited autonamy in customizing your party's equipment-Some grinding required for the best gearThe Last Remnanat is a turn-based strategy RPG with a diferent kind of combat mechanincs. Each character will be placed in a squad of 5 (max) and will act on a general command, such as attack with magical arts, etc. Usually, the available commands are influenced by the abilities of the squad leader and the condition of the battle (if they're dying or if another squad needs help etc.). However, you will not be able to directly control what type of action each individual will perform. For example, the command is to inflict ailments, but you cannot specify whether to silence them, poison them, etc.However, sometimes characters may change their actions depending on the situation. This is usually due to a successful quick time event (QTE), high morale, etc. Sometimes characters will perform healing abilities because they just need healing, or the command was to offer support to others (not a direct command to heal) or the character's class is just inclined to healing. This makes battles much more dynamic and unpredictable. This all leads up to one thing.Satisfying boss fights. I can say without a doubt, the best thing about this game is how challenging and enjoyable the fights that matter can be. It's the strong point of the game. Paired with secret and extra bosses that are even more challenging, this is what truly makes the game shine.Unfortunately, to get there may take some patience as there are mechanics or stats that are not detailed enough, there is no  way to directly give items to your party members, and getting said items may lead into a dull grind. It should also be noted that to be a perfectionist in this game, it will require you to consult the wiki frequently. But then, every good game deserves a wiki, and the Last Remnant is definitely a good game.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												The game has an interesting take on turn-based combat (directing multiple parties of characters that share stats  and move as one unit rather than as individuals); however a lot of the nuances of the mechanics are not well-explained within the game itself. I'd recommend browsing a wiki on basic gameplay to get a better handle on the mechanics the game has. If you like JRPGs and turn-based games it's worth checking out, imo, though for people who prefer 100% control over every combat decision the variable nature (based on party makeup, party leader, and positioning) of combat commands in battle might be annoying. Basically, most of the strategic thought goes into setting up your parties' characters and their skills beforehand, and then adapting to whatever options you get during the actual combat turns. It may feel a little too random for some people, though you can stack the deck in your favor if you know what you're going for with your group/skill makeup. There are around fifty unique characters that you can choose to recruit into your parties -- some are linked to the main story while others are hidden and can only be obtained after doing certain side quests, as well as 'generic' soldiers that you can hire to pad your army.The art direction and music are top-notch -- the game looks beautiful on the PC. Areas themselves are linear, though there are many side quests and hidden regions available if you want a break from the main storyline. A lot of the side content can become unavailable permanently if you progress too far in the main story without exploring every area (though there is the benefit of being able to start a New Game + after your first playthrough). Despite the game's setting being original and interesting, the lead character is a bit of a dope and the main story is not that great, unfortunately (the writing is pretty weak). I honestly enjoyed doing the side content (which includes defeating rare miniboss monsters) more than following the main scenario.The Last Remnant is unique compared to any other turn-basd RPG I've played, so it's hard to make a blanket statement of recommendation; it really depends on your personal tastes. Basically, your mileage may vary; if you play JRPGs primarily as visual novels and prefer an epic cinematic storyline  with typical gameplay, then this may not be a game for you. But if you are a fan of turn-based combat and are open to investing the time to learn the nuances of this game's unique mechanics (and are a collector and completionist-type), then you might enjoy it.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												The story is alright but it is kind of hard to be immersed into the game's world. The gamplay feels limiting as you do not really have much control in what goes on as you fight. For example, if you want to heal but the AI does feel like you have to, it will not give you the option even though it is imperative to heal that turn otherwise you die. And you will die, you will die ALOT. Due to the limiting controls, the boss battles get much harder to the point where it is a random chance if you will beat the boss. The enemies/bosses also scale with level, so leveling up does not make the game much easier and sometimes actually makes it harder to go through due to the increased toughness of the enemies.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												Lured into buying it by a decent MetaCritics score, I could not actually play this for very long.  I simply found no entry into this game. The decent in-game video sequences were providing a very japanese RPG feel, and I guess one could view this as mix between RPG and tactical/skirmish combat. However, from the graphics to the controls everything cried out "console port", and IMHO not at very good one at that. This may have been a decent console game some years ago, but trying to play this on a PC keyboard was pretty frustrating, the visuals were sometimes a mix between decent and annoying (e.g. not showing your party when moving around, very basic tactical environments), and the "unique" turn-based tactical combat system was pretty lame, IMHO. E.g. no tactical movement of your party members, but just a selection of attack options from a list, "combined" Hit Points for entire groups, etc. Still, there are the typical RPG elements such as character building, item drops, etc., but nothing like crafting, enchanting, etc. known from more complex RPGs (at least not as far as I went into it). There is a strong feeling that this game almost plays itself, and while some may consider it to have a deep or compelling storyline (though not compared to e.g. BG2:SoA I'd say), I just couldn't stand the gameply between the video sequences which seemed mainly about depicting some asian kids saving the world...This type of Japanese RPG game with simplified turn-based tactical battles may have it's fans, but I am not among them. If you like JRPGs you may love this one. If, like me, you prefer Divinity 2 or old-school BG2:SoA type RPGs with tons of "fetch this, kill that" type side quests, then this is most probably not for you.Depth: Immersive (?)Setting: Fantasy Type: RPG/TacticalMy Rating: 4 out of 10 (you may rate this 8 of 10 if you are into JRPGs)...

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												Being a fan of a lot of square enix games i REALLY REALLY wanted to like this game... But it suffers from one major flaw, you don't really play the game. I understand a difficult game I do enjoy a challenge but lets be fair here, challengeing because you had to plan ahead, and challengeing because your luck was bad are two completely different things. One example is an easy first boss fight, that i had to do twelve different times and still could not beat. First of all you may die before you EVEN ENGAGE in the battle because of dumb luck. Second you engage in the battle and whatever order you give may just not play out right for some reason, and you never really know the reason why its just ends up feeling like somebody flipped a coin somewhere and said ♥♥♥♥ it. Then you get lucky and can issue an actual battle order but only for yourself hoping that whatever ally you don't control does what you want it to... Did I mention the fact that you can't really control all your party members, you just issue orders and hope they do what you want. I know this is the way the gameplay was designed but it was a poor design choice because I don't really feel like I am controlling anything. Also I might add that as you level up the enemies get harder, while this seems like a good thing at first, its not... You have a difficult boss fight and want to do some griding to come back later to try to beat him... too bad he is just as hard because he leveled up. Want to do some side quests  just to get away from the main story? well damnit now all the bosses and enemies are harder. This game literally punishes you for doing side quests, yea its that annoying. If you enjoy this game thats fine, more power to you and I am glad you did, but for any newcomers please be wary that this game is extremely convoluted and frustrating.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												This game is far too difficult to be any fun.  The story and characters are all annoying cliches, but I would have been able to get over it because of the fantastic battle system.  Unfortunatley, that too was ruined for me by the unjustifiable difficulty of the battles.  I'm barely four hours in (I left the game running while paused, which is why my time reads more) and I've already faced two bosses--one side quest, one main--that I could not defeat even after over a dozen attempts.  With each all it took was a single critical hit to knock out my entire union, so each battle ends up just devolving into grinding away at them just praying on their turns that they don't crit.  There's no way around it.  The game is actually set up to punish you if you grind, so there is absolutely nothing you can do if you find yourself in this situation.  My only option at this point is to simply quit, which is infuriating given this game's potential.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												I literally started this game this month in hope of it being a very good J-RPG; o boy was I disappointed. To begin with, there are way too many characters within this game. The story itself is bland and forgetable, as it kind of reminds me of FF 13 in which the story actually started becoming good after playing 30 hours of it, I can easily say the same about The Last Remnant. In terms of there being way too many characters, I mean the issue with this is the fact the game only allows a total of 5 parties with a total of 5 members in each of those parties limiting you far too much.The battle system itself is very convoluted and never really explained. The player really has no access to what each party members do in each party. For example, the battle system tells the player that all of the party member will attack this specific enemy, either by physical damage, magical damage. Other times it lets you heal if necessary but those options are unpredicatable as when one of my party was very much injured, it would not give me the option to heal at all.What's kind of worse about the battles in The Last Remnant is the way that they are placed. Most of the battles are ridiculous. Sometimes you go into a new area, the enemies are sometimes very easy, and then suddenly you meet this gigantic bird/ dragon and they tear you a new one because for some odd reason the developers decided to put a rare monster into the game at that specific moment. Of course even though I only died once and the auto saves in this game is very well timed, the fact is that those rare monsters are really not rewarding at all.To keep this short, if you're thinking about buying this game, it's worth no more than 4 dollars. The problem isn't the graphics, because those are superb for a J-RPG on the PC, however the problem really has to do with the lack of story, terrible and convoluted battle system, lack of character development and in general, it really does not feel like a true J-RPG. I came into this game expecting more so something along the lines of FF 12 as my lowest expectation and my highest expectation as FF 6, but really it was nowhere near as good as even FF 12. I can truly just recommend this to players who really just want to understand the combat system by trying different things and such. However, for players who want a deep character developement, good easy to understand combat system and even easy loot system, then this is not a game for you.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												I've heard good and bad things about this game, and it was on sale for cheap so I decided to give it a whirl. It's a game that lives and dies by its battle system, which is what one does the most by far. The story is cliche and the CG segments are short and few in between. The graphics are aged by today's standards, which is fine, but the locations and dungeons are generic and uninspired.The choices in battle you can make are random, depending on your available skills, HP, and positioning. If you have a healer unit and the game doesn't allow you to heal, too bad. If you have a full AP bar waiting to unleash hell but the game doesn't allow you to, too bad. You cannot directly control unit positioning. If a boss is dropping AOEs all around himself, you cannot order units to hang back. Extremely unpredictable and frustrating. You can't even see the HP of a boss or miniboss. The game allows you to set formations to trade off advantages and disadvantages and these are essential for boss fights, but these take very long to set up and there is no way to save different formations.Game statistics are opaque and not explained properly. Every character has a 'unique' statistic like 'ego' but after so many years the game is out, AFAIK nobody knows what they do. You can only equip the main character directly. For the other 20 to 50 characters depending on how far you are into the game, you have to actually wait for them to ask to "borrow" a piece of equipment you already have. If they don't ask for it, you have to go out and beat up some monsters and see if they ask you again. Talk about being obtuse and beating around the bush.You cannot see a character's skill tree so you don't know what skills he/she is going to get, and you can only level up skills by using them, making the normal attack option mostly moot. Every now and then a character asks whether to learn a new skill or not, or to focus on physical or magical skills. You cannot postpone the decision. The game doesn't explain what the skill does or who the charcter is or what kind of stats he or she has, so it might as well ask the player to pick randomly. There is no quest board, so after every story event, you find yourself wandering all the towns, pubs, and guild areas just to pick up new quests. At least quests don't get offered in dungeons so you don't actually have to check those.Money is extremely difficult to come by, and I finished disc 1, I was wondering why the shops even bother to stock the stuff they have. You could grind money but that raises your battle rank which is essentially your level, and enemies scale up with your battle rank. Hence you find the characters who join you later on to be underpowered and generally useless. Since enemies level with you and you cannot gain gear advantage, progression feels very slow and stifled. Despite the game being entirely its battle system, its systems actually discourage you from fighting, until you hit a difficulty spike, look up a guide, and see that the recommended level is way above yours, so now it's time to actually level so you can get on with it.If you are looking for similar previous-gen RPGs, try Star Ocean III or Final Fantasy X instead. I'm an old-school RPG gamer, but the flaws above are designed on purpose and those are unforgivable for a game released in 2008. Not recommended.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												Not my cup of tea this one.Like most of Square Enix's games, The Last Remnant features a standard spiky hair teenager you'd see in a subpar anime or JRPG. STORY- Something about demons and his sister? These stories are all the same.GRAPHICS- Simulating big battles in the background is one thing The Last Remnant does very well.SOUNDTRACK- mehGAMEPLAY- I'm not even sure you can call it gameplay.   Pros-    The battles look huge and awesome later on   Multiple ways to set up squad composition   JRPG that discourages level grinding?   Complex combat system    Cons-   Complex combat system (Like myself, most players who start the game will have no idea how everything comes together in combat and leveling. I didn't realize grinding early was bad, considering all the people I tried to recruit afterwards sucked. High BR = Bad)   Yet you still need to do all the side quests just to prevent a wipe from a boss?   Whether you grind or not, it's still difficult   Takes a little bit to get multiple squads (So you can enjoy those big battles)   Individual actions for squad members cannot be selected. (Game revolves around tactical choices for each squad that determine what actions they will likely take. But, it's better than selecting 18 individual unit actions separately)CONCLUSION-This game is not for those looking for a traditional JRPG. Similar to the SaGa series, The Last Remnant has no character development or decent plot, and has a different combat and leveling system compared to oldies like Final Fantasy or Breath of Fire. If you've been fishing out SaGa games out of the trash like I have, you may enjoy this game. I however, enjoyed Unlimited SaGa more than this weird game.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												With unique features like the control of 'units' (small groups of individuals) during battles, instead of a couple of separate individuals as in most RPGs, this game should be a lot better. It really has potential, and I want to like it, but certain elements make it more annoying than enjoyable.The first problem is the characters. Both in personality and speech, these characters are the exact opposite of the Final Fantasy games. Whereas recent FF games have gotten a bit unnecessarily overcomplicated, this game is dumbed down to the enth degree. The verbage and mentalities within the game are so simple that it's a bit painful to witness at times.To further compound this issue, the protagonist of the game, Rush Sykes, is very "simple", but it's a bit much. I tried to give him the benefit of the doubt because he is from a remote town away from the main cities (even though his parents are famous so he should've been home-schooled and therefore not an ignorant fool--but I digress). Rush is the normal, cliche, naive & independent character we've seen many times before. He thinks he can handle the world on his own. But to an excessive extent, worse than we've seen in any prior RPG... furthermore, his personality, which seems to be an attempt at humor, is much more often very obnoxious rather than funny. The game in general seems to be marketed more towards beginner players. Instead of walking around a city or in the field of the outside world, everything is controlled by a dot, as it is in Final Fantasy Tactics. I'm a bit mixed on this. On one hand, it's nice to cut past running through a huge city--which can sometimes take an hour on its own, (i.e. FF9)--to get to the meat of the game, but it also feels like it takes away from it a bit. More of a subjective feature. In the vein of simplicity, it's also easier because you can save at any time from the menu.The biggest issue might be the battle control, or lack thereof. As much as I enjoy it's uniqueness, the difficulty of this game is bi-polar. If you don't have a high enough level, going into a battle with the choices: a) Attack b) Stand-by is impossible because there's no way to manage the individual attacks of each character. Either choice you pick you will often wind up dead. If you have a high enough level, you just pick 'attack' each time and you win easily. The one positive of the battle system is the 'criticals' feature where you have to press a certain button fast enough to get a critical hit, which keeps you interested during the fighting.Finally, the voice-overs. Basically all the voice-overs in this game--at least so far as I've seen--are just terrible. They seem as if they had a tight budget for the game and couldn't get professionals for the English version. I'd be interested in seeing a totally reworked sequel, but as-is, it's just not my cup o' tea.5.8/10

One for JRPG fanatics only, I think. I do love certain genre titles, but The Last Remnant suffers from all of the aspects that make many Japanese console RPGs frustrating and difficult to enjoy. 												Experimental battle system you don't have a lot of control over : as in FFXIII, you give general commands only (at least, FFXIII gave you the opportunity to select the skills you want to use, even if it's useless). This game was an obvious design blueprint for the awful FFXIII battle system. You are supposed to leads groups of warrior, positionning is sometimes key to victory or defeat and, guess what ? You have absolutely no control over it. NONE. So much for strategy. Battle QTEs are anecdotic (for crits), chara design is... meh, and the characters themselves BEG FOR YOU TO B****SLAP THEIR STUPID FACES. This game signs the demise of Square as a JRPG monument on the third generation of consoles. The story is... well, the standard jrpg story : symbolic princess is kidnapped, go for her, make friends, be betrayed from time to time, the ennemies are controled by something bigger than you are supposed to expect, then save the world from apocalypse. Yaaaaay.... Don't buy this game. Don't enable SE for more mediocrity.

Posted: December 9, 2010
												One of the most underrated JRPGs ever. The battle system has a bit of a learning curve, but is actually pretty great once you get the hang of it. You actually have to think in every battle, since no matter how much you grind (or avoid leveling up), to the very end, you can lose your entire group in one turn in a battle against the weakest enemies in the game.For those who like to grind and search for hidden stuff, there are plenty of rare monsters to hunt, which can be extremely difficult to find and beat. There are sidequests, some of which are even missable. Some are decent, some are dull fetch quests. All in all, there's a pretty decent amount of content outside of the main quest.The main storyline is nothing to write home about, and is pretty predictable unless you're new to (J)RPGs, but it's not the worst I've ran into. Recommended to all turn-based rpg fans.

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												Disclaimber: This review was written 11/09/2010The Last Remnant is about a kid who's sister become kidnapped and he ventures on a journey to save her. The game is mainly marketed of it's "strategic" combat system where you can flank, intercept and such while still being a "faithful" JRPG.When you start up the game you are greeted with awesome music and some really sweet battles and I love large battles. It gives me chills in all the Total War games, but this game is nothing like Total War. The graphics use the unreal engine are alright (when it gets going), although this game is especially slow on loading textures in relatively small areas, which will mean that you're going to watch a lot of low-res textures (this might be fixed by defraging the hard drive though). The art style is a joke. If you didn't like Final Fantasy IX for it's art style you're going to hate this game because it's inhabited by giant fish people, small rabbit-frogs and orcs... no wait, those are just guards. All especially bred to be as cartoony as possible. The main characters are ridiculously emo-looking, and I mean all the main characters, which is why this style needs to die, right now.The biggest problem with this game however is the combat system. It sucks♥♥♥♥♥because it has nothing to do with strategy. Since it uses turns you cannot in reality intercept someone because you never know who they're trying to go after. You "flank" your opponents by sending more than one unit towards them, if you're opponent is then fighting more than one squad in the same time you'll flank them and this is regardless of squad size so 1 squad vs 2 squads equals flank but the nice thing is that the squad can be surrounded and that happens when they're fighting over 3-4 enemies I believe. When the fighting starts it only looks like a giant brawl without any kind of structure, and since the game deals with relatively low numbers of units it wont look as epic as the brawls in the Total War series where they're mostly chaotic because here the characters take turns to hit each other. You get 3 squads in which you can have max 5 people in them it's kinda strange that they would even be able to flank someone and quite fitting it all turns into a brawl. Your performance of the battles are entirely luck based because you never really directly command your units in battle. If you want them to heal themselves you gotta wait until they're bleeding to death before the option is even available. I thought this didn't sound so bad before I bought the game but in practice it ruins the "tactics element" of it all, if you could call it that.So basically you can't flank your opponents if you don't outnumber them and you cannot directly control your squadmates. This is a game where the player doesn't have much control over and you would probably have better control when trying to win at ♥♥♥♥ing slot machines! The control you do have is where to send your squads, vague pointers on how they should fight and who goes in what squad. Oh and by the way, you don't get to choose their equipment either. Poof, now a RPG element are gone too.Do I even have to say more? The story mayhap? When you meet (what the ♥♥♥♥ his name was) you befriend him and the story turns over to him for a moment while he tries to make his vassal state independent from another vassal state. Yes, this game deals in Feudalism (kind of) and you get to follow his struggle for his state's independence for a little while. He promises you that he will find your sister in the process but it have to be done methodically. The story isn't half bad I think and it would be really interesting to follow up on if only the game actually let you control the battles. It becomes increasingly difficult to control the outcome of the battles and you would probably lose quite a few battles because you simply cannot control anything that's happening during the course of it.Decent story and graphics, poor characters and art style and a bad gameplay. If you could control the game it would be alright but a game that cannot interact with the player isn't worth spending many hours of frustration on. And don't even get me started on the giant learning curve, why is it so big? Because no one tells you squat and the game is so unorthodox in almost every way. There's a stat that is different for each character that seems more like a characteristic. It changes with levels but what does it do? No, this game is hopelessly bad, don't even try it.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2012
												Recommended BUT....This game is an odd one.  It's a JRPG complete with animal people, teenaged leading character, and a fairly good story once it gets started but it's got a pretty strange combat system.  It supports mouse/keyboard though it could have supported them better.  It also has a tendency to hide pretty important information on how the game works but there's now an excellent Wikia website that will fill you in on all the details you care to learn.The combat system is really the make-or-break feature for this game, IMHO, and it's very different from anything I've ever played before or since.  It's turn based but you get to have a lot of characters in your party (up to 18 eventually) so telling each one of them exactly what to do would take way too long.  Instead, you divide your team into squads then give general orders to the squad along the lines of "attack with melee" and "stand back and heal" then the members of the squad use their abilities to carry out those orders.Not all the possible commands appear every round, though.  The game will pick out four or five of them depending on the situation, who the squad's leader is, and other factors.  That will drive some folks crazy but I found it to be a fun part of the game as it forced me to think about what I could still do even though I didn't get to do exactly what I wanted.  It's a bit like being dealt a hand of cards then figuring out what to do with them instead of picking out the best cards from the deck every time.You're definitely given a lot of choices in this game.  Simply picking the most expensive commands and attacking whatever is right in front of you with whatever squads you throw together will work OK for a few hours but you'll never make it through the whole game that way.  You're going to need to think about what characters should make up your squads, how many squads you should have, which characters should lead, which characters to hire, which monsters to attack (genocide is NOT the answer), how many to attack at once, whether to send all your squads after one enemy squad or to spread out more, and so on.  You certainly don't need to master every aspect of the game to complete it but you do need to get good at most of them.  (Unfortunately, the game doesn't have a difficulty setting.)Character skill progression is a learn-by-doing system.  If you want Nora casting Cachexia by the end of the game then you'll need to let her do some poison gas spells instead of pounding everything with her hammer.  Character weapons are a major part of progression, too, which are advanced by finding components for your characters to use.  (The Wikia site is extremely handy for that aspect of the game.  Why the developers thought you would actually remember where you found some necrotic metal or which type of critter dropped a mystic fiend horn I have no idea.)I see a lot of reviews are complaining about grinding... uhh, yeah, you can ignore those.  This is one of the few JRPGs that will actually PUNISH you if you try to exploit the game by grinding!  You see, most JRPGs have fixed monster levels while the characters that get added to your party as you find them automatically adjust to the player's level.  So some people will sit back in the early parts of the game fighting the same monsters over and over until they are so high level that nothing can stop them.  In this game, the characters you find are fixed level but several of the monsters scale to your party's level.  That means the same tactic in this game will result in hiring weak characters against enemies that only a few members in your party can really fight!That said, the game CAN turn grindy after you've gotten all the characters you want but it's completely optional.  The game can be completed just fine with no grinding at all.  You won't be able to finish some of the most difficult quests but you won't miss out on any of the story at all.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2013
												Let me just say off the bat, the story in this game is garbage.There are some great NPCs that make it bearable, but as it stands, the game's plot and narrative are not that good.Having said that, everything else in this game is incredible.The combat is simply amazing, at first things may appear to be random, but most of the work comes from you building a working party.Your party consists of unions, and your attacks in the battle are determined by who's in that union and what skills they possess.For instance, if you want a union to have the chance to cast mystic arts, you'd use predominantly mystic art users in that union.You can also turn off characters skills, giving you another level of depth to play with.Aesthetically the game is gorgeous, plenty of effects in battle and clean texture work, it's also runs pretty well on lower end PCs.When it comes to audio, this game is damn near perfect.The voice acting is surprisingly well done, save for the main character, but everything else is top notch.The real star of the game though is easily the soundtrack, there is nothing wrong with it, and the quality is probably the best I've seen this generation.In the end, if you can look past the story being so stale, then you have one of the most unique games on the market right now.I thank god Square Enix decided to port this game, it was decent on the consoles, but it really shines on PC.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
												This JRPG is something I consider and underrated gem. Story 6/10The story is generic but not too generic to the point where it's unplayable. It has its moments but is dragged down by its predictability. There is a decent plot twist at the end but it doesn't help rate it any higher. Stories of unique mercenaries you hire are told through their conversations and related missions. Most of them do have an interesting background (Nora, Violet, etc.). But they could have expanded more on their stories which was dissapointing to say the least.Gameplay 8.5/10The heart of the game is in the gameplay. You can have up to 18 units in your team, split into a maximum of 5 groups called unions. Each character can learn various skills (with Rush being the only one that can learn every move except for Weapon Specific Arts) and their usage of skills gives them roles the field. However, you can only manually equip Rush with whatever he is able to hold.The others upgrade and request either weapons or components on their own (what they request is based on your Battle Rank and what path you chose for them) The combat system itself is turn based strategy. You have to be smart about what abilities you keep on and what commands you choose. You do not specifically choose what they will do in that turn but you can influence their decisions based on their path and what skills you keep on or off. The combat is very deep and doing a full in-depth review of it would take too long. Try the demo to see if it is your taste. HOWEVER, I must say that looking at various guides (especially the wiki for the game) is very useful in order to understand the stat gain system and its relationship to the Battle Rank system. You may be familiar with the stat gain system if you have played any of the SaGa RPGs (which makes sense because the developer also worked on the SaGa games as well)Graphics 7/10It is the Unrea Engine so the moves look pretty when they're the flashy moves. Sadly, it is also Square Enix's first attempt using the Unreal Engine so there are many texture pop-in issues (but they recover in a few seconds). The environments without Remnants are relatively bland compared to the areas where Remnants are visible. Music 9/10The music is great for each scenario. The fights in open areas is very energetic, the fights in closed areas have a feeling of suspense. The music also changes during fights to match the current morale of the team. If it is low, then the music becomes darker, if the morale is high, it makes you feel like kicking♥♥♥♥♥Overall, I give it an 8/10

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2012
												Recommended BUT....This game is an odd one.  It's a JRPG complete with animal people, teenaged leading character, and a fairly good story once it gets started but it's got a pretty strange combat system.  It supports mouse/keyboard though it could have supported them better.  It also has a tendency to hide pretty important information on how the game works but there's now an excellent Wikia website that will fill you in on all the details you care to learn.The combat system is really the make-or-break feature for this game, IMHO, and it's very different from anything I've ever played before or since.  It's turn based but you get to have a lot of characters in your party (up to 18 eventually) so telling each one of them exactly what to do would take way too long.  Instead, you divide your team into squads then give general orders to the squad along the lines of "attack with melee" and "stand back and heal" then the members of the squad use their abilities to carry out those orders.Not all the possible commands appear every round, though.  The game will pick out four or five of them depending on the situation, who the squad's leader is, and other factors.  That will drive some folks crazy but I found it to be a fun part of the game as it forced me to think about what I could still do even though I didn't get to do exactly what I wanted.  It's a bit like being dealt a hand of cards then figuring out what to do with them instead of picking out the best cards from the deck every time.You're definitely given a lot of choices in this game.  Simply picking the most expensive commands and attacking whatever is right in front of you with whatever squads you throw together will work OK for a few hours but you'll never make it through the whole game that way.  You're going to need to think about what characters should make up your squads, how many squads you should have, which characters should lead, which characters to hire, which monsters to attack (genocide is NOT the answer), how many to attack at once, whether to send all your squads after one enemy squad or to spread out more, and so on.  You certainly don't need to master every aspect of the game to complete it but you do need to get good at most of them.  (Unfortunately, the game doesn't have a difficulty setting.)Character skill progression is a learn-by-doing system.  If you want Nora casting Cachexia by the end of the game then you'll need to let her do some poison gas spells instead of pounding everything with her hammer.  Character weapons are a major part of progression, too, which are advanced by finding components for your characters to use.  (The Wikia site is extremely handy for that aspect of the game.  Why the developers thought you would actually remember where you found some necrotic metal or which type of critter dropped a mystic fiend horn I have no idea.)I see a lot of reviews are complaining about grinding... uhh, yeah, you can ignore those.  This is one of the few JRPGs that will actually PUNISH you if you try to exploit the game by grinding!  You see, most JRPGs have fixed monster levels while the characters that get added to your party as you find them automatically adjust to the player's level.  So some people will sit back in the early parts of the game fighting the same monsters over and over until they are so high level that nothing can stop them.  In this game, the characters you find are fixed level but several of the monsters scale to your party's level.  That means the same tactic in this game will result in hiring weak characters against enemies that only a few members in your party can really fight!That said, the game CAN turn grindy after you've gotten all the characters you want but it's completely optional.  The game can be completed just fine with no grinding at all.  You won't be able to finish some of the most difficult quests but you won't miss out on any of the story at all.

It is nice to discover something new on the Third playthrough, but it wasn't be criminal if developers discribe game mechanics deeper, so developing Combat or Mystic Arts do not feel that random on First playthrough.Main storyline... it exist, but it's bellow average for too many reasons. Many scenes feels typical with several character poor acting or looking outside their role.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2013
												Let me just say off the bat, the story in this game is garbage.There are some great NPCs that make it bearable, but as it stands, the game's plot and narrative are not that good.Having said that, everything else in this game is incredible.The combat is simply amazing, at first things may appear to be random, but most of the work comes from you building a working party.Your party consists of unions, and your attacks in the battle are determined by who's in that union and what skills they possess.For instance, if you want a union to have the chance to cast mystic arts, you'd use predominantly mystic art users in that union.You can also turn off characters skills, giving you another level of depth to play with.Aesthetically the game is gorgeous, plenty of effects in battle and clean texture work, it's also runs pretty well on lower end PCs.When it comes to audio, this game is damn near perfect.The voice acting is surprisingly well done, save for the main character, but everything else is top notch.The real star of the game though is easily the soundtrack, there is nothing wrong with it, and the quality is probably the best I've seen this generation.In the end, if you can look past the story being so stale, then you have one of the most unique games on the market right now.I thank god Square Enix decided to port this game, it was decent on the consoles, but it really shines on PC.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2016
												Fantastic game, loved it on Xbox and on PC even more. Like the Saga games, the mechanics are unique and poorly explained or not at all, and considerably more complex than a standard JRPG like Final Fantasy or Tales. But once you get to grips with it all, it's SO satisfying.It provides a sigificant challenge, in fact, if you don't understand the mechanics and play it like many people tend to play a regular JRPG  - i.e. lots of grinding - then it can become much more difficult, possibly overwhelmingly so. Essentially this is an ANTI-grind JRPG, but actually you can grind if you wish, you just have to do it in the right way. Thankfully there are a number of experienced and helpful players and a comprehensive wiki, so if you're prepared to spend the time to learn, then you'll discover one of the most satisfying JRPG's i've ever played. Story; the usual JRPG nonsense. The main characters aren't particularly interesting, but they aren't annoying either, a feat many JRPG's can't manage. But there's a huge roster of support characters some of whom are endearing and memorable.Gameplay - 9 out of 10Story - 6Visual design - 8Music - 8 1/2

content:
Posted: January 1
												I went into this game like almost every game I play not knowing what to expect.  Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥I found a diamond in the rough.  Let me be brutally honest, the story isn't what makes this game.  However, it doesn't break it either.  I grew up with Final Fantasy so I saw this game and realized "Aw shhit dawg, is this a final fantasy spin off like Bravely Default?" Hell naw THIS IS BETTER.  The combat is just tactical warfare and is something new to the JRPG genre.  There are many side quests (which is what you'll be doing more then half the time) to find unique leaders to add to your roster.  Each leader is as stated, unique.  Spells, abilities, etc.  They all have voice actors and back story (kindof) and obviously interactive quest.  If you haven't played this and are big on Final Fantasy, I assure you, you will not regret buying this.Final Verdict - 7/10The game is technically endless.  However it has a boring story.  The combat is a 10/10 entertaining to watch in my opinion aswell.  Buy half off tho cause you might not like this game, as its not for everyone.
