												Oh man... Where do I even begin. I have a very hard time liking this game, yet I still do not dislike it.There are so many great things in this game, that it often ruined due to things that could easily be evaded... BY THE PLAYER!PLEASE NOTE: That I have 41 or so hours invested in this game (Which is not that much) This is not that much of a Review. It is mainly for people, who is in doubt if they should buy this game. I have not completed it yet. I have, however, spent alot of time playing this and this is more a way to introduce you and give you tips, so you do not get this great game ruined, like I did.A Brief Intro:The game has really nice graphics and a really amazing world, for you to explore... And there is plenty of things for you to explore. There are many discrete places, which may hide a nice little treasure or a rare monster for you to kill, or capture. After each battle you can happen to loot a living monster/beast, which you can either harvest for rare components, or just keep it and sell it. Rare monster can be sold for alot. The nice enviroment is very Final Fantasy-familiar, but the game has this "mature" tone. I by that I mean it is more raw and real (IT EVEN HAS BLOOD :O) This very bright and big world is filled with all sorts of monsters. Note that monsters has their own 'Natural Habitat', so you will not find a Flying Flame Orb Monster in the sea, no you will find Fish-like beasts here. The same models are re-used often, just with a different skin. This is not bad in anyway, as the variety of monsters are very big. So you won't get bored of always meeting the same monsters, except for those damn spiders... Keep in mind the variety of monsters, is no way near how many different monsters the FF-series has. Yet enough and they looks insanely cool. At least most of them. There are huge giant dragon too... Who does not like to duel such a beast? And they look like Bahamut too.The combat is very different from anything you are used to. At least here in the western realms. You control 'Unions' which consist of up to 6 (Or 5? Sry can't remember right now) 'Units', that is basically small squad... or units... One unit can hold up to 5 Characters. Each units is offered options that they will then execute after all units have been assigned which options to perform (Attack, Magic, Heal, Ranged or just chill). These options/actions are only avaiable under certain conditions. Like you are not able to revive if enemy units are 'Deadblocking' you (Simply ganging up on you). It CAN be very difficult to understand and learn this combat system, which is part of why I have a hard relationship with this game. It can be extremely time consuming to set up each unit and assign them the correct roles. Units are also assigned which 'Formations' they should fight in. And there are many and plenty to choose from, in order to get just the right formation for a battle. This too can be hard to understand, but very rewarding when learned.It is partly open-world, or what you will call it and it filled my desires of a open world. Meaning that the 'World Map' which you often navigate through, holds many different locations, that you fast travel to. You never actually walk, unless you want to unlock new areas, or quests. From the World Map you pick which destination you need leave to and BANG you are there. Be it a dungeoun, forest, desert or one the many Cities. So lets say you venture to Drillmor (One of the first locations), from the World Map, then you will spawn in Drillmor and a huge map will be there for you to explore, with certain enviroments. Like Drillmor is grassy mountain place, while others are swamps, desert or old castles. These location are where you will do most of you quest, hunt rare monters or just grind exp. Cities is where you get quest, and is often build up of 2-4 districts, where you can walk around too. There are many NPC's and alot of different (useless, but pretty) decoration in every city. Very well made. Some quest are also done inside cities.There are many, many bosses in this game and that is nice. They each deliver their own challenges, some easy, some damn hard. It can be very difficult sometimes, to defeat a certain enemy. Yet with the right formation and tactics, these battles can suddenly turn extremely easy.Now how can I be annoyed after all these saucy and delicious things the game has to offer? I tell you, and I will it hard!I really hope that you read this, so that you do not experience this and only have a fun time with this game, which it is very able to deliver, if treated right.THIS IS NOT FINAL FANTASY! Yet you will recognize alot of familiar elements. I experienced playing and running through the game smoothly. Enemies were alright and some were tough. Bosses made tension rise at times, and sometimes I thought I would loose, only to have a great victory. I started feeling like I was a bit strong and might had grinded a bit too much (Which I had not, I just killed every enemy on my quests). Then BOOM! I kept running into one enemy after another that would annihilate my units fast and effective. It just kept happening and then I thought: "Have I missed somthing? Like a dungload of quests?" The answer was a big smelly YES. Yet I spend alot of boring time grinding, with no knowledge of the quests I had missed. I mean it was like 15 quests or something. Luckily I had still time to gather them all and finish them, but I had spent some time meanwhile, running around not knowing what to do, or where to go. Which destroyed that great new and exciting feeling I had, and quickly made me rant as I ran around in fantasy land. This could easily have been avoided.So I finished to quests, but that was not fun either, as one quest was nice and just as hard as I like it. Then the next stage of the quest would throw a dark mega dragon in my face that would KoS from miles aways. KO. Then I learned how important formations and the 'Arts/Skills/Magic' is. So I learned that, but once again, that WOOOAW-feeling had turned a bit thinner. Now I just want to finish this dung and get on with my life. I hate it so much, but still wake up and it is the first thing I turn on. I really like it, but I wish that WOOOAW-feeling had lasted a bit longer, and not had been ruined by my ignorance to the game. I HIGHLY suggest that you use The Last Remnant Wiki (google it) and spend some time to learn all these things and know when and where to get quests, so you do not get stucked somewhere. This is really a great game, and if you know what you are doing it will last until the end of the game. Use that website and learn all you can, without spoiling anything, like the story and such. Which is pretty good so far.-It can take very long to organize your Union and Units, wich can be really exhausting at times.-Very bad at introducing you to the mechanics, due to them being so advanced and new.-Many things has to be learned on the internet, or by being a magic genius.-Amount of enemy units can at times be very irregular. Sometimes 1, other times 3. Not that big of a deal.-Very easy to get lost and not knowing where to go next (except main quests. You always know where to go).-Extremely annoying Spiders... I really hate them and try to avoid them at any times. They are not tough, just annoying.All these CONS can be avoided if the player takes the time to prepare himself/herself for the game and learns a little bit. I highly advice to use the WIKI and trying not to read the spoilers.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												Certainly is underrated. Story is alright for a JRPG. Its full of traditional JRPG tropes so not too much new there. The protagonist is a sis-con/etc. However, where it becomes more unique is in party formations. This is like an RPG game with a heavier emphasis on setting up your parties to handle all threats. It is a different and welcome approach. Because of this, some fights can be much harder than they need be. You'll likely find lots of people complaining about the difficulty. But here is probably the greatest tip of all and it didn't take much to figure out. Yes some are hard, but they all have optimal strategies to make them work. It isn't luck of the draw. Luck only comes in when it comes to damage/resist totals. Overall instead of simple luck, it usually involves who you target first. If you are having trouble, try other combinations. I've had some tough ones become insanely easy because instead of focusing down one enemy, I focused another. Or instead of splitting up, I focused. The other big factor for this game is do a search on it for how to manually set the graphics/etc. Square - Enix did a pretty poor job. But there are wikis out there which will quickly tell you how to set the game up to look much better. It literally is a must do for anyone who buys this game. Read the sites, hack the ini, enjoy the game.It is a shame this title didn't get more refinement or better support from Square. Certainly is one of the more unique JRPGs out there. Play it in the Japanese dub if possible. The mannerisms and voices match much better. However, the English subs are sometimes grossly off the mark. If you know any Japanese, you'll notice right away when you come to a scene and wonder who translated it because what they are saying and what the text reads is not close.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2013
												The Last Remnant is a unique title.  It manages to have some of the greatest voices on the face of the planet and still manages to fall short due to its writing.  The main character is voiced by Johnny Yong Bosch, so you'd think he'd be able to save the performance, right?  Nope, the writing's that dry and cliched...though moreso the former than the latter.What does make this game worth recommending, however, is the gameplay.  When I say that the title is unique, I don't mean because of the writing; games have had great voices and bad writing before.  What makes this game unique is that it has a style of gameplay unseen since Chaos World back on the NES.  Rather than controlling one character at a time and fighting monsters that way, you take several characters into a fight and control them as squads.  This isn't a Turn-Based game, either, though it may look it...or not.  This game is the type of thing that is hard to decipher from videos alone, but its more of a Tactical Turn-Based RPG, though I wouldn't go as far as to call it a Strategy RPG.This game also lends itself to an OK story, but there's enough here to keep one who is having fun interested for a while.  The areas are large and open (and this is not a linear game), the customization is one of the more unique things I've seen out of an RPG, and the character recruitment process is slightly unpolished, among other things in the game, but the idea of having so many optional characters with histories and personalities is a nice touch.  If the price is low enough (and this game can go pretty low, price-wise) then I'd definitely recommend checking it out, especially if your looking for a unique experience.

												From Squeenix comes a fairly fun, non-traditional JRPG. I don't know if it's for everyone, but if you enjoyed Final Fantasy in its day and want a fantastic graphical update with a lot of fun mixed in, it's one to consider

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												I really tried to like this game as I'm running out of decent games to play...but I just can't finish it.The characters/writing are atrocious. Quests are horribly uninspired and are rarely more than "get to the end of the dungeon". The combat is unique at least, but I can't say that I enjoy it. It seems as if customisation is meant to be a huge part of the combat, but I'm ten hours in and haven't found any way to meaningfully to do so. Every enemy dies to the same combat arts spam. The fights themselves have the appearance of being tactical affairs, but it's RNG heavy. Sometimes one of your units gets focused by 4 enemies and dies, leaving you with a lost fight. Short of that, the same ganging up on enemy units is always the correct approach. (At least up to where I made it)It is an interesting idea of a game, but it completely falls short in all areas.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												The Last Remnant is a game I'd recommend, however, only to a certain type of player. In this review I'll try to go over what I liked and what frustrated me, to try and give a clearer picture for those looking to buy.I should note, I finished with 95 hours played at BR45. This was also completing most of the side quests as well as recruiting all major leaders, I also did a small amount of rare monster hunting.I also edited files to give the game a larger FOV and reduced texture pop in, I high recommend doing the same before playing, you can find a guide detailing how here on Steam.Here's what I liked:The graphics, this game looks fantastic. The remnants are wonderful to view and the small areas of the citys you can visit are well detailed (this does not include the bland dungeons).The large amount of items, drops and weapons. If resource gathering, crafting and mining is your thing, TLR's got you covered. The game contains tons of different items and components. You can go down many different weapon tree's, crafting better version of each weapons, turning them into more deadly looking tools. There's a fair amount of rare and boss weapon drops in the game too.The variation of combat arts and mystic arts. These's are the ability's your characters will learn and perform. There's a huge amount, most look fairly wonderful to watch. It's also nice to assign certain Leader's to specialize in these area's.The music. This game has some fantastic music, tracks like Swirling Sands from the Great Sand Sea are a favourite.The menu's and IU. It's a fairly important part of an RPG, this game nails it. It's clean, slick and easy to use.Here's some things I didn't like:You can't manually select what a character cast during battle. I see what Square Enix was trying to do here, but it simply ended up with you turn different move's on and off before battle, just so your desired move was forced to come up during battle. It ended up becoming annoying more than anythign else.When you most need a certain command during battle, it won't show. Let's say I only have one Union left, I want to revive my other downed Unions, the game will at times, only give me attack commands rather than showing me something I really need.Poor character development. Firstly, Rush is out right annoying and the few characters who have likable personalities aren't explored, they're left to occational one liners.Battle's a boring at first. TLR is a hard game. Until you open up the better moves and are able to create more interesting Unions the battles feel alot like pressing the same button and watching a short cutscene until it's over. Now this changes somewhat later on. Anyone who's played Final Fantasy 13 will understand this very problem.I would say The Last Remnant is an aquired taste. The more I played it, the better and more interesting it's mechanic's and features got. Anyone who's interested in a challenging JRPG will want to give this a go. If you're looking for something more traditional, this may not be for you.If you're unsure my advise would be to YouTube some gameplay videos, flick over the different mechanic's on this game wonderful Wiki.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												Another of Square's fantasy rpg's. At first I was thinking this is just another Final Fantasy clone and guess what it really was'nt.. maybe a little!!!. You play the game as Rush, a young lad trying to save his sister ( there's a twist btw!!!) with the help of some friend's that join him along the way. The world revolves around some relics called "Remnants" that hold the balance of power and keep the inhabitants of the world somewhat protected. Now that's the games basic overview out of the way.. GaME PlaY - Good old fashioned turn based battle system, but with the added feature "Unions". Union's make several battle group's ranging from 2 - 5 character's in each of these that in turn each character from each group will get to attack, buff/debuff or heal as directed or @ random if "play by ear" is selected until your turn has ended fun fun fun !!! Now as I progressed through the game I could mine, collect, battle random monster's, puchase merc's to join my union's and even get the odd summon out!! etc etc then I got bored. There just was'nt enogh BIG moment's, most of my play through felt like one big side quest with additives of the main story chucked in hear and there.Conclusion : Boring game progression, Great battle system, not enough cgi (come on it's Square), graphic's are nice considering how old the game is...ohh and I forgot to moan about the fact you cannot change any of your union members gear/weapons, there changed @ random by the actual charcter's them selfs and most of the time there choices are poor.7/10.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												KUPO!When it first released for the Xbox 360, I was excited. Though it's price was steep and I decided to wait for it to drop. I waited MANY years for it to happen. I started to worry if I should regret the wait, but I bought it recently (Aug. 2014) and I KNOW it was a good choice to wait. It says that it's not compatible with Laptop systems, but I'm using an old Asus (mid year) 2012 laptop and it runs well enough for me to enjoy it. Al I had to do was sacrifice the graphics, which is fine for me. I have them set to the most minimal setting available. I am REALLY enjoying this title. If you like any of the Final Fantasy titles that have been released by Equare Enix (aka Squaresoft and Enix after they merged), I believe you will enjoy this tale. It's unique turn-based fighting system and it's progressive story make up for all the loss I had to give up to play (i.e. the graphics). I especially appreciate Sqare Enix's new system settings for this title. They allow you to adjust the game from the language text, language spoken, all the way through bindings of the controller, keyboard and mouse, and even allow you to adfjust the graphics and hardware settings. As a veteran player of over 20 Squaresoft/Square Enix titles, I give this one a 9/10 score :3Kupo!

												The Last Remnant is a unique title.  It manages to have some of the greatest voices on the face of the planet and still manages to fall short due to its writing.  The main character is voiced by Johnny Yong Bosch, so you'd think he'd be able to save the performance, right? This isn't a Turn-Based game, either, though it may look it...or not.  This game is the type of thing that is hard to decipher from videos alone, but its more of a Tactical Turn-Based RPG, though I wouldn't go as far as to call it a Strategy RPG.This game also lends itself to an OK story, but there's enough here to keep one who is having fun interested for a while.  The areas are large and open (and this is not a linear game), the customization is one of the more unique things I've seen out of an RPG, and the character recruitment process is slightly unpolished, among other things in the game, but the idea of having so many optional characters with histories and personalities is a nice touch.  If the price is low enough (and this game can go pretty low, price-wise) then I'd definitely recommend checking it out, especially if your looking for a unique experience.

												From Squeenix comes a fairly fun, non-traditional JRPG. The graphics, IMHO, are stunning, and the gameplay is simple enough to gain good control over if you simply pay attention to the tutorials that pop up when they are needed. One word of advice: in battling multiple foes, take out the ones that would flank you first. Honestly a very nice game, pretty decent story and full of painfully funny dialogue. content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												I really tried to like this game as I'm running out of decent games to play...but I just can't finish it.The characters/writing are atrocious. Quests are horribly uninspired and are rarely more than "get to the end of the dungeon". The combat is unique at least, but I can't say that I enjoy it. It seems as if customisation is meant to be a huge part of the combat, but I'm ten hours in and haven't found any way to meaningfully to do so. Every enemy dies to the same combat arts spam. The fights themselves have the appearance of being tactical affairs, but it's RNG heavy. Sometimes one of your units gets focused by 4 enemies and dies, leaving you with a lost fight. Short of that, the same ganging up on enemy units is always the correct approach. (At least up to where I made it)It is an interesting idea of a game, but it completely falls short in all areas.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												Rating: 6.5/10Overview: Turn Based JRPGThe Good:+In any JRPG you will spend the majority of time in combat, so it's important that you enjoy it or else you probably won't enjoy the game. Luckily this game has an enjoyable and strategic combat system. Rather than control single units you command groups of units called unions. You can have a max of 5 party members per union and a total of 18 party members. Thus one of the first strategic decisions you make is whether  or not you should have a few large unions or many smaller unions. Each one comes with its own pros and cons. Within each union you can also set the formation which also grants certain benefits and weaknesses. I.e Higher strength vs lower magic.  In combat each union is given a list of commands depending on which party members you grouped together. When you engage with an enemy union "deadlock" occurs. Deadlock means you have to kill the enemy union before you can target someone else. However, you can break deadlock to heal/revive another union, however this  will mean the enemy will get an extra attack. Thus, it becomes very important to only break deadlock when necessary. In addition to this, there is also flank attacks, rear attacks, interference/interceptions,...terms the game does a decent job of explaining.  Who you attack and how many unions you send to attack is a large part of the strategy involve. Do you gang up on a single enemy union causing more damage but leaves you more vulnerable to flank attacks or do you target multiple enemy unions and hopes your party is strong enough to handle each one? These are some of decision you make during some of the tougher battles.There is also a morale meter in combat. The more you kill enemy unions, flank attack, interfere, and in general the better you do in combat, the higher the morale. A higher morale means more damage given and less damage taken. Conversely, the better the enemy does the lower the moral meter. Lower morale means more damage taken and less given. During some of the easier battles, moral doesn't play that big of a role, but when you start fighting boss enemies it's important to keep the morale as high as possible as it could be the difference between surviving an attack or having an entire union wiped out in a single blow.   You put this all together and you have a fun, fast and engaging combat system that can easily hold up throughout the course of the game. + Turbo mode option doubles the speed of battle. A great feature that speeds up gameplay.  + An option that turns off quick time events in battle and makes them automatic. During battle there are times when you have QTE granting you higher damage.  Again, a great feature to have. The only downside to this is that it has roughly  80% success rate.  + The game auto saves after every battle and every time you enter an area. I know it's not exactly a big thing but this feature saved me a lot of trouble during the course of the game. +The game is filled with interesting locations and characters. Each city feels different based on the geographical location. The areas you explore are varied, from subterranean caverns, sandy deserts to forests and swamps. Artistically they all feel great and fun to explore. + The game is filled with plenty of side quests and optional areas. Completing many of these side quests allow you to hire specific characters for your party so it provides a good incentive for completing them. If you just stick to the main story you will probably miss over 50% of the game. +This is more than just a straight port to the PC. The game makes a variety of gameplay and balance changes throughout the entire game and Square-Enix should be commended for taking the time and effort to make the game better on PC. +Loved the musicThe Bad:-The biggest downside is the game does such a poor job of explaining some of the more important game mechanics. For example, the game gives a brief 2 line description about the type of formation you want to use but does not mention how specific of a bonus or weakness it will give your party. The game desperately needed an codex within the game detailing monsters and where to find items to upgrade your equipment. Having to go online to search for this information is an indication of poor design.   -One of the more important mechanics the game fails to explain is Battle Rank. As you win battles your Battle Rank goes up which is dependent on how many monsters you fight, how hard the battle is, how many unions died in battle etc. You would think the higher the Battle Rank the better your doing. In fact the higher the rank, the harder the enemies. If your Battle Rank grows higher than the rate in which your stats increase you could find the enemies very difficult to defeat and find yourself stuck. Granted, this is one feature they improved upon the PC version however it's still a problem and it is poorly explained in the game.  In theory, it is a good system to have to prevent grinding, however this system can also be exploited. - The game has some ludicrous difficulty spikes. I almost stopped playing the game early on because of how frustrating the battles became, especially boss battles.  Normally you can just can grind it out, however because of Battle Rank you have to be a bit more careful how you improve your stats. -I am not a fan of JRPG's stories and this game is no exception. The story feels stereotypical of all JRPG's before it. The dialogue is embarrassingly bad and the voice acting is just as terrible. The characters are one dimensional and the main character is annoying. -Significant texture pop in. ConclusionI enjoyed the game but its flaws really dragged the game down. What should have been a more enjoyable experience ultimately felt more frustrating. Despite the  score I still recommend the game because if you like JRPGs and like learning new game systems  and getting really immersed in the game this is a game you should check out. Everybody else should expect an average JRPG.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												Overall, I give the game a "thumbs up", but it will ultimately split players based on its quirky leveling and combat system.  There are a couple other design decisions that I thought were odd, but they did not detract from my enjoyment of this title.  The core of this game is all about the fighting, and you will do a lot of it.  The battle system takes some getting used to.  First of all, your characters fight in small groups called unions.  As you progress through the game, you unlock more characters, formations, skills, etc.  The bit that takes some getting used to is that the player does not necessarily give orders to individual characters, but only to the unions.  For the most part I did not have any issues with this system once I got used to it.  However, there were times when I needed to heal up and that option just was not available.  It was also a little frustrating when my super skills that can be used by some of the main characters would not come up during boss battles but would come up while fighting some weak creature.  The game itself does a horrible job of giving any real details about this battle system.  So much is really out of the player's hands.  Other than giving high level commands to your unions, the actual skills that are performed are up to the individual characters and can change based on the situation.  This seemed to work fairly well other than a few critical times when I needed to heal up a downed union, but this will drive some players bonkers.  Another odd bit about the battle system is the area of the fight.  You get to decide which enemy union your unions will be fighting against.  Sounds great until you see that the positioning itself makes no real tactical sense.  AOE skills may completely miss or hit all the enemy unions.  Unfortunately, the player really has no control over specific placement.  The other major leveling portion is weapons and crafting.  There are literally hundreds and hundreds of components, upgrade materials, crafting elements, etc.  The actual inventory system is terrible.  Keep that WIKI handy as it is crucial to find that one oddly-named item you need to upgrade your weapon.  Your party characters will also ask for items at times and it is satisfying to see their weapons change from low level into deadly works of art later in the game.  Be aware that for some items you need to first have to complete a quest to get the ability to farm that needed item off of a monster.  Story is overall fairly good and kept me interested.  Know that my time with the core quest was only about a quarter to third of my gametime.  The rest was doing optional content and we aren't just talking about a couple of zones.  There are whole areas and cities which can be missed.  Even some party characters will give quests which can be satisfying.  Graphics during the fight scenes are excellent with fluid movements.  On the other hand, characters moved stiffly during some of the cutscenes.  Completionists can expect a lot to do with all of the items to upgrade and quests to complete.  Most of this is good, but one of the most annoying aspects of the game for me was trying to get certain monsters to spawn for certain guild quests.  Monsters in the various zones spawn off of a set table (check WIKI) and this includes rares.  The issue is having to zone to the overworld and then back again just to get the desired monster to spawn.  It really gets tedious when the needed monster is deep in a labrynth.  It just takes away from the whole immersion and it made some of my play sessions tedious.I realize I gave some negative items in the review above but for the most part I really liked this game.  I would strongly recommend the demo first so you can see for yourself if it is something you would want to spend 100+ hours on.

												From the staff of Square Enix, The Last Remnant offers all the RPG excitement you have come to love with a few new tweaks. Play as Rush Sykes, you are on a mission to save your sister, and perhapes the ery world as well. Gather allies and command them in turn based combat as not just individual characters, but a unit as well. his unconventional approach may seem wierd at first, but after playing a bit, tends to grow on you as you build up your units and charge into battle in a story like no other.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												Sick of hack n' slash action games posing as the real deal? This is a great way for PC gamers to play a turn-based, strategic RPG, which unfortunately, has been a dying genre for the platform since the 90s. I don't like that it eschews a world map (a terrible trend in Japanese RPGs). However, some of the areas are vast enough to give the feel of a world map, even if you are just picking names of places to go. This isn't as good as Final Fantasy XII, the only FF that wasn't garbage after IX, but it gets the job done. The battle system could have offered more control, but it adds a different kind of strategy with who to target, and when to use what commands you are given the option to use. The texture pop-in of the UT3 engine is bad, and the cutscenes look like crap even after forcing v sync with a third-party app, but the towns and the remnants look cool. There are also many sidequests, and you'll probably need to do a lot of them because the boss battles can be rough.

												the last remnant is an amazing square game that got bashed on too much. this is a great rpg thats different every time you play it. over multiple completions i still come back to it and find something i havent done before. the battle system is great, fun and a little complicated which turned quite a few people down but its really not any harder of a typical square game. the story is great and hooks you right in, music and enviroments are a sight to see as well as the cities, and plenty of secrets, characters, and items well after you beat it. a much improved version compared to the xbox version. square took everything wrong with the xbox version and made a much better complete game for pc and for 10 bucks you cant beat that at all.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												The Last Remnant is a game that, at times, will be unforgiving. The very beginning of the game, RNG can take you for a ride, and before you know it you have game over'd on the first fight. The combat system is unique, leaving unions to choose their specific attacks. This allows the fight to feel more real than having units spam the same move multiple times. The story isn't as expected, as the story seems to make one think how did it all happen the way it did. Overall, I would recommend this game not on the premise for the story, but for the unique combat system.

I would strongly recommend the demo first so you can see for yourself if it is something you would want to spend 100+ hours on.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2013
												This game is amazing! The first thing you need to understand is this game is the fixed version. If you look for reveiws online they all talk about the Xbox and Playstation versions that were all a buggy mess. When they ported to the PC they added in all the content from both consoles and fixed the bugs and glitches.I recommend using a controller for the game as well (though it does work with keyboard and mouse but I found it more enjoyable/easier for me personally to use a controller). I used an Xbox 360 controller (built-in support for it) and had no issues whatsoever.The difficulty of the game is counter to almost every other JRPG made. The difficulty increases as you grind and level up so you can technically beat the game at lvl1 faster/easier than at lvl99+. The combat is turn based/auto-resolve where the only control over the fights you have is setting up the units in the groups and telling what style you want the group to fight as (attack/assist/defend/etc).The game part way in unlocks the ability to slow/freeze time to allow you to "tag" enemies so you can chain groups to increase the drop chance of items and increase the xp you get (bonus for the more enemies you fight at once).There is a New Game+ ****BUT***** it's not your normal New Game+ Mode. Instead of having all the levels, items and units you unlocked before you start over from scratch with only some things carrying over.Things that carry over as copied from the wiki article (http://lastremnant.wikia.com/wiki/New_Game_Plus)    All components    All formations    All magazines    Your current customization levels    All items that unlock arts for Rush. Rush will also begin the new game with the first art of the skills granted to him by the Orbs and Formulas. For example, carrying over the Evocation-enabling Azure Orb will grant Rush the lowest-ranked Evocation, Mystic Missile, at the start of the game.    Mr. Diggs' skill levels and digs count    All area mapsSo when you are close to finishing the game (it'll be pretty clear as you'll be able to craft really good items) DON'T CRAFT ANYTHING AND FINISH THE GAME IF YOU PLAN ON PLAYING NEW GAME+!

												basically only buy this if you're an experienced jrpg fanthe battle system is the strongest point of the game for me as its a really interesting mix of JRPG turn based combat with elements from strategy games. but i've also heard the exact opposite opinion from people who liked everything else in the game so much that they put up with the combat. so idk, maybe there's a little something in this game for everyone?the battle system is really fun and is full of a lot of interesting mechanics, but the game isn't exactly top notch at explaining it all. it took me 3/4ths of the game to feel like i completely understood the battle mechanics, and even then i found myself a little confused or frustrated at times. the battles sometimes feel very random but often times the only thing that decides the winner is your own strategypersonally i found the story to be really boring and unengaging, but not enough that it made me stop caring. there was interest in seeing where the story went, but i didn't feel like i really cared what happened. i just wanted to knowthe difficulty of the game is also skewed as ♥♥♥♥, there were boss battles that i had to retry over and over that were side by side with boss battles i felt were extremely underwhelming. maybe i was doing something very wrongalso 75% of the content of this game is sidequests. if that's your thing then cool but i found it very weird that there were entire cities and full dungeons that i wouldn't have known about if i hadn't stopped in at a town's pub. also a lot of the sidequests don't feel that special, it's often just going to a dungeon and getting to the "end" of it.i've said a lot of bad things about the game but it honestly is worth playing, especially at its price. i got a good 60 hours out of it and that's only with half the sidequests done. i really enjoyed creating parties and seeing what worked in battles and i really enjoyed the larger scale wars, even though there weren't too many. the story isn't that bad but i couldn't care less about the characters. idk. if you're big on rpgs with interesting battle systems i absolutely recommend this

content:
Posted: March 30, 2013
												Last Remnant is a very complex and interesting game with lots of unique mechanics. The problem is that the game doesn't really tell you what those mechanics are or how they work. As a result, a lot of things will just seem random or abritrary unless you look things up in the wiki.If you do spend time on the Wiki, you can find out how arcana magic works, how people skill up, how to level your characters so that they change into certain classes, how to make sure your members learn special abilities and how to manipulate union formations to give the biggest bonus stats. It's also very easy to skip quests and therefore miss important items or recruitable players without using the wiki as many quests become unavailable after certain story developments in the game. However, personally, I found it extremely rewarding to figure out everything and create the optimum setup for my team. It really depends on if you want to invest the time and effort.The start of the game is pretty slow, as combat is very repetitive until you unlock more skill types to give you a variety of battle options. Contrary to what a lot of people seem to say, you don't have to grind whatsoever. You have the ability to slow time, making it rather easy to avoid the monsters on the field, and as monsters scale with your level it can often make it more difficult to grind. The reason people think this is because some of the bosses are very hard, but you're supposed to change your union formations to suit the fight.The music is very atmospheric, particularly the battle music, though it can sometimes be a tiny bit repetitive if you play for long periods of time. The voice acting is very good and it adds a lot in the battle when the characters yell things out while they fight, but you probably want to keep it in Japanese with subtitles. The English ones aren't that bad, just a bit cheesy.The game is quite old but some of the graphics are still amazing to me. Everything is really detailed and has it's own atmosphere. Melphina is probably still one of my favorite cities in any game - just stand on the deck and stare out at the waterfall-thing. It also makes battles a lot cooler, when you're fighting huge dragons and they're all look gorgeous. It was very forward for it's time, and even now a lot of games don't do it as well. As it's a console port, using a controller is much more smooth, and it's easier to hit the buttons during fast-paced quicktime scenes in battles using one. And, as most people didn't seem to know, you can skip cutscenes by hitting Pause/Break (where the scroll lock and print screen buttons are) and then hitting S (Not sure if there are specific controller buttons for this).

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												As much love as I have for this game, I can clearly say this is one of the games that I will pull up when a friend asks me why I never tell them about obscure games made by high end companies. You should experience it. But if it's your last couple of bucks or you do not want to be cruelly punished for trying to defeat rare game as much as this. Stay away. This seems to be targeted to people who liked everything about final fantasy 12 but the gambit system and having full control over everyone. You have almost no control here, You're pretty much trusting the ai to use from a skillset you create for them to use, though those skills you can turn off, probably need to be on to grow. Go figure. Happy sails to figuring it out, or go find a guide that works, play the game in a linear fashion, or get trolled by the levelling system wondering why enemies aren't dying when they were when you left it. Let me give you a glimpse of what to expect.... Ever played dissidia? got to a high level and turned down your level and watched as everything became easier to do? That's how this gets, But you can't go back, and trading for a weaker party may not help. I say this, because it is comparable to copying answers on the wrong test. Everything that square excels at is pure gold here. And what they do not do well gets caught through the filter and is easy to spot. Most strategy games will have you building perfect moves and ideas to make the best attacks possible and use them in battle to your own benefit. This does exist, but there is no explanation whatsoever to how this works, and looking it up online takes away from the flavor of playing the game on your own, and it seems very futile without it. Strategy... Is and isn't here. Obvious options like strike from afar and stay back is normal for most strategy games, but they do not last here. You will end up putting them in the fray or getting them ambushed by using waiting as a strategy. This game is sheer punishment and one wrong turn or missed action could doom you, Autosave exists. Thank the PC gods.As far as strategy games go, this is comparable to why most games force you to select a loadout before you do anything, you can do this here, but since there is no clear sign to if your unselected skills will grow or not, I leave them on in sheer faith that they will do what is needed, and that leads you to counting mp and tracking commands to predict what moves will show, which works. Another thing that delves from strategy is how often certain individuals reassess the situation and with who and under what limits, Certain groups with high holds of hp will not see danger in not maxing out health and will get you killed. While others who may be useless in battle or offensively grief your unit, will always know when to reassess and who to heal to keep things fresh and alive. Furthermore, the system shines at learning as you go at times, as when you're on the ropes healing just over what you're getting damaged, you'll learn a new skill, and you'll get better at it or beat the opposition afterward. But the problem is that the game knows what it has to offer, and it does anything it can to ruin it for you. On overpowered bosses? part of the strategy is to die to preserve your unit hp without having enough available units to be overwhelmed by a per unit attack. That is beyond realistic, and is almost impossible to do if you have or learn a revive skill. So you turn it off. Hope the curse kills off one or more of your units, it'll kill the leader and everyone on the team will turn vegetable no matter their own individual rank or standing. So the Marquis will literally just sit there and die, not join a unit or anything, ironically they will last the longest because they retain the group's health pool. Keep all party members and take a critical group attack? Game Over. Take small groups into battle? A direct attack will kill you. Normally you would think, hey, I probably need to gain a few levels and learn some attacks. No, the game has a tiered level system less brutal than xbox, but is more rampant on you developing a strategy closely to luck and hopeful reassessment. You will not notice this until much later, or instantly if you are the thickheaded type to never put down a challenge, which is wholly enabled by a perfect auto save system. In its entirety, I can compare it to a fighting game, People watching you play will clearly see the holes and imbalances in the strategy and delivery in the game, and call how cheap it is at a constant beat, but when they ask why you still play it... my answer is more of wanting to see how much more obscene the curve balls are going to be, and when they're going to stop tearing holes through groups without fair reason. I'm sure anyone else looking for balance in the game will quickly pick up a guide and follow their lead to a balanced game and read through everything, spoilers included, to see when and where are the best times to defeat and complete enemies and quests. And I can safely say what a shame it is they weren't more introductive to newcomers to the genre as final fantasy is the normal mainstay of square, and even they made gambits a fair and eventually obvious system of priority and functionality. It'll take time to understand this game, and instead of the normal idea of overpowering enemies that wont take to strategy, You'll have to hoard equipment and hope that your allies take to it, and stop them from trying to snatch orange and yellow rare accessories just because. Which is a complete nuisance. When you get how this game works or when luck favors you, you will save over your game and have a breath of relief, because it's finally over and You won't have to sit curiously staring at the majestic enemy that can and did raze your team at every moment for no favorable reason at all. I love this game because I can see past this and ignore the fact that I can one shot bosses because a boss I almost defeated at rank 13 is practically impossible at rank 36. It sort of says, hey, the story is free, But the challenge is going to cost you. So when the game has given you a sound beating, you can go back to reading until you're annoyed, and return to try to grab the belt midswing, only finding out that this belt is now a sword and they hope you can figure out how to fight with one hand before... Too late, You died again.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												I actually gave this game another chance after having given up on it the first time through. Although I enjoyed it a lot more the second time around I still can't recommend this game. From the game mechanics to the presentation, eveything feels very clunky and unpolished. Pros:* Combat:It's still very much a traditonal turn-based JRPG in terms of combat although instead of just ganging up on one unit, you'll 1v1 everybody in order to prevent flank attacks which do more damage. There's an illusion that you're actually moving around like a tactical RPG ala Fire Emblem, but that's not really the case. There's also a morale system where you deal more damage if the battle's going your way, but I'm not really a big fan of it as I feel it's unnecessary and clunky.* Crafting:You're able to dungeon dive and kill monsters for components so that you can create new weapons or upgrade old weapons. Cons:* Shoddy camera:It zooms in when you're trying to look up and zooms out when you try to look down. I like my camera to be at a set distance and this made me slightly nauseous at times as I'm constantly zooming in and out as I try to look at something.* Story:I liked the game far more after I skipped all the cutscenes and ignored whatever Rush (MC) was saying. The story is whatever but Rush is very cringeworthy. * Gameplay:The game doesn't explain itself very well and I had to look up things a couple of times just to figure out what was going on. Why are orders random? What's this status effect do? I uninstalled the game after a boss cursed all my units and randomly instant KOed them and I couldn't heal or revive anybody.* No Exploration:Everything is an instance/dungeon so you pick among a list of choices on a map and teleport into that area.* JargonPersonal pet peeve. Raidlock? Deadlock? Unions? Why use such weird terminlogy? Engage / disengage and Squads / Unit is much more natural sounding.

It is not optimized for the PC.I have been to forums, trying out every suggestion to make the video and graphics better, as it should be since this is a 2009 game and my rig, though not the most powerful, still can hold its own.I have tried every graphics setting all the way down to low and none. I've lowered resolution to 1280x720. It improves performance, but only slightly.Slightly.My gosh, I mean seriously, there have been guys in forums stating that their rigs can run CRYSIS 1 and 2 fully maximized everything, and this game makes their gaming rigs cry uncle.What gives?I have one last trick that I can try. I will install this in my SSD hard drive. Hopefully it will make this game run silky smooth. But I'm not confident, as I have played another port (ENSLAVED: Odyssey to the West) in my SSD and I had cutscene loading problems.I guess its true, what they say - ports from consoles suck eggs 95% of the time.I want to like this game. Seriously, I do. I'm even willing to do the research in the wikis necessary to be able to play it the smart way. Its just dumbed down by technical reasons. Too bad.UPDATE: Keep ALL video and graphics settings to DEFAULT VALUES and it should run silky smooth. With this info, I change my recommendation from NOT Recommended to Recommended.Wooohooo!!!! Time to enjoy some Japanese RPG!

												If Final Fantasy XII was a franchise, then The Last Remnant would be Final Fantasy XII-2. Both produced by Akitoshi Kawazu, TLR shares a lot in common with FF XII: a fantastic medieval fantasy world, grind-heavy battle system which feels very rewarding for those who like it, a bland main character, and totally amazing soundtrack! The Last Remnant suffers from some graphic issues and a forgettable story, but where it shines, it truly shines. For you who like Final Fantasy, or generally a fantasy JRPG with good turn-based battle system, deep tactics and customization, and great music, The Last Remnant might just be the right game for you.And hey, it's pretty cheap now.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												Yes, buy and play this game. It goes on sale frequently. You can choose to quickly play through just the main plot or go for a very long, full completion.While I doubt that it was their intention to write their main character as so annoying as to drag the whole quality of the game down, I feel like the real complaint from detractors of this game is that the main character isn't socially normalized enough. I've met several people like the main character, though: loud, don't think deeply, altruistic, and self-censoring (re: "Let's kick some A!"). I'd rather sit through an awkward character's screen time in the context of an engaging story than have a really targeted and over-designed main character whose only flaw is that they're too awesome for the world they exist in (ugh, it must be so hard for them).This game has a story that takes you through individual character storylines with quests that help provide cohesion if you let it, but, and this is the uniquely good part, you have the option to skip all of that. Just like you have the option to skip tactics and decision-making in combat, even going so far as to publicly write it off as wholly random or even just containing "too much" randomness. With the exception of the scenario of "I want to choose exactly what every unit of every union in my army does at every moment", other players' experience (first-hand knowledge of how the game's mechanics work together) demonstrates that there is actually a level of control you can achieve that approaches that but ultimately settles on a medium somewhere between the micro-managerial staple of other RPG games and no control. For me, I don't like the part of old-school RPGs where it's basically button mashing through a ton of menus with no risk of losing a fight. I like this game's system so much better because it only ever approaches that if you're fighting enemies that you seriously out-rank, and the game does a great job of providing difficult areas (an unlockable tiered end-game area) and monsters (they scale up).Furthermore, the main character being annoying has no bearing on the unravelling of the Conqueror's plans (It wasn't about conquering anything. It was about liberating all remnants.), the development of Athlum's independence, the fantastic descent into greed-fueled madness of Duke Hermeien, and the tragic storyline of the Conqueror's Seven. And, that's only the content from the non-missable plot in this game. In the missable plot, you get to meet and redeem those seven characters from the tight grip of the Conqueror's mythology and power.Now, does the game fall into tons of stereotypical jRPG story elements (re: tropes)? Undeniably. It includes mechas (Hermeien), main character amnesia, direct replacement characters (Emma), an every-man with a super-power (Rush), parents who are completely out of the picture of their young children's lives, a bizarre sense of fashion that tries to differentiate major characters without building towards some larger narrative, and a mascot (re: Mr. Digg) who looks like nothing else in the whole game. Are they really out of place in this game, though? I don't think so. If Rush's Talisman made him transform into a Remnant Monster (reminiscent of something mechanized), I probably would have felt it crossed the line into tripe. Or, if Emma and Emmy's characters had zero difference (other than the name).The game's best moments for me were near the end of the game when you can hear the many different voices of your characters in battle modified by the barely positive morale of that battle, signifying that you're on par with your enemies, making you realize you've amassed and trained a small army of awesome companions.In conclusion, if an "Everyone's getting hyped!" is good and a "They caught us with our pants down!" is bad, then I give this game a grade of: "IRIIIIIIIIIIIINAAAAAAAAA!"

content:
Posted: October 17, 2011
												With not exactly zounds of jRPG style games out there for pc Square's Last Remnant is a welcome addition to the platform. Albeit cursed on release by console reviewers coz of fps problems the game runs smooth on almost any modern pc.As for the game itself, it will not be a let down. The story is what we have come to expect from jRPG-s - a bit silly but grand and reasonably told. But the bread and butter of the game is the battle. Infact the whole battle system is much more complex than lets say the one in Final Fantasy. Getting the right skills and synergies going definitely will be a challenge. Actually the games "general difficulty" is rather hard and will keep you on your seat the whole time. We would have wanted to see some grander summon animations/CGI but all in all what we have in the game is sufficient.Lovely graphics, decent control, ok story a bit lacking in voice acting and summoning grandness I'd rate this game 8/10.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2012
												EPIC COMBAT SYSTEM: you don't control just one party, you control several parties at once on a battlefied against multiple groups of enemies. Gone is the traditional micro of turn-based combat; instead you direct each group to focus on magic or combat techniques and which enemy groups to engage - and then watch as both forces charge towards each other, resulting in interceptions, flanking, and morale swings. Late-game, the respawning normal monster combats become tedious, but the boss battles only get more EPIC.Gorgeous visuals: I was once stuck on a quest wandering around a giant desert for 2hrs or so - and I didn't care, because the sand dunes in every direction just looked so pretty.Immersive storyline of the kind SquareEnix is known for. Every character has a story.The only thing I would gripe about is the expensive crafting system. At least your party members will just ask you for any components you have that they could use - you don't micro their equipment upgrades, either.

Altogether I would actually recommend this, as much as ports are usually lackluster at best. It runs great, plays well, and is a solid RPG.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2013
												kay...Im going to re-recommend this now that I have completely finished the game.Overall my thoughts..Its fairly decent and in ways i can see why people considered it an underrated RPG. It has a lot of highlights and from in somewhats I say it has the beginning elements of a battle style that is currently in final fantasy 13, only its heavily modified. Now to be fair, there are good things about this game and then there are some WTF moments because this kind of game..you don’t normally expect stuff like it.I shall try my best to not spoil any game play, but no promises..First off. This game is well worth the money and honestly, it is a game that, if you can get into it you can waste a good 80+ hours on. If I had spent my time maxing out my characters then I could of done this but I decided to go the casual route because it would take far too long for me to invest time into the characters.This game is also is about 13GB on your drive so expect a huge chunk gone when you install it. Not that size is a problem, it makes up greatly for its long story line as well as its ability to visually please those people who think graphics are a major concern. So yes, this isn’t FF7 style graphics or anything, its more on the lines of FF13 despite this game coming out before it.As for game play the over world is rather enjoyable. There are many animations that go on within the scenery depending on location and in someways it can make you sit there to watch the view. I do wish they added the option to take pictures because some areas of the game is very nice and worth looking into for projects or hell even a background on a PC.(yes i have done this.)Moving into the main aspects of the game, The lead character is..well..like most other RPG characters I see nowadays, being that hes slow, an idiot at times and makes you want to slap him through your monitor because hes so...eh..but more onto the game play, unlike most other console style RPGs you actually get a ton of characters to play with. You can have up to 50 max, 18 in battle, but there are restrictions.Battle mode is something you shall be in often as everything is centered around it. This game unlike other RPGs does not really have an minigames, but instead they give you a ton of side quests to do, however more on this later. Main point on the battle mode is that its entirely based on 1). your health 2). your morale and 3). luck.. So basically anyone with luckhax, you may enjoy this game greatly. Also just because the game was made in 2008 does not make it a bad game at all.One thing I loved (and will be downloading later) is the Soundtrack.. I found it rather addicting, especially when you are over-leveled in battle at times. The music keeps you active, pumped and ready for more fun as it keeps being dumped upon you time after time. If anything the most memorable thing would be the soundtrack in my opinion, but again it is just my opinion.Controller support for this game is fantastic. Not only that it naively supports the PC keyboard and mouse(not that I recommend) but it also supports third party controllers especially for big picture mode which is win. XINPUT is also supported so xbox controllers are available here as well.On a minor note. the game actually runs fine on Linux for you WINE users out there. Didn’t bother testing controller support, My controller was undetected with big picture mode but worked with every game, even games that are designed only for the xbox controller.Now, for the bad side of things.1. Grinding. You start off the game rather slow, and it seems easy at first but then your hit with enemies that are completely BS at times especially the bosses because they often get more than one turn and near the end of the game you actually have to watch out because they gain the ability to attack up to 10 times in a row killing you entirely. But yeah, grinding in this game

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3, 2011
												TLR feels like a classic Square RPG between the Final Fantasy 6 and 7 era; at least as far as story and world goes. Take a completely fantastical storyline, a slightly irritating yet identifiable character, a supporting cast of twisted backstories and unusual concepts, and throw in some menu-based face smashing with just enough strategy to keep you scratching your head. It's a game that's 50% story and 50% bursts of strategic challenge in the form of difficult boss fights.My only complaint is that, like any typical CRPG-like, the grind through the dungeons can get tiring, but the story is well worth it.The system is unique, favoring macro strategy over micro. Your control over your party is limited to who you attack and how, but the choice of which specific attacks, battle order, and timing comes down to the AI and stats. This sounds boring but is actually engaging and uniqueIn the end TLR feels like a lovechild of Tactics, Final Fantasy 6 and 7, and Ogre Battle. Not a bad thing.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2010
												Un excellent RPG des maitres du genre sur console Square Enix. Un produit rare sur PC, qui joint RPG et tactiques pour fournir de grand moment de plaisirs.Great J-RPG game by Square-Enix.The story got some nice elements - there also a few cliché and some of the usual plot twists - but the overall is great.The game has some tactical and stragegic choice as you not only lv up the member of your team, but you must chose which skill learn for each of them - the more you learn, the slower they progress, so the less action of that skill you learn.You need to chose for them their behavior (simple A/B/C choice when they grow their weapon) by improving their weapon - which require component to loot (mobs / reward / digging).But the most important part is the squadron. You have a limited number of characters to deploy on battle - and a maximum number of squad. Up to you to decide the number of character per squad (up to his maximum) as well as the squad formation and where the member are in each squad formation.As each formation have pro and cons, it's important to know when to use one.Plus you don't chose your squad action as you like. The actions avaible is a guidline determined by the computer depending on the squad Action point, his member skills, his HP/ buff / debuff (as well as the other's squad) and his position on the map compared to the friend / enemy squad.Add special "limit break" skill, pincer attack and a gestion of moral squad by squad as well as team by team affection your action and their succes, and battle can get quite interesting.Sadly, as most JRPG, you got a lot of grinding and hidden quest.The good point is : the hidden quest (who are often harder than the main quest, especially at the end of the game) are the only one really needing grinding and providing real hard fight. But they gave overpowering reward.All in all, if you like JRPG, don't miss it (it could do with an HD version by now, true)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
												The Last Remnant: The Salt BringerSeriously this game has made me so happy yet so mad, the sheer fact my old 360 and this PC have remained intact over the fruitless years of trying to conquer this game (With the physical strategy guide, mind you) is proof enough this game is worth playing.Synopsis:You start the game as Rush Sykes, who's sister, Irina, has been kidnapped. You venture off to lands unknown to find her, meet up with some people who think your parents (famous scientists btw) are amazing people. These new allies not only help you find your sister but eventually place you both on a gigiantic pedestal of world changing proportions, facing down enemies beyond that of a teenage boy who has yet to say a single curse above the occasional "damn." Also, character development, plot, twists of plot, and other RPG centric stuff occurs.Review:Yeah yeah, we get it. "The combat system is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t." Well, Square saw you wanted a "Final Fantasy"-Esque game without the convoluted self-serving plot, and a new combat system, and you very well F!^&#!%! got it. Yes, it's randomized based on your weapons, party members, remnants, etc. But it adds a new difficulty to the game that all you weeaboos and achievement whoores have yet to appreciate. As an RPG fan, and even as a FF fan, this combat system makes me rage, quite a bit honestly. But, when you finally beat that one spot, the one you've been stuck at for ages, it's like a long awaited ♥♥♥♥♥♥. It is just fulfilling and makes you dizzy with delight... then you find another boss immediately after who wrecks your♥♥♥♥♥♥and sets you back to square one.Now you may ask; "well if that's how you feel, why reccommend it you masochistic prick?" Because it's difficult, because it's a mixture of chaos and control that's amazingly frustrating and we all hate ourselves that much to force ourselves to commit to something that might give us a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ heart attack when you finally get to the end of the game, just to get your♥♥♥♥♥♥stomped in because your remnant never f!^@%#^! showed on the f!&#*@^ action wheels... <Insert Pant-Like breathing>.. Honestly, the story is actually quite phenominal if you're willing to murder yourself over it, the characters are well developed by the end and it's a difficult task to beat, but we all need relentless challenging. So go kick some "A." enjoy some of the frame drops (that can be quite hilarious at times) and most of all, find a way to kill Mr. Dig and his nightmare eyes.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 17, 2011
												With not exactly zounds of jRPG style games out there for pc Square's Last Remnant is a welcome addition to the platform. Albeit cursed on release by console reviewers coz of fps problems the game runs smooth on almost any modern pc.As for the game itself, it will not be a let down. The story is what we have come to expect from jRPG-s - a bit silly but grand and reasonably told. But the bread and butter of the game is the battle. Infact the whole battle system is much more complex than lets say the one in Final Fantasy. Getting the right skills and synergies going definitely will be a challenge. Actually the games "general difficulty" is rather hard and will keep you on your seat the whole time. We would have wanted to see some grander summon animations/CGI but all in all what we have in the game is sufficient.Lovely graphics, decent control, ok story a bit lacking in voice acting and summoning grandness I'd rate this game 8/10.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												This game is certainly one of the MOST UNDERATED games of all times. I first played it on Xbox 360, there were a lot of issues with textures and frame rate, I even lost control of my army once. But as a true warrior I continued to fight those issues and believe me it was well worth it. Even if I never got to complete the game (was stuck on the same boss for several months), it was already one of my all time favorite because of the combat system.And then, the PC version came out. They fixed most of the issues and mad the game a bit easier, but still hard as hell for people who are new to this kind of combat and leveling system. I was able to complete the PC version thanks to those changes and thanks to my prior knowledge of the game. If you like challenging combats and managing multiple squads against enemies that are at least as strong as you, this game is for you.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												I'll start with the cons: the protagonist is a whiny kid who I couldn't care less about, the characters are almost all cookie-cutter with almost every action they make utterly predictable and the story unfolds so slowly and makes so little sense that I stopped even trying to follow it and just fell into a "so they want me to go here" mentality...Now having said that the pros:The gameplay is excellent and it's a lot of fun. The reason I had so much trouble following the story is that I'd spend a 1/2 hour on a story mission and then 20 hours doing other things. Training skills and upgrading weapons is an almost never ending task and you can lose yourself in it... I eventually had to tell myself enough and force myself to carry on the storyline. Equally you can lose yourself in the intricacies of so many aspects of the game. Weapon choice, formation, which characters to take and what squads to put them in: there are so many options with so many equally good choices. Many games claim to give you the option of how to win, this one really delivers.My view of this game is that the developers put great effort into the innovative gameplay and astonishing depth of detail of the mechanics but almost none into the characters themselves or the story which impressively manages to be both utterly boring and overcomplicated/confusing. It has the feel of a game developed by a statistician: all numbers and no heart. That said it's still a lot of fun and I recommend it to anyone who enjoys RPGs but, if you are like me, you'll probably find yourself getting angry that this is only a 'good' game and not the 'great' game it could so easily have been.[rant]Now to let off some steam:David- the protagonist that never was.  He's cool, already got good reasons to be fighting without needing to insert cookie-cutter motivations and would have been an original choice: the little-boy-lost character is common, the subornative-lord fighting to regain his kingdon's independence from a benevolent neighbour is totally unique in my experience.Torgal- the 'tall dark stranger'. His story also happens to be far more interesting then anything Rush gets up to... Khrynia- OMG WTF. Anyone who doesn't know what that means will hate her with a passion, anyone who knows but doesn't speak them as acronyms will hate her with a passion and anyone who does will rightly feel that she's an insult taking the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of them and will hate her with a passion. Which is a shame because, other then being the irritational equal of young Anakin Skywalker, she's actually quite interesting.Bristly Dragon Mane- proof that someone is a serious sadist. I had about 6 characters need this component and each one needed 6-12 of them... so that's about 50 BDMs in total. At 15% drop chance that means I would need to defeat 333 dragons. Even reloading before a dragon fight until you get the desired result it's going to take a huge amount of time to get what you need. Surely all those respawnable rare monsters dropping rare cores could have been put to a purpose rather then this inane dragon massacre...Accessories- such an enormous choice of accessories, with so many great options all doing slightly different things helping you tailor your 1 character to his goals... the other 17 you control are just gonna do their own thing and occaisonal borrow something you have, if you're lucky. Surely something like Skyrim could have been used: giving allies equipment that they can choose to use if they feel it is beneficial but no, you might have 10 immense accessories sitting doing nothing in your inventory and the chances are you'll only be able to give away 2-3 to your allies.... ARRGGHHBattle Menu- there isn't one... there is no way to exit the game once you start a battle except by finishing it, either by winning or losing. If you are called away or run out of time you'll need to CTRL+ALT+DELETE, if you've bitten off more then you can chew CTRL+ALT+DELETE, if you've been unlucky and something has happened you can't recover from CTRL+ALT+DELETE.... A really good game doesn't allow you to realize you are going to lose then prolong it for the next 5 minutes as you see all your allies die slowly... and .... inexorably ... bringing... you ... to ... GAME OVERI could keep going but I think that'll do for now[/rant]

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												Having just finished it, I can say this game is interesting. Instead of playing with a party, you end up building a small army to fight. It has some peculiar ideas, but not the best execution of them in my opinion, gets very repetitive if you are going for completion. It is still a good jRPG, though far from contender to the best titles out there. I would give it a 3.5/5.Some of the members of your army make no sense being there, and there is very little story when optional team members are concerned. Speaking of story, it makes a bit of a jump here and there, and it is not the greatest at making sense. I did find it enjoyable enough to make me sit through to the end still, though you will need to ignore a plot hole here and there eventually.Most of the content you can see as artificial padding, in the form of the guild tasks, that make you reenter already done dungeons many, many times to find a specific random mob, hated those, and the upgrade system not allowing you to downright give items to your teammates required to upgrade their weapons, so you had to go back and farm them again and again if you care about your teams progression, very annoying. If you don't care, get ready to be pestered about it, because your team asks you for the things they need, over and over and over again, every time you go back to the world map you spend 5 minutes just skipping the dialogs of them asking.The battle system is a nice change from normal jRPGs. You don't directly control your characters, you organize them in units, and then give the unit a general purpose, like "use mystic arts". Then, some of the unit member may use a magic, while others will just regular hit, and it is random who will do what, you can train them in different classes to increase the likelihood they will do what you want, but it is no guarantee. Also, even random battles are challenging, since after each one your party automatically recovers, so there is no excuse to not go all out. The bad side is that the toughest battles end up relying too much on RNG to win.Instead of levels, you have a battle rating, and this is one of the bad things about the game. They give you a general battle rating, and enemies scale according to it, but each one of your characters has a BR as well, and they do not tell you what it is. Some stats are hidden like skill progression, and class changes possible and requirements, and some stuff that appear in old towns that makes you either have to use a guide to know of, or visit everywhere after each story step which is annoying and takes quite a bit.Also you have no control over your teams skills, and sometimes they make the worst possible decisions when leveling up. For instance, I read a lot about this skill called "Cachexia" and how it is essential to kill the optional bosses, and although I had 9 members of my 18 member army capable of learning it, and with magic of it's level, just one of them chose to learn it, and only while doing the dungeon that leads to the final boss. I did grind quite a bit trying to get it, but after failing to do so I ended up having to do everything without it, making it all a lot harder.Overall, I would say get this game during a sale and it is worth it, and give it a play, if only to check it's battle system in the very least, or try to do a quick story playthrough ignoring most sidequests. Don't get too much into micro managing though, or you will need to spend a lot of time on the wiki to try to do things right.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												10/10This is one of the best games i played in last 10 years. Innovative and fun battle system, nice FF type story, interesting characters and most important of all, not easy. If u just wanna finish the game without getting achievements and doing all optional stuff ( like getting  all characters u want and upgrading weapons to the max and killing all the optional bosses) game is pretty challenging.If u want to finish game 100% u will need around 200 hours and u will need patience, luck, hardwork, nerves of steel and most importantly walkthrough. That is perhaps only bad side of this game.No learning curve and gazilion of things and quests that are missable. And if u miss them and finish disc 2 u will not be able to obtain best weapons or even be able to access some optional  areas with strongest monsters and best drops on disc 4.If u truly wish to play this game to its full potential u should read guides that will explain what to do and what not to do and how to do it. For example, when u start game, the game  explain u how to chain monsters and   benefits of chaining, what it doesnt say to u is that by doing that u lvl fast but your stats dont increase as fast as your lvl. And in this game monsters u encounter are scaled to your lvl.So basicly u end up with lvl 50 characters who are weaker than lvl 30 character of someone who didnt chain. I had few of my friends quit this game, because they chained a lot and after  some time they  couldnt even kill normal monsters let alone bosses. In short great game, read guides, dont chain monsters and even if u despise guides and walkthrough at least read  list of things that u shouldnt miss before advancing to disc 3 ( i think )
