Instead of single units (sending a lone unit out into a fight becomes and obviously poor idea), you have a "Union", a group of units you have mixed together to suplement each other's strengths and weaknesses. Level grinding is HIGHLY recommended, and so-called "side-quests" become a necessity if you want any kind of gear that will stand up to the main story's OVERPOWERED bosses.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2013
												From the team that brought you the SaGa series comes this tactical JRPG with more than meets the eye. Technical hurdles from the 360 version are not apparent in the PC release (other than occasional texture pop-in) And I experienced screen tearing, and with no ingame v-sync option, I had to turn on v-sync via my Nvidia control panel.Whilst this game isn't for everyone, those that fall in love with it appreciate its deep micromanagement, lengthy battles and challenging bosses. Artstyle reminds me of Final Fantasy XII and the lengthy side quests and atmosphere remind me of Final Fantasy XI.A stellar soundtrack too, brilliantly composed.100+ hours of content. And exploring and unraveling its mysteries can be deeply satisfying... if you're able to put in the time.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Pretty damn nice game. This gem didn't get the marketing you'd expect from most SE games, so it flew under the radar with a lot of people. But this gem has a fabulous story. Game mechanics are in part hidden, meaning there's actually a lot of different factors that influence your battles which are either never explained, never shown, or both. You'd think this to be a deal-breaker, but it isn't. It's still fairly easy to understand combat and get through the game, without fully understanding all of it. Understanding simply gives you the freedom to really tailor your strategies to your preference.But the one main point is most definitely the story, which is very good! Definitely worth playing once, quite enjoyable playing three times.The game was made with english voice acting in mind, so picking english will have the sync with the mouths down just right.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												I put quite a bit of time into this game(Circa 2009) trying to upgrade all characters I was using in my party before finally beating the game. Alot of times this game seems at odds with itself, leveling can cause issues due to the game attempting to rectify ease of difficulty that can arise from overleveling, but I was overleveling from the constant grind, attempting to get certain rare creatures to spawn in certain zones for equipment upgrades. I wish there was a follow up game with more polish. I was one of the fortunate souls who did not attempt to play this on the Xbox 360, and opted for the PC version which apparently was in a better state upon its release. The game is not without its bugs, and issues with settings as framerates go bonkers without any reason. The gameplay is rare in which you have teams of characters who work together to fight the enemy. Sometimes this system worked out, sometimes it became muddled with confusion. I would liken it to something similar to Bahamut Lagoon on the SNES which I recommend people play if they enjoyed this game. Although BL leans towards strategy games of the time. There are some areas where a fight essentially relies on trying it over and over and getting by purely on luck. These certain events were a letdown in many cases. There were alot of very poor rpgs being made at the time of this games debut and in general during its console generation, and it was a breath of fresh air in its attempt to add something to a genre dying from lackluster gameplay, visuals, and repetition, Hopefully we will see a game soon, likened as a spiritual successor or inspired by it.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2013
												I've been a fan of the Final Fantasy series for years (specially III and VII). Although it's not Final Fantasy, The Lst Remnant is a pretty good jrpg. The story is great, the graphics and animations beautiful. I found it kind of clumsy without a controller (movement "wasd" and mouse, action battle triggers arrows, etc.). With a XBox 360 Controller the game is really very playable and easy to learn. The combat system is excellent and hard to master. The only thing I would pehaps change in the game is the ability to handle the equipment of your party (you can only control the equipment of the main character). Instead of it, the party members ask you to go around the world to find specific materials or for some weapons you have not equiped.Bottom line. A must have for all jrpg game fans. It was worth every cent I spent on it.Graphics: 98%Music: 95%Voice act (Japanese): 100% <- It's well deservedPlayability: 86%Overall: 92%

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												I really like this game. This is an RPG game that does not have the regular leveling up system that most RPGs have. It instead has the Battle Point system that make's this games learning curve a little bit of steep. Pro:1. Diverse set of character's you can choose from2. Boss battle's are really difficult that the game forces you to think outside of the box and make's each battle exciting3. For an RPG, you don't need to think too much of stats allocation.4. The story is pretty good if you ask me. Cheesy. But good.Con:1. The protagonist is crazy and really difficult to like2. Repetitive monsters. The dev's were not creative enough to think of other monster's and creatures to fill the world. IMO3. Repetitive battles. 4. No love angle. The game hints on this but WTF, you can't pursue it. Oh, well.For it's current going price of $19, it's not a bad deal. I actually purchased this when it was on sale for $3 but believe me you will not waste that $19. Atleast if you like JRPGs like me.8/10

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Excellent game in my eyes, Though I wish I could have more control of my characters in combat. The auto commands are actually pretty well implemented, making the system it's own style rather than a burden to get around.  The Plot is interesting and you really feel like you're part of the world rather than the world being tailored for your exploration.  Alongside that, you have a say in how you want to structure your character based on what skills you use.The customization of this game really shines in creating unions.  Not only can you structure your own parties, but you can also hire other characters to fill in the ranks for when story characters enter and leave throughout the game.My only nitpicks are I wish I could control each unit in a union directly, but that's nitpicking, andthat they had a bestiary to see where to farm drops, also nitpicking.  In all, I'd give the game an 8.5/10

content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												Yes, buy and play this game. It goes on sale frequently. You can choose to quickly play through just the main plot or go for a very long, full completion.While I doubt that it was their intention to write their main character as so annoying as to drag the whole quality of the game down, I feel like the real complaint from detractors of this game is that the main character isn't socially normalized enough. I've met several people like the main character, though: loud, don't think deeply, altruistic, and self-censoring (re: "Let's kick some A!"). I'd rather sit through an awkward character's screen time in the context of an engaging story than have a really targeted and over-designed main character whose only flaw is that they're too awesome for the world they exist in (ugh, it must be so hard for them).This game has a story that takes you through individual character storylines with quests that help provide cohesion if you let it, but, and this is the uniquely good part, you have the option to skip all of that. Just like you have the option to skip tactics and decision-making in combat, even going so far as to publicly write it off as wholly random or even just containing "too much" randomness. With the exception of the scenario of "I want to choose exactly what every unit of every union in my army does at every moment", other players' experience (first-hand knowledge of how the game's mechanics work together) demonstrates that there is actually a level of control you can achieve that approaches that but ultimately settles on a medium somewhere between the micro-managerial staple of other RPG games and no control. For me, I don't like the part of old-school RPGs where it's basically button mashing through a ton of menus with no risk of losing a fight. I like this game's system so much better because it only ever approaches that if you're fighting enemies that you seriously out-rank, and the game does a great job of providing difficult areas (an unlockable tiered end-game area) and monsters (they scale up).Furthermore, the main character being annoying has no bearing on the unravelling of the Conqueror's plans (It wasn't about conquering anything. It was about liberating all remnants.), the development of Athlum's independence, the fantastic descent into greed-fueled madness of Duke Hermeien, and the tragic storyline of the Conqueror's Seven. And, that's only the content from the non-missable plot in this game. In the missable plot, you get to meet and redeem those seven characters from the tight grip of the Conqueror's mythology and power.Now, does the game fall into tons of stereotypical jRPG story elements (re: tropes)? Undeniably. It includes mechas (Hermeien), main character amnesia, direct replacement characters (Emma), an every-man with a super-power (Rush), parents who are completely out of the picture of their young children's lives, a bizarre sense of fashion that tries to differentiate major characters without building towards some larger narrative, and a mascot (re: Mr. Digg) who looks like nothing else in the whole game. Are they really out of place in this game, though? I don't think so. If Rush's Talisman made him transform into a Remnant Monster (reminiscent of something mechanized), I probably would have felt it crossed the line into tripe. Or, if Emma and Emmy's characters had zero difference (other than the name).The game's best moments for me were near the end of the game when you can hear the many different voices of your characters in battle modified by the barely positive morale of that battle, signifying that you're on par with your enemies, making you realize you've amassed and trained a small army of awesome companions.In conclusion, if an "Everyone's getting hyped!" is good and a "They caught us with our pants down!" is bad, then I give this game a grade of: "IRIIIIIIIIIIIINAAAAAAAAA!"

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Absolutely amazing game! The art style is almost a complete replica of the art style of Final Fantasy 12. Although the way you can avoid battling monsters in the game is similar to FF12, the combat system once in  battle is entirely different. Even if you buff up a single character's damage as much as possible, you can still be royally beaten to death. Strategy is a must in the battles. Flanking systems, methods of offense instead of straight skills, and random during-attack extra damage inducing button input all are brought to this new game. Spent 12 straight hours playing it for the first time. Although the combat system is a bit confusing at first, you figure it out relatively quickly over the countless battles you'll be put into. 100% worth the buy and play.

												9.4/10So... I have played this game when it was on the Xbox 360 and one major improvement is that now you have a new game plus available after the battle with the last boss. over all this is an absolute blast tons of replay value and the price is amazing. if you like RPG that are a bit out of the ordinary battle systems and some what of an open world theme you will love this game. if you have not played this game I strongly recommend this game. the reason for the above rating is while this is a great game there are some.....issues. I would understand the change in orders if unions stayed healed and what not. Graphics could use some work/ touch ups. Character hair, armor, things of that nature.still overall give this game a try.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												A lot of fresh and unique RPG elements, and super-complex mechanics (so complex, in fact, that you won't understand even half of them unless you consult the wiki). Overall, it feels extremely ahead of its time, and a great reference for Tactical RPG lovers.I thoroughly enjoyed this game, and it's a shame that the tactical combat system wasn't used by Square Enix for any other games since. Would love to see something similar in the future.Although the extra content becomes very repetitive after a while, the main story is quite interesting and the setting / mythos is compelling.Absolutely recommended.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												I have no idea how to describe the game as a whole, but here are some things that I like and dislike about this game.Pros:- THE BATTLE SYSTEM!-Interesting characters along with a story and personality for alot of them.-A near infinite amount of strategic customization/elements (unions, arts, equips, characters)-Enemies! Lots and lots of enemies! (Rare ones too!)-The graphics! (They're all sparkly)-You can summon bosses during battles-Bosses are not just your typical 4 vs 1 beat-em-ups but are basically an army vs an army.-Side-quests!Cons:-A near infinite amount of customization (When you get alot of members, they're always bugging you for stuff)-Mountains upon mountains of materials.-The learning curve (However there are wikis and guides out there to help with the basics)-A main character that doesn't think :/I highly recommend this game, because while it does have its good sides and bad it is not a game to miss out on. The battle system is one of the most interesting mechanics I've ever seen in RPGs and the pros more than make up for some of the faults of the game (which is mostly the learning curve).Score:french toast / 5

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												A new (relatively) classic of JSRPG's, The Last Remnant has all of the aspects a good Squenix strategy game should have.The combat is easy to learn and rewarding when mastered. Some people may have some issues at first if they haven't been paying attention, or are mashing a single command for an entire battle, but along with the customization for weapons and skill progression system, it makes combat a worthy endeavor in any case. The story is good as far as I've seen, the protagonist is kind of.. well typical, but typical of many RPG's you just have to enjoy the ride through the main story and enjoy the world around it. Solid 7/10, worth trying, enjoyable new take on turn-based combat from a favorite studio.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												This game is unique among it's genre. Not only does it stand out with the number of people that take part in one active battle, it scales enemies based on a BR system, instead of a level system. BR is kind of like your overall level for everything you have accomplished, so like your basic skill level for the game. Instead of scaling of stats, it scales of player's skill, in a way. It has a great story and will take you on an adventure. The only thing I didn't like, was the english voice acting. It was subpar. The Japanese was decent, but the translations came off as corny most of the time. There is many side quests that are extremly hard as well as the difficutly jump for the last boss on the main story.

												Pros: The storyline is great and solid. Definetly something you would expect from a Square Enix game. I could play this game for hours due to the interesting storyline. Cons: The gameplay seems to be missing something. At times I have no idea what is going on and sliently hope that I am not losing. This game causes my laptop to overheat and crash, even with a fan underneath. Though, this may be due to my laptop being older (HP Pavilion 6).  So players with "older" PCs may need to take precautions (fans, running limited processes, decrease brightness, etc). Word to the wise: Use a controller for this game (either an XBox or PS3).It might take a little time to set up, but will save you a major headache later. The controls are set up for consoles (for which it originated from) rather than the PC.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												The Last Remnant is definitely an interesting game; innovative battle style that I have never seen before, making gameplay actually quite fun.  I don't have a whole lot to say that others haven't said better, but this is what I think:Pros:- Rush's cheesy lines cracked me up.  It was like... well the writers were trying to be cool so he uses a lot of slang that cracked me up.  - While this was no Final Fantasy, the character detail and graphics are great.  I love a game where you can look closely at a character and see their clothes in great detail.  - Battle is fun, and when you are not having a super tough time you can watch a movie, or read a book while you are waiting for the battle to get over.- Voice acting was pretty goodCons:- Without a controller, playing on a keyboard is terrible.  You can absolutely tell that this game was originally made for the 360.  - Story is a bit basic, though admittedly not a huge turnoff for me.- I am not 100% sure that rare enemies return once you see them.  This kind of sucks, because they often tear me a new one, and I have to get experience before I come back to play.  - Some of the game functions are very dynamic, but they are also very confusing.  All in all, I really like this game.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2013
												A refreshing change in gameplay. Although the game does start slow and somewhat hard, it progresses to be on a perfect pace on gameplay with the story progressing on an equal scale, making for a perfect blend of a gaming experience. The gameplay mechanics is based off of randomly generated moves based on what you already know, and is changed based upon who you target. Your playable characters are grouped into parties that will be affected in different ways depending on who is in it. What affects the group? In general, the type of combat preference your characters have, the formation you have the group in (You'll see soon enough in the game once you can recruit multiple members into your parties), and finally how many people are in a party. You can have multiple parties.Speaking of the story specifically, it is well written, but is by no means a master piece, but as I had said, the story the game brings is fulfulling and is more than enough to please you.Gameplay specifically, as I had previously mentioned, this game starts out slow and somewhat hard. Grinding is not exactly mandatory in this game, but is somewhat appreciated if you refuse to fight boss battles over and over. The game really wants boss battles in this game to live up to it's name. And in the beginning of the game, boss battles are excepionally harder than most fights you will encounter.Also, a REALLY IMPORTANT note to make, all boss battles are preceded by a cutscene of varying length, usually more than a minute or more in length. This is important to mention because CUTSCENES ARE UNSKIPPABLE, meaning that if you fail a boss battle, you will have to suffer watching the same cutscene over and over. Hence, grinding is somewhat a real recommendation early on in the game. If you are finding yourself in this loop of a boss battle failing, I reccomend going back and grinding a level or two and consider upgrading your equipment and changing your parties' formations. Also, shift tab is reccomended if you can't stand the cutscenes. This is probably the only problem you will have with this game.^Tl;dr: Grind if you hate time passing you by without making progress.Also, another note worth mentioning is that this game has a New Game+, which means that after you beat the game, you can play through it again retaining all your arts you learned as well as components you use to make items in the game.Although if you plan to play New Game+, you should SPLIT ALL UNNEEDED ITEMS before the final boss. You lose everything in material things but components, you even lose your gold. *Any gold you get in New Game+'s start is based on how many quests you did. Although, a perfect thing to be mentioned is that this game might not be for everyone. But with everything in mind, this game is by all means a decent thing to buy, especially consideing its low cost on steam.*Can skip cutscenes with an xbox controller, onlyAlso, a note worth mentioning, this game is fully xbox controller compatible, and the game is automatically set to think you are playing with an xbox controller. Change the controls first thing you get into the game, unless you want to be forced to by invonvenience^^^^^^^^^ TL;DR: I RECCOMEND THIS GAME, GRIND IF HARD. GAME IS STILL GOOD.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2012
												JRPGs were a holy grail of console gaming in the 8 and 16 bit days. In the 32, there were classics of the genre like Eternal Arcadia, Sakura Wars and Grandia II. Oh, no Final Fantasy? Haven't played once since the Sony monopoly began, which was why this, as one of Square-Enix's cross platform (initially Xbox 360 exclusive) JRPGs was so enticing. I longed to see what they had in store for me. HIronobu Sakaguchi was gone, but I had Lost Odyssey and Blue Dragon, both excellent if not old fashioned games. Sadly, Last Remnant (Last? What is it about JRPGs from this pedigree exhausting the same thesaurus entry?) ran terribly on console. It's release on PC has greatly alleviated these problems, but alas, something about the game leaves me cold. It plays great and has a unique combat and character system, yet ,,, the last remnant of what I onced loved about the genre has dried up. Next stop, Xenoblade and Last Story (there we go again!) for Wii. Here I come.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2013
												This game is SquareJP's finest work this generation. The story, whilst being somewhat generic is a shining example of how you take a generic concept and make it more than that. In this game, you do not control a few singular characters, instead you have 'unions' which you form with a key character acting as a general so to speak, with bodyguards and special units in the union. You can have several unions depending on your battle level which allows for some jaw dropping gigantic battles against hostile unions. The traditional japanese roleplaying elements are heavily modified, with RTS style tactics of engaging and 'deadlocking' enemies in a close combat fight whilst your other unions move around to flank them or intercept enemies who are trying to flank your unions whilst they are in a deadlock. All of this is controlled with a sleek, stylish interface and battle controls identical to a traditional JRPG and is very easy to use whilst having respectable depth. If you think that the game is an actual RTS in the way it handles, and are put off by it, don't be because it isn't. This is a fantastic example of how you can merge two genres together whilst catering to everybodies tastes.At £7.99, this game is more than worth it, and is a no brainer in a sale. I'm not even a huge JRPG fan at all, and other than Final Fantasy 4, 7, 13 and Lost Odyssey, I have never played any other ones and I have to say this one is easily the best. If like me you were left with a sour taste in your mouth after the latest, awful Final Fantasy games, The Last Remnant is a breath of fresh air, a fantastic new IP and proof that Square have not lost their touch.9/10

content:
Posted: September 2, 2013
												The Last Remnant is a fantastic game. I have spent over 60 hours playing it (my profile may say 40 but I've spent some time playing offline). If you like strategic but fast combat, this could be the game for you. There are tons of sidequests that give meaningful and useful rewards and many different characters that you can use in combat. For a JRPG, the story is not very strong, however it does have some interesting concepts.The game can be complicated at times, with complex character progression as well as difficult concepts such as battle formations, but once you gain an understanding of these concepts the game can be very engaging. The Last Remnant Wiki will also help a lot.Overall I'd give this an 9-9.5 out of 10. The game is very addictive and has great graphics (for its time) and good voice acting for the most part, but I believe you can choose to listen to Japanese voices if you like. An Xbox controller is highly recommended for this game, but not required.Anyway, I obviously really like this game if you couldn't already tell from how much I've written about it. I've enjoyed all 60 hours of my game time and I bet you would too!

content:
Posted: November 19, 2013
												For being pretty much the only actual full console JRPG that got moved onto PC, it's pretty good. It's definitely a love or hate game, but there's a reason for that. It's graphically impressive still for a game that released in 2008/9, offers really fun combat and pre-battle strategy.The Last Remnant is unnecessarily complex. If you attempt to play through this game normally, even reading all hints, tips, and tutorials the game gives you, you will never fully learn or understand the battle system. It's a really cool battle system, in fact my favorite turn-based combat system, incorporating a little (dumb) use of RNG. This should be a fatal flaw of the game design by not telling you all the basics of a JRPG game, but it's fun if you figure it out. I had to reinstall and try this game three times before it clicked.Things you should know before considering playing this game:1: This is the Dwarf Fortress of JRPG's in complexity so you will probably need to read the whole game wiki to FULLY understand and prepare your unions/parties/units2: If you are too low of a battle rank, the game is hard. If you are too high of a battle rank, the game is hard. If you grind, you will get punished. Basically, if you reach a point where a battle is super hard, you've either ♥♥♥♥ed up or you're just not high enough level. The game doesn't give you a clear idea of which it is.  By "grinding", I mean heading to an open field with monsters and clearing it all out just for the sake of grinding. If you're on your way to an objective or on a quest, do fight.3: If you HAVE to battle, DO NOT BATTLE A SINGLE MOB AT A TIME. Battle Rank raises depending on the amount of battles you have, not experience from battles. Try to get every single possible mob in one chained link, then initate the battle. If it's too hard with all those monsters, do one by one anyway.If you didn't read everything I typed above this line of text then do not play this game.TL;DR it's an extremely complex game that offers zero explanation of it's systems because there's no tutorial or visual presentation of information, but the high points are addictive and very fun.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
 An engaging game providing many hours of entertainment for those into strategy and JRPG The last remnant, while being a relatively old JRPG and slightly complicated understand, is a game that not only has a good story line with fairly well made cutscenes but provides that optimal amount of challenge as well as a non repitative way to grind in order to beat a challeging boss or complete a chapter of the story. Pros: - Good storyline- Well done up cutscenes- Fresh concept to rpg team building and combat- Many hours of gameplay- Good replayability(New Game +)- Good spread of characters allow for many hours of trial and error  Cons: - Xbox control based tutorials make it hard to learn to play at the start- Certain concepts like upgrading weapons for your team are extremely hard to understand- It can become really hard to find or farm for certain items towards the later half of the game- Some wrong decisions in game can really cost you 8/10 A good game that you will come to love after giving it a chance and reading some online guides.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												It's a fairly good game, entertaining enough so far. It seems to have fairly decent depth, the world seems moderately vibrant, the combat is complex (perhaps a tad much) and the animations and graphics are solid. There's two big gripes I have with this game, one being a lack of aesthetically impactful design in terms of music. The music is bland and barely memorable. Not much more to be said for it.The other gripe is that the game is a tremendously lazy port, to the point where all instructions show an Xbox controller button rather than a keyboard key. Rewriting the tutorials would've done wonders, but instead, players are forced to look up and perhaps even jot down all the important keys. This is particularly painful with the battle mechanism of critical calls, something akin to the action commands from Mario & Luigi and Paper Mario. The screen will show the A, B, Y and X buttons or the Right Trigger, and you're supposed to figure out what to press without any appropriate visual cue. (In case you're interested, it's the arrow keys for the A, B, Y and X buttons, and space bar for the Right Trigger)Other than that, the game seems rather promising and I hope it will continue to deliver.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												Wow, what an adventure.To get to the nitty gritty, let me focus on a couple of parts of the game: the battle system, the story, and the ending.The battle system:The battle system of this game is unique and definitely improved the game in my opinion. If you are unfamiliar, you have multiple squads under your commands that attack in sets. If you've played Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic, it is somewhat similar, but much more smoothly executed and on a much grander scale. The battles feel huge in certain cases, and it really adds to the experience in that it makes it feel like you're fighting a war right off the bat, rather than just skirmishes.10/10The story: The story was very engaging, and this characteristic is largely why I prefer RPGs to other types of games. Though it has a couple of predictable plot twists, the world is immersive. The side quests definitely add to the story and add to the immersive-ness of the world, as well as providing tangible advantages such as recruiting valuable characters and the acquisition of powerful weapons. There were a couple of problems, such as the ending feeling rushed, but I'll get into that in the next section.8/10The ending: The ending was absolutely the worst part of the game. I think it's odd to feature the ending as a part of the review, but I felt very strongly about it. This game can be split up into two fairly individual parts (to the point where one could have actually been a sequel). The second half of the game felt rushed compared to the first part. I felt like, where the story had a comfortable and reasonable progression in the first half, I felt like I was barrelling through the story when I went at the same pace for the second. At endgame, the game really just kind of feels like it skids to an emergency halt. The final boss is scaled in difficulty to the progression of your character, which is nice, and the final boss did take me a few tries, but when I did actually beat it, I was for some reason a little disappointed. The ending cutscenes did give me a feeling that I was finished, but the satisfaction wasn't really there. For the reasons that the ending was sort of abrupt, but well written, I give the ending a6/10Overall:I highly recommend this game, overall 8/10

Posted: July 9, 2014
												My reason for not recommending this game is technical - It is a bad port. It is not optimized for the PC.I have been to forums, trying out every suggestion to make the video and graphics better, as it should be since this is a 2009 game and my rig, though not the most powerful, still can hold its own.I have tried every graphics setting all the way down to low and none. I've lowered resolution to 1280x720. It improves performance, but only slightly.Slightly.My gosh, I mean seriously, there have been guys in forums stating that their rigs can run CRYSIS 1 and 2 fully maximized everything, and this game makes their gaming rigs cry uncle.What gives?I have one last trick that I can try. I will install this in my SSD hard drive. Hopefully it will make this game run silky smooth. But I'm not confident, as I have played another port (ENSLAVED: Odyssey to the West) in my SSD and I had cutscene loading problems.I guess its true, what they say - ports from consoles suck eggs 95% of the time.I want to like this game. Seriously, I do. I'm even willing to do the research in the wikis necessary to be able to play it the smart way. Its just dumbed down by technical reasons. Too bad.UPDATE: Keep ALL video and graphics settings to DEFAULT VALUES and it should run silky smooth. With this info, I change my recommendation from NOT Recommended to Recommended.Wooohooo!!!! Time to enjoy some Japanese RPG!

content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												If Final Fantasy XII was a franchise, then The Last Remnant would be Final Fantasy XII-2. Both produced by Akitoshi Kawazu, TLR shares a lot in common with FF XII: a fantastic medieval fantasy world, grind-heavy battle system which feels very rewarding for those who like it, a bland main character, and totally amazing soundtrack! The Last Remnant suffers from some graphic issues and a forgettable story, but where it shines, it truly shines. For you who like Final Fantasy, or generally a fantasy JRPG with good turn-based battle system, deep tactics and customization, and great music, The Last Remnant might just be the right game for you.And hey, it's pretty cheap now.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												I put quite a bit of time into this game(Circa 2009) trying to upgrade all characters I was using in my party before finally beating the game. Alot of times this game seems at odds with itself, leveling can cause issues due to the game attempting to rectify ease of difficulty that can arise from overleveling, but I was overleveling from the constant grind, attempting to get certain rare creatures to spawn in certain zones for equipment upgrades. I wish there was a follow up game with more polish. I was one of the fortunate souls who did not attempt to play this on the Xbox 360, and opted for the PC version which apparently was in a better state upon its release. The game is not without its bugs, and issues with settings as framerates go bonkers without any reason. The gameplay is rare in which you have teams of characters who work together to fight the enemy. Sometimes this system worked out, sometimes it became muddled with confusion. I would liken it to something similar to Bahamut Lagoon on the SNES which I recommend people play if they enjoyed this game. Although BL leans towards strategy games of the time. There are some areas where a fight essentially relies on trying it over and over and getting by purely on luck. These certain events were a letdown in many cases. There were alot of very poor rpgs being made at the time of this games debut and in general during its console generation, and it was a breath of fresh air in its attempt to add something to a genre dying from lackluster gameplay, visuals, and repetition, Hopefully we will see a game soon, likened as a spiritual successor or inspired by it.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												Since this is my first review of a game, please give me some leeway for a bit of naivety. It will happen, I'm sure, because I probably have bias towards or against some things in the game. Now to get on with the actual review.The Last Remnant is a game that I was skeptical about picking up at first. It happened to be on sale for $5, and I saw a few good reviews, so I decided to buy it, and I am so very glad I did. I love strategy games, and this turned out to be one of my favorite strategy games I had ever played, quickly knocking others down on my list.First, the story: in terms of details, it's pretty good; ideas, the same description; in fact, it has a rather unexpectedly in-depth story for what I expected, as of some of SE's games recently (I looked at a few; the story in each drove me away). It takes you into the world and explores the Remnants, which are mystical/magical objects that randomly appeared out of nowhere on the planet and, when bound, can be used as anything from a weapon to a tool and just about everything in-between. However, this is just a subsection of the story, which has (as far as I have played) covered politics, war, rogue elements, many details on the Remnants, scientific researchers, and i actually forgot the end of the list because there were enough parts that I ran out of attention span while typing this. It can be a bit wild in progression, as the story-based events occur only when you go to the right areas, but the quests and tasks (which are basically the normal "side quests" and "fulfill-and-reward" ideas) also add to the information on the world. A few quests even explore personal areas on certain characters, and each character that is involved in at least a side quest has been carefully built. I was very impressed by all of these details, and from what I have read, I'm not even halfway through the game.Next, the gameplay. Okay, so the first thing I'm going to say is this: there are way too many controls. Your battle controls, field controls, menu controls, and critical controls are many, and some of them overlap in weird ways. For instance, it appears that this game was set up to be used on controller, as you control sight/movement in the field with what is the keyboard equivalent of thumbsticks. Also, what you would think are the same controls in each area of the game are not. They may be bound to different things, i.e. camera movement controls in the field are camera/menu controls in battle (which, it is weird to move the menu and catch sight of your view moving in the same direction as your menu cursor) and a few other things. However, they are not impossible, and once you settle on a comfortable set for you, it doesn't take long before the controls seem natural, no matter how mixed up they seem at first. Now that I'm finished bugging out about that, let's move on to the rest of the gameplay. The Last Remnant uses a combat system that is unique in that I can't remember another game like it. I'm sure there was, but I'm at a loss to which it is. Anyways, you control unions (groups of fighters assembled before battle in preset positions) in a tactical battle setting, which is to say that although you take turns, where you wanted to go and what you wanted to do with each union may not happen. In the battle, unions move throughout the field and engage enemy unions in various forms. You also have to deal with morale, which increases and decreases according to your success in battle. I'll leave it to the game for an explanation, but suffice to say that it is an interesting fight, and no two engagements seem the same.Now, on to other details. The music is quite good; a heavy beat gets you pumped for a fight, and the music changes depending on morale during battles, which in my case either sent me on a murderous rampage or had me fighting desperately for my life. It grabs you and drags you into the fight like no other music I've heard before, similar to the way that the Final Fantasy series often did in the past (case in point: 4-7, at least in my opinion). The characters develop a lot more than I suspected they would. I thought they would be plain soldiers with backgrounds and a bit of development, but they also develop some of the characters you get from sidequests, giving them background information, personalities, and putting much  emotion into the way they act. I find that I absolutely hate to lose units in battle, not just because they are useful, but also due to the emotions and their personalities that have burnt themselves into my mind and heart, and losing one means I lost a friend in the game. When that happens, well, take how you would feel if someone KO'ed your friend with a punch to the face when you were right there with them and apply it to the situation. That's my personal twist on the characters in the game, and I don't care whether you think I'm insane or not (I am, by the way :} ).In conclusion, the story is pretty good, the music is epic, the battles are engaging, and the only cons you really have to deal with are the occasional slowdown at the start of a cutscene (due to high processing required and extreme details being applied, has occurred few enough times that I can count them on my hands) and the exceedingly rare random close out (happened a grand total of 3 times for me so far, two of them I'm pretty sure were because my computer was doing updates, the warning and the actual restart caused the game to close out). In my humble opinion, this game is 10/10. I love it, am addicted to it, and will never say otherwise. ^_^

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												The Last Remnant has been one of the few games which I can replay and experience it differently even though the story is the same (bar one set side quest options). I originally played this game on the Xbox 360 so I'm used to the game mechanics, however I have to play with a controller on this steam version as the controls for the keyboard are difficult in comparison as the buttons aren't as straight-forward. The game doesn't have steam achievements.Game: Overall, the plot of the game is pretty straight forward as you get reminded or can talk to NPCs to tell you what you need to do. After completing several story points, you are almost able to fully explore the world from near the start of the story, adventuring through the different areas and unlocking other towns. Some are mandatory for the story to progress but others are optional. Side quests pop up after most story events, so revisiting towns and cities are a must if you want to complete them all.Battle System:This is a hit or miss for everyone. I know plenty of people who dislike the battle system due to controlling a union of people but not being able to control each and every single unit. At first it is confusing as not many games use this style but after getting to grips with it, it is extremely useful and conserves time. Since it's a turn based game, imputting the attacks takes long enough to decide as unions so it's literally a godsend that we don't control each character exactly. The camera angles of the fighting keeps you involved in the fight as it follows those whose turn it is attacking/supporting/on standby. Another way this game involves you is by using a critical trigger. It requires you to press the button when the ring encloses over it. By doing so, not only do you bump up your allies in the turn system but also improve the critical chance of your attacks as well as a chance of synergising the last allies attack to a better one if you have enough Action Points(AP). Battles have frontal attacks (deadlocks), side attacks (flanks) and rear assaults which can give your parties edge in a battle but enemies also have the ability to do the same.Unions:You can choose who you want in your party by either completing their missions and buy there services in the guild or talking to one of the soldiers in Athlum (when you are given permission). Certain characters are required for side quests to appear. Unions are made up of a maximum of 5 units. These units/people are chosen by you and can be arranged in different formations to suit their opponents or roles before battle. Different formations have different abilities, strengths and weaknesses so it's fun to play about with what works best. Apart from your character/Rush Sykes, you aren't able to equip other units personally, if you have a weapon and they want it, they'll ask in the map screen if they can take it off your hands. However, they also ask for materials to improve their weapons as well so hunting items down is a good way to increase the strength of your parties. The stats in the game aren't really explained about, neither are class roles but are mostly straightforward apart from their trait stats.Skills: There are multiple arts which can be learnt such as combat, magicks, lotions etc. When learning specific ones, you are able to disable the use of other skills, enabling the one you want to learn more likely to pop up as an option in battle. I've seen a lot of people say the moves all look the same but I disagree with this. Sure, some have the same energy build up but the actual attack performed is different in some way.Visuals & Sound: Originally on the 360, my game was glitchy and laggy most the time. The steam version is much better, there are still glitches at times (like capes spinning about) but the smoothness of the animation at full visual capacity is quite good for a 2008 made game. The detail can take a few seconds to load in though. The voice acting for the game is okay, not the best voice acting but also not the worst. I'm a sucker for Square Enix soundtracks, so the music accompaning the game is quite beautiful and helps set the situation of the game. Within battle, the music can change depending on moral, turns or how close a union is to dying.Other notes: Sovani. Are. Awesome.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												I feel that TLR does not deserve its 65 metacritic rating. That being said, if you dislike JRPGs, this wont change your mind.The world is nice, the music is fantastic, the characters and story vary from laughable to pretty decent. My only real complaints are as follows;1) Upgrading your characters is wierd. You have no control over what they upgrade, so theyll take items they need after a battle, which sounds cool, but most of the time I would have 30 of the item they suddenly wanted. They should have made NPCs take that junk without having to have a mob drop it when they need it.Due to the wierd way you upgrade your characters, youll have to spend quite a bit of time farming drops, or at least I did. Luckily the combat system is great. The main problem with farming too much is; youre trying to upgrade your character, and the more you level the more difficult mobs become.The characters also harass you until you give them what they want, like a drug addict....you got any of that fly oil Rush.??. *sniff*2) Certain more rare items require magazines, which are dropped from doing guild quests, which arent tracked, so you have to make sure you know what youre doing before you go out. 3)  The max number of units is 18 in a group of 5 (5 per group) WHY in the world they made it 18 characters instead of 25 I cannot fathom. 4) You can miss quests simply because you progressed in the main story, that was just terrible!5) There is a late spike in difficulty. The game goes from a fun challenge to soul crushingly difficult at a certain point. My reviews are always super negative, I enjoyed the game, there are just some odd issues with it. Worth buying! (on sale)

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												The good: Interesting world and art direction, deep systems for upgrading/developing characters, lots of unique characters to recruit, an awesome battle system that lets you play out larger-scale fights, a large amount of sidequests that net meaningful rewards (like recruitable unique characters, or access to previously inaccessible areas of the map).The bad: The complexity of how things work makes it hard to grasp without external help. Also, the story is weak.Overall I'd recommend this game for people who enjoy turn-based JRPGs but want to try something different. The way this game plays is like nothing else I've tried and personally I enjoyed it a lot.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												Pretty damn nice game. This gem didn't get the marketing you'd expect from most SE games, so it flew under the radar with a lot of people. But this gem has a fabulous story. Game mechanics are in part hidden, meaning there's actually a lot of different factors that influence your battles which are either never explained, never shown, or both. You'd think this to be a deal-breaker, but it isn't. It's still fairly easy to understand combat and get through the game, without fully understanding all of it. Understanding simply gives you the freedom to really tailor your strategies to your preference.But the one main point is most definitely the story, which is very good! Definitely worth playing once, quite enjoyable playing three times.The game was made with english voice acting in mind, so picking english will have the sync with the mouths down just right.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												Spectacular game that keeps you engaged with a very interesting squad-based "rts/rpg" hybrid combat system. Great storyline to follow, great graphics, well executed cutscenes. Good sense of overwhelming power from opponents, unsurmountable odds faced and beaten. One thing I would have to make sure to mention to anyone who purchases this game and plays, check and DOUBLECHECK that the "autosave" feature is on in the options or you may end up losing a LOT of progress. It's not on by default. Would rate it about a 9/10.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												This game is a beautiful and ambitious tweak to the JRPG formula.  A compelling. interesting story, coupled with above average voice acting and an interesting battle system culminates in one hell of a good time.  It does have its weak points, including the obscure nature of how to find some items required for leveling and a general sense that the game isn't giving you all the stats required to make inform decisions.  However, all in all, The Last Remnant delivers a great experience.Oh, and when it gets a bit sloggy 3/4 the way in?  Just push on through because the rest of the story is one to hold out for.If you loved FF, Tactics, and strategy, I highly recommend the title.  Great game, wish we'd see a sequel.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2014
												What can I say about this game.It's a breathe of old school RPG goodness to those of us old enough to remember old school RPGs. The game is nice to look at, battles are enjoyable and challenging and the music is just beautiful.However it isn't for everyone. The game is challenging and the leveling system will put off most. The HARD mode lives up to it's name and is for none but the most hardcore. The Battle System is challenging to understand at first, fairly easy to get once you do understand while remaining difficult to completely master.But if you're looking for a good JRPG to while away the hours, this is a good choice.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												Wow, what an adventure.To get to the nitty gritty, let me focus on a couple of parts of the game: the battle system, the story, and the ending.The battle system:The battle system of this game is unique and definitely improved the game in my opinion. If you are unfamiliar, you have multiple squads under your commands that attack in sets. If you've played Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic, it is somewhat similar, but much more smoothly executed and on a much grander scale. The battles feel huge in certain cases, and it really adds to the experience in that it makes it feel like you're fighting a war right off the bat, rather than just skirmishes.10/10The story: The story was very engaging, and this characteristic is largely why I prefer RPGs to other types of games. Though it has a couple of predictable plot twists, the world is immersive. The side quests definitely add to the story and add to the immersive-ness of the world, as well as providing tangible advantages such as recruiting valuable characters and the acquisition of powerful weapons. There were a couple of problems, such as the ending feeling rushed, but I'll get into that in the next section.8/10The ending: The ending was absolutely the worst part of the game. I think it's odd to feature the ending as a part of the review, but I felt very strongly about it. This game can be split up into two fairly individual parts (to the point where one could have actually been a sequel). The second half of the game felt rushed compared to the first part. I felt like, where the story had a comfortable and reasonable progression in the first half, I felt like I was barrelling through the story when I went at the same pace for the second. At endgame, the game really just kind of feels like it skids to an emergency halt. The final boss is scaled in difficulty to the progression of your character, which is nice, and the final boss did take me a few tries, but when I did actually beat it, I was for some reason a little disappointed. The ending cutscenes did give me a feeling that I was finished, but the satisfaction wasn't really there. For the reasons that the ending was sort of abrupt, but well written, I give the ending a6/10Overall:I highly recommend this game, overall 8/10

content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												Very fun, but don't expect to grind your way to victory. Or understand... anything.The combat mechanics, the effect your abilities have, predicting just how much damage certain statistics will cause... who the hell knows? There is such a learning curve, you likely still will be unsure by the end of the game. Charcter suddenly doubles in power, because you forfilled a random hidden requirement for a random hidden skill? Yup, why not.  Been trying to level grind, only to find that it leveled up all the enemies in the game, plus gave them new equipment, while you are still flailing around with a toothpick? Guess you are in for some problems.I find the whole thing insanely fun, and I spend 80% of the game unsure as to what I am doing. I randomly find i've gained new special abilities, which will randomly 1-hit kill somthing one minute, and do virtually nothing the next. Charcters will automatically upgrade their items seemingly for giggles, although there is actually some bizzare formula at work. Apparently.And then there is the insanely un-predictable squad combat system/synergy bonuses. Just roll with it.Stupid fun. Just don't expect to 'get' it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2010
												Un excellent RPG des maitres du genre sur console Square Enix. Un produit rare sur PC, qui joint RPG et tactiques pour fournir de grand moment de plaisirs.Great J-RPG game by Square-Enix.The story got some nice elements - there also a few cliché and some of the usual plot twists - but the overall is great.The game has some tactical and stragegic choice as you not only lv up the member of your team, but you must chose which skill learn for each of them - the more you learn, the slower they progress, so the less action of that skill you learn.You need to chose for them their behavior (simple A/B/C choice when they grow their weapon) by improving their weapon - which require component to loot (mobs / reward / digging).But the most important part is the squadron. You have a limited number of characters to deploy on battle - and a maximum number of squad. Up to you to decide the number of character per squad (up to his maximum) as well as the squad formation and where the member are in each squad formation.As each formation have pro and cons, it's important to know when to use one.Plus you don't chose your squad action as you like. The actions avaible is a guidline determined by the computer depending on the squad Action point, his member skills, his HP/ buff / debuff (as well as the other's squad) and his position on the map compared to the friend / enemy squad.Add special "limit break" skill, pincer attack and a gestion of moral squad by squad as well as team by team affection your action and their succes, and battle can get quite interesting.Sadly, as most JRPG, you got a lot of grinding and hidden quest.The good point is : the hidden quest (who are often harder than the main quest, especially at the end of the game) are the only one really needing grinding and providing real hard fight. But they gave overpowering reward.All in all, if you like JRPG, don't miss it (it could do with an HD version by now, true)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2011
												This game is an amazing JRPG with a quite unique combat and leveling system, and it was released on PC in a time when there wasn't that many JRPGs on the platform. I haven't really put the hours into the PC version, did finish it will every achivement on the Xbox 360 back in the days. Graphics: Unreal engine makes this game look beutiful and the character models and monsters look real good, some enviroments look a bit "cheap" but a game thats now 7 years old it looks sweet.Story: A bit ditzy and hard to follow at times but it's pretty standard JRPG stuff in hereGameplay: I love it. Combat can get tedious but it's so fun to level your units the correct way and do all the side quests and such. Thats why I play JRPGs , for all the things around the main game :)Sound: Voiceacting on most important conversations and a lot of the voices are fitting for the characters. Sound effects and music is AAA qualityConclusion: 9/10 , one of the best JRPGs on PC. I'd even go so far to say this is better than FF 13 series.  If you see this in a sale and you like JRPGs, pick it up ASAP.

There is a lot of game play here though, and you progress from a small single party ot controlling several large parties in battle. There is also a lot of content for completist in this one as there are many items you can collect that require vast amounts of farming and loot stacking to get. (they aren't required to complete the game pretty much entirely optional)

												I've seen a lot of dislike for this game, but in my opinion it was a pretty fantastic game. The Last Remnant had a great story line, and a unique and interested battle system. The idea of squads instead of individual units is something that added the feel of actually controlling a small force instead of just a party of adventurers. Overall it was a lot of fun to play, even if the PC version was harder than the Xbox hard version.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												A game which the developers (Square-Enix) decided to experiment with not only a new engine, but also a revisioned combat system. The graphics are beautiful and detailed for the year it was released; however, the optimization of the game leaves much to be desired. Don't allow such a minor inconvenience deter oneself from playing this beautiful game: the story is both emotional  and deviant to the company's typical big, bad company/opposing mercanary force, the characters are quickly developed and are easy to identify with, and the amount of optional content will allow for longer retention.To summarize, if it's a somewhat challenging game that one seeks with a clever plot and intriguing characters to maintain interest, then this is the perfect game.(Also, the price is a steal)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Gameplay wise this is honestly my all time favorite JRPG. The game gives you control of up 18 characters at a time from a pool of hundreds, most of which have their own unique story line and a quest associated to them. Every character develops in their own way and loosely follow a unique leveling tree. However probably the best thing is that every character has their own individual weapon tree, class tree, skill pools, and leveling patterns, but you see NONE of them and they are constantly changing, the more you use a character the more they grow. The game adapts to how you play, depending on how you use a character that character develops to follow how you use them. If you go out and grind endlessly to make your party stronger, enemies will in return grow stronger to match your party, as a result the game constantly challenges you. It also has a pretty good story line, I am currently holding off on finishing the final sequence to finish the last of the side quests but I can say I was/am definitely emotionally invested in the story line. It doesn't have the GREATEST story, but it's definitely not just a mediocre story. It also has a stupid amount of side quests, I have 126 hours sunk into this game and am basically at the end of the game yet I still missed 2 side quests. All in all 10/10 and I plan on playing the game through again on hard mode with a new game+ when I beat it. Best $10.00 I've ever spent. If you do decide to get this game let me give you a few quick tips (things I wish I had known/was glad I knew) that I'll try to make as unspoilery as possible. (they probably won't make any sense until you reach said point in the story, but try to keep them in mind)Every available side quest becomes unavailable as soon as you enter the area called the Aqueducts.You can't defeat the fallen if you set foot in Underwalt, making an entire area of the game unavailable.Talk to the Duke of Ghor after every time you clear one of the bases.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												9.4/10So... I have played this game when it was on the Xbox 360 and one major improvement is that now you have a new game plus available after the battle with the last boss. over all this is an absolute blast tons of replay value and the price is amazing. if you like RPG that are a bit out of the ordinary battle systems and some what of an open world theme you will love this game. if you have not played this game I strongly recommend this game. the reason for the above rating is while this is a great game there are some.....issues. During battle you have unions. You issue orders (somewhat) to them. If it is an order to heal or support the others sometimes when union A is order to help union B and union B heals them selves but takes damage again the union A's orders are changed and they do not heal union B. this is just one type if issue i have run into issues with the battle system. I would understand the change in orders if unions stayed healed and what not. Graphics could use some work/ touch ups. Character hair, armor, things of that nature.still overall give this game a try.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												I have no idea how to describe the game as a whole, but here are some things that I like and dislike about this game.Pros:- THE BATTLE SYSTEM!-Interesting characters along with a story and personality for alot of them.-A near infinite amount of strategic customization/elements (unions, arts, equips, characters)-Enemies! Lots and lots of enemies! (Rare ones too!)-The graphics! (They're all sparkly)-You can summon bosses during battles-Bosses are not just your typical 4 vs 1 beat-em-ups but are basically an army vs an army.-Side-quests!Cons:-A near infinite amount of customization (When you get alot of members, they're always bugging you for stuff)-Mountains upon mountains of materials.-The learning curve (However there are wikis and guides out there to help with the basics)-A main character that doesn't think :/I highly recommend this game, because while it does have its good sides and bad it is not a game to miss out on. The battle system is one of the most interesting mechanics I've ever seen in RPGs and the pros more than make up for some of the faults of the game (which is mostly the learning curve).Score:french toast / 5

content:
Posted: April 12, 2013
												From the team that brought you the SaGa series comes this tactical JRPG with more than meets the eye. Technical hurdles from the 360 version are not apparent in the PC release (other than occasional texture pop-in) And I experienced screen tearing, and with no ingame v-sync option, I had to turn on v-sync via my Nvidia control panel.Whilst this game isn't for everyone, those that fall in love with it appreciate its deep micromanagement, lengthy battles and challenging bosses. Artstyle reminds me of Final Fantasy XII and the lengthy side quests and atmosphere remind me of Final Fantasy XI.A stellar soundtrack too, brilliantly composed.100+ hours of content. And exploring and unraveling its mysteries can be deeply satisfying... if you're able to put in the time.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												If Final Fantasy XII was a franchise, then The Last Remnant would be Final Fantasy XII-2. Both produced by Akitoshi Kawazu, TLR shares a lot in common with FF XII: a fantastic medieval fantasy world, grind-heavy battle system which feels very rewarding for those who like it, a bland main character, and totally amazing soundtrack! The Last Remnant suffers from some graphic issues and a forgettable story, but where it shines, it truly shines. For you who like Final Fantasy, or generally a fantasy JRPG with good turn-based battle system, deep tactics and customization, and great music, The Last Remnant might just be the right game for you.And hey, it's pretty cheap now.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												I really like this game. This is an RPG game that does not have the regular leveling up system that most RPGs have. It instead has the Battle Point system that make's this games learning curve a little bit of steep. Pro:1. Diverse set of character's you can choose from2. Boss battle's are really difficult that the game forces you to think outside of the box and make's each battle exciting3. For an RPG, you don't need to think too much of stats allocation.4. The story is pretty good if you ask me. Cheesy. But good.Con:1. The protagonist is crazy and really difficult to like2. Repetitive monsters. The dev's were not creative enough to think of other monster's and creatures to fill the world. IMO3. Repetitive battles. 4. No love angle. The game hints on this but WTF, you can't pursue it. Oh, well.For it's current going price of $19, it's not a bad deal. I actually purchased this when it was on sale for $3 but believe me you will not waste that $19. Atleast if you like JRPGs like me.8/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												My reason for not recommending this game is technical - It is a bad port. It is not optimized for the PC.I have been to forums, trying out every suggestion to make the video and graphics better, as it should be since this is a 2009 game and my rig, though not the most powerful, still can hold its own.I have tried every graphics setting all the way down to low and none. I've lowered resolution to 1280x720. It improves performance, but only slightly.Slightly.My gosh, I mean seriously, there have been guys in forums stating that their rigs can run CRYSIS 1 and 2 fully maximized everything, and this game makes their gaming rigs cry uncle.What gives?I have one last trick that I can try. I will install this in my SSD hard drive. Hopefully it will make this game run silky smooth. But I'm not confident, as I have played another port (ENSLAVED: Odyssey to the West) in my SSD and I had cutscene loading problems.I guess its true, what they say - ports from consoles suck eggs 95% of the time.I want to like this game. Seriously, I do. I'm even willing to do the research in the wikis necessary to be able to play it the smart way. Its just dumbed down by technical reasons. Too bad.UPDATE: Keep ALL video and graphics settings to DEFAULT VALUES and it should run silky smooth. With this info, I change my recommendation from NOT Recommended to Recommended.Wooohooo!!!! Time to enjoy some Japanese RPG!

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												Overall its a pretty decent JRPG, I recommend it, but it has a few defaults that makes it hard to give this a good score.- One of the worst leveling/grinding mechanics, all kinds of experience be it for skills/stats/# of items needed is all hidden to the player and there is no explanation at all on how any of it works. Basically, the more you fight, the more your rank increases, which makes you gain less stats increases and enemies scale up the higher your rank is. So the game mostly penalizes you for grinding/fighting a lot. There are ways around this but nothing is explained in the game, its up to you to go on the Internet (if you start this game I highly suggest you go read some faqs before playing, IT'S IMPORTANT, YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED)- The items farming is pretty tedious too without any help from the game and the RNG system which felt worse than FF12, especially when you have to do it for 18 characters instead of your usual 4-5 characters. Can't beleive it was worse on the xbox360 version.- Storywise, I thought it was well made overall, but for many it will feel cliche JRPGish, the story was missing a little depth, it is pretty short compared to all the sidequesting this game has, Expect something like 35 hours for the main story and all the rest takes around 100 hours of gameplay maybe more if you didn't read the faqs like I told you and you like to complete everything in the game. Those endgame quests/DLC are brutal if you aren't prepared.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
												It has a generic, very forgettable and LINEAR plot, strange cutscenes and dry fanservice.It has a confusing battle system and punishes grinding.It has a formation system, a class system, an arcana system, a battle rank system, rare monster spawn system, mystic/combat/weapon/unique/remnant arts system, party loot split and weapon upgrade system, etc, etc, etc, all thrown in your face with extremely vague / no description of how they work whatsoever.It has 50+ maps, 100+ recruitable characters, 300+ different monsters, 500+ craft materials (doing a guesstimate).It has useless items that cannot be differentiated from key ones linked to sidequests.It has dialougue options which don't matter most of the time but when they do... they do.Solution? The Wikia page. If you hate "cheating" nor have the patience to experiment - don't buy this game. But if you like exploration mixed in with stress-free strategy (no time limit for turns, hooray!) and like the idea of planning ahead to build a power-party. this game is for you. There's just so much content and the battle system is really fun once you get the hang of it. Nearly 50hours in, and I'm only mid-game. If only they had achievements for PC as well...

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												I had written a brief and unhestitatingly positive review of The Last Remnant a long time ago, but now that I've finally finished the game, I feel the ned to scrap it and replace it with something a little more detailed and a little less glowing.  This is a beautiful game with a great story and fascinating lore.  The game mechanics are... original at least, though I doubt everyone will appreciate having to choose from a list of not-quite-randomly generated commands in battle rather than having full control.  The game is marred, however, by the simple fact that there's so much in it... and most of what's in it is fluff.  It's a completionist's nightmare, and the only game I've played that I thought would benefit from some major streamlining.  Check my play time - that's one playthrough.  I didn't even do everything; there was a lot that I missed and some that I deliberately skipped because I just wanted the game to end already.  The many monster-hunting mini-quests quickly become a source of irritation once you realize that the monsters you're after aren't guarenteed to show up even if you're looking in the right place.  The mini-quests involving item collection and upgrading your equipment and your party's equipment aren't much better: the incredibly complicated crafting system includes hundreds of different components you may need, and the game offers no clues on where to find them - some can't be acquired at all unless you're carrying a certain unique item.  What I'm getting at is, play it if you're a Squenix fan - you won't be disappointed - but for the sake of your own enjoyment, resist the temptation to do everything, and be prepared to refer to Wikia frequently.And now for the punchline: there's a new game plus mode.  You're hilarious, Squenix.

content:

												My main type of games I love to play are jRPGs with different areas to explore, side quests towards the middle/end of the game, and a variety of equiipment with magical elements to equip and use on bosses, monsters, and the like.Now for this game. At first I was skeptical that I'd like it. I'm not a strategy game type person - this game is not like Risk strategy, more like Final Fantasy Tactis strategy. This game is thrilling, there's a lot of people to meet, levels to get up (Battle Ranks), side quests to do, and different places to go. Granted this isn't a jRPG, but it is a highly fun RPG that is completely underrated. The amount of content and playability will have you guessing what will happen next, what ties are going to be broken (if any), and who you can really trust. If you like looking for a variety of items to craft better equipment or weapons, this has a lot you can craft.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												"7.0/10"+ Rich graphics, memorable symphony music, unique/massive scale fights- Zero character growth, battle commands are random, sidequests are grindfestsA beautiful mechanically sound game that brings in an interesting battle system into an otherwise predictable jrpg plot. The Last Remnant caught my eye from the get-go with its visuals but dulled me back to real life with its  nuanse of storytelling and smaller-than-it-looks worlds. You play as Rush, a stubborn and small-minded individual out to save his sister and the world from destruction (How different!). What saves the narrative is a union-based system that gives you a commander-shouting experience. Rather than control each member, you're giving directions to the union as a whole and letting them decide. It gives the game a unique flair and really, Steam should list "Strategy" as its 2nd or 3rd tag. Without a proper setup; having a healer, disabler, tank, area of effect abilities, you'll be left scratching your head, getting smashed from some of the more formidable story bosses. Thankfully Steam gives you an emulator-esque experience, letting you save at any point in the game as long as you're not presently in a battle. This means you can rewind and plan accordingly. Thin your numbers out with more unions and flank the enemy? Bolster two-three unions for a direct assault? Focus on moral boosting units and leader special abilities? Acquiring more party members is also a treat as you'll be entering towns and recruiting people from various guilds. Getting the better party members requires you to do sidequests... and boy are some of them lengthy. Despite an engaging battle system that keeps you interested, it also has flaws. For one the commands are random. If you want a unit to do something specific, chances are it may not show up. Heal this union? No, sorry, I'll heal this other one. Use our special union ability even though we have enough mana? Maybe next turn. It's discouraging as well as prolongs otherwise 20-30 seconds fights into 2-3 minute charades. Buy:  For the gameplayDon't buy: For the plot

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												I absolutely love this game and stand by it. I have put probably about 300-400 hours into this game (not on steam, but mostly on xbox). I bought it on PC because it is a superior version which does allow more specific choices for characters and doesn't punish you for grinding.I Think the battle system and character progression system is great, but not for everybpdy. Your characters will grow depending on the commands you give in battle, the commands you get to choose from in battle are limited, but are always swayed by the choices you have made for that group of characters previously. Instead of having 6 focused characters, which you make specific choices for growth, like in the usual JRPG fare, you have 20 characters and make general choices in combat that indirectly affect the character's growth. It means that all the choices you make will have an impact, so you have to be mindful of what abilities you want a group to have.The battles are both challenging and engaging and unlike other JRPGs I've played. The fact they are large scale is really enjoyable, and you can also speed past them if you'd like. If you really want to enjoy it, you will need to use the wiki for it. There are details which appear as random in this game, but are really a number of complex factors that create a coherent, if unclear, system.The game's content is mostly sidequests and completely optional, and are amongst the most rewarding challenges I have faced in most JRPGs. I always feel like there is more I could do and more progression I could make, creating powerful and interesting combinations of characters.I thik this title is greatly misunderstood and underrated because of the sub-par Xbox release, but is really a unique JRPG gem and will shine through if you have the time and interest.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												I got this game on a whim during a sale, because strictly speaking Square Enix owns at least 1/3 of my soul. I wasn't overly disappointed with TLR. The graphics and controls are pretty top=notch for the game's age, and the difficulty scales well. I did have problems with some tougher bosses based on hiring new units and the way the 'leveling' system works. (Some of my units were woefully underpowered for several fights.) That said, the combat system (controlling several parties) is intriguing, and I'd like to see SE revisit it with a little more traditional RPG leveling system in mind. My only true gripe about this game is something that ALL developers need to take to heart: Skippable. Cutscenes. Even in NG+, the cutscenes are unskippable, and they are LONG. Have popcorn while playing. Overall, I'd give this game a 7/10. Cutscenes notwithstanding, the story can feel a little forced at times, and sometimes hard to follow, and honestly a little boring at points. The combat and gameplay in general are good enough to play through at least once.
