content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												The Last Remnant is definitely an interesting game; innovative battle style that I have never seen before, making gameplay actually quite fun.  I don't have a whole lot to say that others haven't said better, but this is what I think:Pros:- Rush's cheesy lines cracked me up.  It was like... well the writers were trying to be cool so he uses a lot of slang that cracked me up.  - While this was no Final Fantasy, the character detail and graphics are great.  I love a game where you can look closely at a character and see their clothes in great detail.  - Battle is fun, and when you are not having a super tough time you can watch a movie, or read a book while you are waiting for the battle to get over.- Voice acting was pretty goodCons:- Without a controller, playing on a keyboard is terrible.  You can absolutely tell that this game was originally made for the 360.  - Story is a bit basic, though admittedly not a huge turnoff for me.- I am not 100% sure that rare enemies return once you see them.  This kind of sucks, because they often tear me a new one, and I have to get experience before I come back to play.  - Some of the game functions are very dynamic, but they are also very confusing.  All in all, I really like this game.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												TLR is even better than I hoped.Battle mechanics:Makes you feel like a commander in the battelfield rather than the main character of a story, which is kinda refreshing and truth be told not that different from traditional RPG battle systems, since you select attack and see if you hit, miss, or get a critical hit, good thing that in TLR criticals(offensive and defensive) depend on you so you don't just sit back and watch the battles.Class system:It's both a good and a bad thing, is so huge that you'll be surprised, I was at least. but there's no reliable way to track progress and predict it accurately.Your main character can become whatever you want him to be which is always great, using whatever weapon you want which is a bonus, giving him different attacks depending on what you choose which is unusual, and feeling like he is trully becoming proficient instead of just a regular guy learning skills, what is there not to love about that?The world itself I find it lacking, you can visit few places. but even on the city itself what you see, find or the people you talk to is too limited.Side quests feel dull, specially when you accept and get teleported in and out, it feels wrong to me not going myself to do something I said I would, and not having a record of things that need doing in my main menu is annoying.All in all it's a great game, love the visuals, the voice acting is great.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
												The Last Remnant: The Salt BringerSeriously this game has made me so happy yet so mad, the sheer fact my old 360 and this PC have remained intact over the fruitless years of trying to conquer this game (With the physical strategy guide, mind you) is proof enough this game is worth playing.Synopsis:You start the game as Rush Sykes, who's sister, Irina, has been kidnapped. You venture off to lands unknown to find her, meet up with some people who think your parents (famous scientists btw) are amazing people. These new allies not only help you find your sister but eventually place you both on a gigiantic pedestal of world changing proportions, facing down enemies beyond that of a teenage boy who has yet to say a single curse above the occasional "damn." Also, character development, plot, twists of plot, and other RPG centric stuff occurs.Review:Yeah yeah, we get it. "The combat system is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t." Well, Square saw you wanted a "Final Fantasy"-Esque game without the convoluted self-serving plot, and a new combat system, and you very well F!^&#!%! got it. Yes, it's randomized based on your weapons, party members, remnants, etc. But it adds a new difficulty to the game that all you weeaboos and achievement whoores have yet to appreciate. As an RPG fan, and even as a FF fan, this combat system makes me rage, quite a bit honestly. But, when you finally beat that one spot, the one you've been stuck at for ages, it's like a long awaited ♥♥♥♥♥♥. It is just fulfilling and makes you dizzy with delight... then you find another boss immediately after who wrecks your♥♥♥♥♥♥and sets you back to square one.Now you may ask; "well if that's how you feel, why reccommend it you masochistic prick?" Because it's difficult, because it's a mixture of chaos and control that's amazingly frustrating and we all hate ourselves that much to force ourselves to commit to something that might give us a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ heart attack when you finally get to the end of the game, just to get your♥♥♥♥♥♥stomped in because your remnant never f!^@%#^! showed on the f!&#*@^ action wheels... <Insert Pant-Like breathing>.. Honestly, the story is actually quite phenominal if you're willing to murder yourself over it, the characters are well developed by the end and it's a difficult task to beat, but we all need relentless challenging. So go kick some "A." enjoy some of the frame drops (that can be quite hilarious at times) and most of all, find a way to kill Mr. Dig and his nightmare eyes.

												I've been a fan of the Final Fantasy series for years (specially III and VII). Although it's not Final Fantasy, The Lst Remnant is a pretty good jrpg. The story is great, the graphics and animations beautiful. I found it kind of clumsy without a controller (movement "wasd" and mouse, action battle triggers arrows, etc.). With a XBox 360 Controller the game is really very playable and easy to learn. The combat system is excellent and hard to master. The only thing I would pehaps change in the game is the ability to handle the equipment of your party (you can only control the equipment of the main character). Instead of it, the party members ask you to go around the world to find specific materials or for some weapons you have not equiped.Bottom line. A must have for all jrpg game fans. It was worth every cent I spent on it.Graphics: 98%Music: 95%Voice act (Japanese): 100% <- It's well deservedPlayability: 86%Overall: 92%

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												I had written a brief and unhestitatingly positive review of The Last Remnant a long time ago, but now that I've finally finished the game, I feel the ned to scrap it and replace it with something a little more detailed and a little less glowing.  This is a beautiful game with a great story and fascinating lore.  The game mechanics are... original at least, though I doubt everyone will appreciate having to choose from a list of not-quite-randomly generated commands in battle rather than having full control.  The game is marred, however, by the simple fact that there's so much in it... and most of what's in it is fluff.  It's a completionist's nightmare, and the only game I've played that I thought would benefit from some major streamlining.  Check my play time - that's one playthrough.  I didn't even do everything; there was a lot that I missed and some that I deliberately skipped because I just wanted the game to end already.  The many monster-hunting mini-quests quickly become a source of irritation once you realize that the monsters you're after aren't guarenteed to show up even if you're looking in the right place.  The mini-quests involving item collection and upgrading your equipment and your party's equipment aren't much better: the incredibly complicated crafting system includes hundreds of different components you may need, and the game offers no clues on where to find them - some can't be acquired at all unless you're carrying a certain unique item.  What I'm getting at is, play it if you're a Squenix fan - you won't be disappointed - but for the sake of your own enjoyment, resist the temptation to do everything, and be prepared to refer to Wikia frequently.And now for the punchline: there's a new game plus mode.  You're hilarious, Squenix.

												A seriously underrated turn-based strategy RPG.The combat system isn't hard to learn, but is super in depth if you want it to be.Customization is somewhat predefined, however, it still leaves you plenty of room to create your own set of unique unions.They hide quite a bit of information from you, specifically the class system, class requirements or even the material locations for your weapon upgrades.The biggest flaw is the Battle Rank system, as it determines the difficulty of the game, but isn't equal to the strength of your group, but the number of battles that have been completed.The Last Remnant is certainly a more difficult game then your average RPG.If you can deal with it's flaws, i would certainly consider giving it a go.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2012
												The only X-box 360 game I EVER owned that I never finished (due in part to pure rage), now ported to PC with more features (and less lag). It's what I'd describe as a Tactical-RPG, with turn-based elements relying on planning and forethought. Instead of single units (sending a lone unit out into a fight becomes and obviously poor idea), you have a "Union", a group of units you have mixed together to suplement each other's strengths and weaknesses. Level grinding is HIGHLY recommended, and so-called "side-quests" become a necessity if you want any kind of gear that will stand up to the main story's OVERPOWERED bosses.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												I loved this game on the XBox 360 and am now greatly enjoying the improved PC version. It really is better this way. I think the main reason why it captures my attention much more effectively than other games (Western and Japanese RPGs both) is that it actually provides a challenge, but without being needlessly frustrating. Nevertheless, I wouldn't warn inexperienced players away from it. The unusual battle system takes some time to get the hang of, but personally I love it. The story and characters are great, too, although the protagonist will make you roll your eyes a lot especially during the first third or so. To round off the experience, there's an excellent soundtrack.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												Yes, this game has a lot of flaws. The level up system needs some work and story is forgettable. Nonetheless, The Last Remnant adds an interesting twist to the RPG genre. Instead of having three or even five members for a party you can have up to 18 members that you can control at a time. Battles feel like actual skirmishes and it's extremly satisfying flanking an enemy from all sides. The game difficulty can spike up after some story events and it can seem more annoying that challenging. Nonetheless I was able to clock in 200 hours. I enjoyed this game thoroughly and I think you will too.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												2 technical issues   1)  Volume  controls do not affect the main page. Every time you start the game, every time you have to get to a load screen the music volume will goes up to its 100% until you make a selection. Gets tedious if you Play while others sleep.  2) Having software loaded for a n52te would not let the game grab control of the 360 controller. I have no idea why and it did not matter if i unplugged and restarted the pc, It would not recognize the controller until I removed the software.As far as gamplay goes it is pretty nice. Not a lot is explained up front, but there is a manual to look at to help you get started (if you prefer to just dive in without websites and guides). I did manage to pick up things pretty quickly from the mini tutorial at the start. Keyboard controls do not seem instinctive to me but that could be from my preference for the belkin over the past few years. But it plays very well with a controller. I'm not very far into the game yet. But I find the experience pretty fun. The most noteworthy being a completely random crit styled system that comes from the Gunblade (final fantasy 8) crits from pulling the trigger at the right time. In this game the function is expanded on to give multiple buttons (ABXY & right trigger). Except the queue is visual not auditory. You control group behavior not each individual in the group though with 5 options and the ability to see who will do what with each option before confirming you can somewhat affect how the move will go.  The main theme in fights seems to be to not let your party get surrounded. So be aware of that when you start early on if you attack middle groups you may find yourself making fights difficult for no good reason.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												The voice acting is horrible, but the story line seems pretty neat so far.  Has an absence of random battles, which is one of the things that contributed to Chrono Trigger being my favorite RPG of all time.  The battle system is really fun - and makes it to where you can die with relative ease.  Manual-controlled timed counter-attacks are also a really fun implement, keep you focused and involved during the battles.  I notice choppy frames, probably due to the fact that it's console port - I've heard of/seen screen tearing issues in ports before [original gtaiv 1.0.4 comes to mind], supposed to be an issue with the games running over 30fps on PC, but I'm no genius on that matter.  But it has a great feel to it, easy to get into, towns have a real old-school interaction feel to them which I like, and so far there seems to be a lack of wandering around a world map - you instead choose quick travel destinations on the map, whether it be a dungeon or town.  Maxed out, it looks beautiful for being almost 5 years old, and in the end just makes me wish I had FF7 redux, but oh well!  Worth the $3-$4 right now during the sale, for sure.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												A fascinating game. If you like JRPGs this one will most likely not disappoint. Even if the standard Final Fantasy isn't your thing, this game might still be interesting.The characters are interesting so far, and break some of the old tropes (though some do remain as well).If I had to compare this game, I would say it has a very similar feel to Final Fantasy Tactics, especially Tactics Advance. It's got similar party managing. That said, it's more classic JRPG combat and not tactical stategy like Tactics. You also don't have much say in other characters than your main one. You can't choose their equipment or what skills they learn and such. This can either be a blessing to some or a con. I would personally like more customizability to the characters, but so far as I've noted and what I predict, the party system is going to become quite deep and involving, if you want.Combat has a nice element of twitchy QTE put in between the standard turn-based fighting. It can be somewhat challenging to land those criticals, but they are very rewarding (especially later on when you can get insane Teamwork-chains). In case you don't want to sit there with your fingers ready to press the right button all the time, you can also turn the critical QTEs automatic, which probably works similar to how the auto-trigger works in FFVIII.The story is so far interesting. We'll see how it develops.Recommended to fans of JRPGs and other turn-based RPGs.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												Last Remnant - exactly what the FF series should be like by now. FF XIII? Fal'Cie, L'Cie, and playing dress-ups with Lightning? Thanks, but no. The game has it's flaws, no argument here (feeling more like a budget title from Square because of lack of marketing, which is a pity) - and some are more serious than others, I admit. On top of that, it takes a while to get at least a bit familiar with the battle system, but man... is it satisfying when all the pieces come together in a boss fight :) Like a well-thought-through game of chess.The learning curve is something else alltogether. Want a druid in your group? Too bad, your unit just became a hunter. How about a warlock? Sounds neat, right? Tossing Mystic Arts around and obliterating enemies like nobody's business. Well, tough sh*t, you just got yourself a ninja. This is not a game for control freaks. A lesson I learned all too well with this game. And I'm thankful for that.There are tens of characters to pick from, across over 50 classes available, who may, or may not listen to what you want them to be. You do the math. With 18 characters on the battlefield, it really feels like you command an army to be reckoned with. And even with that number.... I was left with wanting a little bit more. Last Remnant feels more "alive" than anything I have ever played from Square Enix. Characters upgrade their weapons based on what they are ordered to do in battle, and just ask you for components. No time to grind for Vulture Rawhide that Nora has been bugging you about? Well, she will be stuck with her inferior hammer for the rest of the game. Your choice. This is how in-game fighting incentive should work. I don't want to fight monsters just to get enough EP to teleport the hell out of a zone... believe you me.Last Remnant (2009) looks way better than Lightning Returns (2014), and, from what I have seen playing the latter, is definitely more in-depth. Unless you like playing dress-ups, which, truth be told, is not this game's strongest suit. There's so much more to tell about this game, both positive, and negative (more summon options!), and I feel I just scratched the surface. Buy it, play it, EXPERIENCE it. Or don't, and let the world be swallowed by the misuse of remnants.Again, your choice.

												Spectacular game that keeps you engaged with a very interesting squad-based "rts/rpg" hybrid combat system. Great storyline to follow, great graphics, well executed cutscenes. Good sense of overwhelming power from opponents, unsurmountable odds faced and beaten. One thing I would have to make sure to mention to anyone who purchases this game and plays, check and DOUBLECHECK that the "autosave" feature is on in the options or you may end up losing a LOT of progress. content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												This game is a beautiful and ambitious tweak to the JRPG formula.  A compelling. interesting story, coupled with above average voice acting and an interesting battle system culminates in one hell of a good time.  It does have its weak points, including the obscure nature of how to find some items required for leveling and a general sense that the game isn't giving you all the stats required to make inform decisions.  However, all in all, The Last Remnant delivers a great experience.Oh, and when it gets a bit sloggy 3/4 the way in?  Just push on through because the rest of the story is one to hold out for.If you loved FF, Tactics, and strategy, I highly recommend the title.  Great game, wish we'd see a sequel.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												Wow, what an adventure.To get to the nitty gritty, let me focus on a couple of parts of the game: the battle system, the story, and the ending.The battle system:The battle system of this game is unique and definitely improved the game in my opinion. If you are unfamiliar, you have multiple squads under your commands that attack in sets. If you've played Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic, it is somewhat similar, but much more smoothly executed and on a much grander scale. The battles feel huge in certain cases, and it really adds to the experience in that it makes it feel like you're fighting a war right off the bat, rather than just skirmishes.10/10The story: The story was very engaging, and this characteristic is largely why I prefer RPGs to other types of games. Though it has a couple of predictable plot twists, the world is immersive. The side quests definitely add to the story and add to the immersive-ness of the world, as well as providing tangible advantages such as recruiting valuable characters and the acquisition of powerful weapons. There were a couple of problems, such as the ending feeling rushed, but I'll get into that in the next section.8/10The ending: The ending was absolutely the worst part of the game. I think it's odd to feature the ending as a part of the review, but I felt very strongly about it. This game can be split up into two fairly individual parts (to the point where one could have actually been a sequel). The second half of the game felt rushed compared to the first part. I felt like, where the story had a comfortable and reasonable progression in the first half, I felt like I was barrelling through the story when I went at the same pace for the second. At endgame, the game really just kind of feels like it skids to an emergency halt. The final boss is scaled in difficulty to the progression of your character, which is nice, and the final boss did take me a few tries, but when I did actually beat it, I was for some reason a little disappointed. The ending cutscenes did give me a feeling that I was finished, but the satisfaction wasn't really there. For the reasons that the ending was sort of abrupt, but well written, I give the ending a6/10Overall:I highly recommend this game, overall 8/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												I put quite a bit of time into this game(Circa 2009) trying to upgrade all characters I was using in my party before finally beating the game. Alot of times this game seems at odds with itself, leveling can cause issues due to the game attempting to rectify ease of difficulty that can arise from overleveling, but I was overleveling from the constant grind, attempting to get certain rare creatures to spawn in certain zones for equipment upgrades. I wish there was a follow up game with more polish. I was one of the fortunate souls who did not attempt to play this on the Xbox 360, and opted for the PC version which apparently was in a better state upon its release. The game is not without its bugs, and issues with settings as framerates go bonkers without any reason. The gameplay is rare in which you have teams of characters who work together to fight the enemy. Sometimes this system worked out, sometimes it became muddled with confusion. I would liken it to something similar to Bahamut Lagoon on the SNES which I recommend people play if they enjoyed this game. Although BL leans towards strategy games of the time. There are some areas where a fight essentially relies on trying it over and over and getting by purely on luck. These certain events were a letdown in many cases. There were alot of very poor rpgs being made at the time of this games debut and in general during its console generation, and it was a breath of fresh air in its attempt to add something to a genre dying from lackluster gameplay, visuals, and repetition, Hopefully we will see a game soon, likened as a spiritual successor or inspired by it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												Overall 9/10If you like J-RPG’s, you must have this. The Last Remnant was one of the first genre releases by Square Enix back then in the early days of the X-Box 360 and long before Final Fantasy XIII got criticised for its linearity and lack of freedom, this game remembered the classics strengths of the genre and despite some of the typical flaws will always be one of my all-time favorites. The story uses the most common of tropes, when teenage hero Rush starts on a journey to save his kidnapped sister and stumbles into a larger narrative about the war of nations and ultimately the fate of the world. Despite the characters following archetypes we all have seen before in similar games, they are all fleshed out enough to be relatable. You will not just handle a small party of 3-4 heroes, but a small army of up to 18 characters. These can be recruited out of a much larger pool during the course of the adventure and lots of them are rewards for optional side quests or hidden missions. This is where the main fun lies, building and optimizing your army, you will have to arrange them into different groups, that will act as unit on the battlefield. That means a lot of actual gameplay happens in the menus before you actually engage an enemy. If you are fond of this kind of fumbling, you will love this game, if you however prefer a more action oriented approach, this might be frustrating. The battles themselves won’t give you too specific control over your team’s actions, but are still full of important decisions based on relative positioning and timing. Downside is, when your army is fully staffed everyone’s attack will be displayed individually, dragging even random encounters quite a bit (at least 1 minute per fight).Worth mentioning is, that you probably want to use a gamepad (ideally the X-box 360 controller) since the mouse keyboard optimization is horrible. You will also run into some brick walls along the way, where you will need to think carefully on how to approach. Specifically there is a very challenging sequence of 3 consecutive boss battles in the middle of the game, that you can get trapped in between. But again all this will shake things up and you have to do some work in the menus, re-shuffle your unions, re-align your formations and things might look brighter the next try. The general freedom between story progress and rewarding exploration will keep you playing for a long time if can muster the patience for the drawn out random encounters and the time spend in menus. The overall world structure, character design and storytelling is close to Final Fantasy XII while the battle system draws more from Final Fantasy Tactics. Not the worst references and therefore a must pay for any JRPG fan.Pros:- deep tactical combat- large amount of optional content- lovable characters- strong story with a great villainCons:- uneven difficulty curve- long duration of random encountersEdit: I want to clarify one point that I see frequently brought up in negative reviews. Yes, the finer mechanics of leveling are not explained well in game and external lecture is recommended, but if you normally play, follow the story and do side quests when they become available, you will encounter a smooth difficult curve. However, if you want to min-max and if you want to brute force encounters (that normally would scale) by keeping enemies weak (at a low Battle Rank) while your party is high, then you need to avoid fighting as much as possible early on. So yes, getting the most powerful party possible can be achieved by manipulating the systems and you need to read-up the internet to know how. But again for regular play this is not necessary, the game wants you to overcome difficult encounters by optimizing your tactic and setup, which works perfectly fine.

												Romancing Saga on steroids. It's a really neat jRPG with a steep learning curve.  Feels like an MMO at times, with all the monster hunting and exploring you do, but thankfully most of it is completely optional, so you can play through the story at your own pace.I definitely recommend it, even to this date. If you're looking for an immersive experience and like the Romancing Saga series, then this is for you.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												Probably one of the best games I have played. The combat system is fairly unique and can take a little bit of getting used to but once you understand how it works it is absolutely the most polished and exciting combat system in any jrpg. The story is kind of cliched in parts but it is fairly engaging and the depth of the side quest, upgrade, and weapons systems is better done than many. That said it is a jrpg, you will grind, you fight unfair battles that will make you want to kill all living things within reach and you will forget to do something important that will stunt one characters growth in game but it is all worthwhile. I would be remiss in not recommending this game (on pc) to all who enjoy a good game that can suck you in for hours at a time.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2016
												I played for 6.5 hours straight in the first sitting which is rare since I've gotten to the point where I have so many games if I don't immediately love it I try something else.Combat seems simple but gains complexity, lots of characters, you can gather materials for upgrading, side quests, open world exploring, and rare monsters to find.  Story doesn't seem bad either.  Gives me a FF12/FFX vibe.Definitely recommend for anyone who likes FF or JRPGs.Edit: After quite a bit more playtime I wanted to mention this game is very hard at parts and its not obvious how to improve your party.  You have a 'battle rank' but that isn't equivalent to a level.  Someone BR 65 can struggle at the same parts as a BR 30.  A lot of the boss fights come down to simple luck if you get your random 'special skill' or not.  When the game gives you a warning that you won't be able to leave if you save somewhere make sure to use a new save slot.

Posted: July 2, 2016
												It's a good game, no doubts but it isn't perfect. The story is ok, you  can find a lot of places if you are patient to explore everything you can. The combat system is cool and it requires a lot of strategy and the fact that you can use a lot of characters in one battle make this game a concentration of skill and tactics. There are many different and interesting quests and is a game very enjoyable. The problem is about the gdr itself becouse the characters have a lot of customization but the customize themselves automatically achieving objects. It can be ok but the problems comes when you acquire the objects but they still don't need them and the game doesn't allow you to give them back when they need them so, even if you still got the objects they need, anyway you have to farm the objects again and it's so frustrating. All in all is a good game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
												It is a fun game. it has a weird leveling and combat system that i say would turn off people who are more used to more popular RPGs like final fantasy and while it has a nice story, the pacing is a bit off to me and not very fluid. However, the combat system is very unique and can lead to various gameplays and strategies. for a 2009 game, the graphics are very good (but then again, graphics never really matters to me). i never played the xbox version but it has been said that the PC version is a lot better.the bad thing about this game is that they basically don't tell you about anything other than how to fight enemies. it has so much more than that like the upgrading and the leveling system. that leads to people, like me, to resort to outside help like wikis to play them or people just quitting the whole game because they cant figure anything out. if you play blindly and succeed, then i salute you. all in all, i would love to see more of the world and its people and its battle and leveling system expanded. i recommend the game for people who love turn-based RPGs, nice character design, great lore and/or strategy in RPGs (which i would say in a turn-based non-SRPG games are pretty rare). although this is a minor point, i would not recommend the game for people who like to control their party members individually as the battle system can get pretty random unless you set up correctly and for people who cannot stand the phrase "LET'S DO THIS!!!!"7.5/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
												With all it's flaws, this game is still one of my top 5 favourites. First of all it's challenging. If you are doing a full gameplay with all side quests and all, it will take an effort to get to the end. You MIGHT have to grind but I didn't feel it necessary. And even if I wanted to grind a little, and I didn't want to waste too much time, I sped the battle up, and it wasn't such a painful experience.Second of all the characters are awesome. They are all unique, with different characteristics and reasons to fight. I found it really nice that I could choose who to play with. And a lot of them have a special ability which one might consider to get, since it will not only look awesome but it also helps in battle. Just look up the wiki and see how many unique and special characters and abilities this game has. One can't even get every one of it by playing through once!No matter if the story is linear or the desert is so f*cking big that it takes half an hour to walk from one side to the other. You will probably never spend there that much time anyway. When I finished the game and it told me that I can  actually replay the whole, I was sure that I will visit this world again, and this time I make it count that I get every little secret it has in store for me.All in all it's an amazing game. Play it if you are up for the challenge and would like to hear a story about the magnificent world of Remnants!

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												The game tries so hard to be a squd-based strategic rpg. An nearly gets it done at least halfway. Which basically means that the base system is good - you can find / hire new units, put them in a squad together and then give them positions in different formations depending on their function. You can even costumize the different units pretty well, in regards of abilities and equipment. In combat you then choose overall orders like "attack enemy with magic / physical abilites" etc. Overall the system is a bit similar to Fire Emblem.But that is where the bad stuff happens. Actually the game never bothers to tell you anything. Not about how the specialization, itemization and development of units works. Not even what the different orders for the combat do. That is where the game just becomes a bad joke. At some point I got three options for hitting the enemies with physical abilities. All costing the same amount of ability points, but I had no clue what order makes what unit use which ability. For a game that wants you to micro so much of the units, their equipment and their skills, you have practicall NO controll over their behaviour in combat. Another example: At some point I decided to do a pure healer squad for backing my fighters up, since they got ganged by AoE-attacks during a hard fight. So I put a few magic users in a squad, told them to only use their healing abilities and let them wait in the background to heal the others. Which was utterly useless. Only like every 3 rounds I got the option to heal the other squad, which was pretty dead at that point. BUT was I happy to notice that my healers had the possibily to smach the dragons skill in with their puny staffs.Also, of course you don't know what enemies you fight before you encounter them. So in the same area there can be a group of 2 units which you can one-hit. Then the next encounter is a disguised mini-boss, who summons elite squads every round and hit all your squads every time it attacks. No jokes, those monsters stood right next to each other.Also I can and will not give thumbs up for a game that just continues to crash when you attempt to change the graphic options. That is just flat out ridiculous.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
												This game... I really can not understand how this game could get so many positive reviews. It failes at so many levels. First of all it features the most annoying male protagonist ever. And that really isn't a good start for a game when the character you start the game with is causing you pain just listening to him.It also features a horribly random combat system. Not just is the order in which characters and enemies got to take an action random. Also the actions a character has available at his turn are down to randomness. You desperately need to heal? Well, you can only pray that in the next turn the game gives you the option to heal as one of the available actions. I lost a lot of fights not because of doing anything wrong, but simply because the random number generator decided to not give me the option to heal when I would have needed it. Terrible design. Another prime example of terrible design would be the leveling system. It's probably the most counter-intuitive leveling system ever featured in an RPG. Rule number 1: the less you fight the easier the game is. Getting a higher battle rank in this game is NOT a good thing. It will make basically all encounters harder up to the point that some become outright frustrating thanks to the randomness of the combat system.The easiest way to play this game is to just run through the areas and avoid fighting as much as possible...I never finished the game. The combination of meh story, painful main character, and the terribly random combat system extinguished my interest in completing the game fairly quickly.I really can not recommend this game to anyone. Both gameplay and story fail to deliver.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												Not the worst JRPG you've played, but it's the most frustrating and annoying of them...-Keyboard+mouse controls... looks like people who ported the game saw K+M for the first time in their lives, gamepad is strongly recommended.-VERY limited control of your units. Every turn you have 5 random options to chose from and thats it. You might have no option to heal when you're desperately in need of it and you might be screwed even if you have it cause you can heal with ITEMS or MAGIC or both and you will get the one which isn't so powerful.-No matter what, your weakest union WILL be gangraped 99% of the time, every monster on the field wants their blood.-Monster AOE spells are overpowered beyond belief, even the weakest monster in the area (~same level as you) can onesot your party in 1 turn. Lets say normal monster attack hits for 100, singletarget ability hits for 300, AOE ability hits for 300 every unit in your union, which will result in 1500 damage on 5ppl... Some BIG monsters can AOE multiple unions and erase your party in a single spell... and they will cast it FREQUENTLY.-You can't surrender, so if you're trying to beat a very strong rare enemy and it destroys half or your units on the first turn... you must watch the other half die, sometimes very slowly.-You CAN'T skip cutscenes. After some cutscenes you will be immediately thrown into battle, and if you lose it... load your save and watch 5+ min cutscene again.-You can equip only your main protagonist, others can only request some components and RARELY items from your inventory, so you can sit on a pile of top gear and no ability to use it. It's not a huge minus anyway, cause all you have is main/offhand weapon and 2 accessory slots.-Though locations are pretty unique and well done you will be forced to visit them over and over again if you want to complete sidequests or hunt for rare monsters for the guild. Every quest teleports you to corresponding location and teleports back to tavern IMMEDIATELY after it's completion.-The world and lore are really interesting, but the story feels like it's written for the 12 y/o. This "flaw" can be seen in almost every Japanese game (atleast in my experience) and can be forgiven.-Battle system is pretty good for a JRPG, but it's very annoying that you can't skip battles with weak monsters when revisiting old locations.I'd give it 6/10, but put a huge red FRUSTRATION WARNING on it.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2013
												I've never played any of the other games this one is "based" off of, such as Romancing SaGa. After playing this for a bit, I never will. I did not enjoy this game at all. This is very much a game that you NEED (and I honestly mean that it is required) to read a how-to-play guide before you ever get started. Partly because the party/control/gameplay system is ridiculously convoluted at first, but also because there are inherently backwards gameplay things you absolutely need to know before you start.For example, battle rank (BR). BR is basically determined by how many enemies you kill. It's not like EXP though, from what I understand, because (from what I've read) it more or less keeps track of the number of times you enter combat, and not anything related to the toughness of the monsters you kill. You want to keep BR as low as possible, since your characters get better stat increases at low BR, and the enemies will scale with you, potentially even causing you to be out-leveled at later stages in the game.This is idiotic. Why the flaming crap do they fill areas chock-full of enemies that you can beat, and then say "Nuh-uh, you'll regret it later" and "You're doing the smart thing and attacking enemies one at a time!? HOW DARE YOU, NOW YOU MUST SUFFER!" Plus, this is not explained to you at all. Of course, neither is 98% of the rest of the game.The combat is weird, and strangely hard to follow. You will assign your unions (squads of units) to attack certain other enemies, but when the attack round starts, the unions run at each other in this pre-scripted "action" scene that makes it really hard to mentally place where they are actually running to. It's hard to explain, but immediately noticeable. Honestly, this game would be way better if they cut out the cinematic crap and just gave you a flat overhead view of the battle.Not a fan. I played it for maybe 10 hours, and was lost and frustrated for 10.6 of them. This game has no direction, no tutorials, and completely illogical gameplay mechanics. If you feel like studying guides for 5 hours before playing, be my guest. I choose to play something actually fun, and actually challenging without resorting to cheap tricks like withholding information.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												When the words Square Enix and RPG go together great things happen, unfortunately The Last Remnant is proof that even the best in the business can get it wrong.  Despite solid potential in the form of an excellent storyline and brilliant characters, the game is let down by an awqward progression system and a difficulty curve that is so inconsistent, a visual representation would look like a bowl of frustrated spaghetti.The Last Remnant follows an intriguing storyline, vividly brought to life through brilliant character acting and the very best quality voice acting.  The excellent production allows the player to really connect with the characters and experience the feels of story to the fullest.  Unfortunately, the ridiculous jumps in difficulty negate this by forcing the player to spend great lengths of time struggling to progress, ultimately destroying the rhythm of the story.  Impossible chain boss fights are sudden and deny the player any chance for recuperation, so much so that even multiple save files will not save you (hue hue) from hours of punishment.  Add to this the long, arduous random battles which can accumulate into hours of necessary grinding to rectify the tardy and deceptive progression system known as 'battle rank' and any enjoyment quickly fizzles away.The main point of interest in The Last Remnant is the battle system.  The player controls several parties of characters in the form of a turn based strategy with real time combat elements.  This is not particularly effective as the player is limited to a pre-determined set of attacks depending on the situation, inevitably replacing strategy with luck.  The real time combat elements have been cleverly integrated to sway the tide of battle if executed correctly and play a major role in determining the outcome of each fight.  Outside of battle the gameplay is fairly limited in terms of exploration and despite there being plentiful completionist content and a strangely addictive appeal, the majority is simply empty dialogue followed by a re-run of previously visited dungeons.Overall, The Last Remnant shows promise but quickly succumbs to its flaws which hinder the game from ever competing on the same level as it's better known stablemates.  If you are an RPG enthusiast with a high tolerance for frustration then you may be able to enjoy The Last Remnant.  If not, you would be better off looking elsewhere.3 subligars out of 5.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
												This is a game for players who love sidequests. The game is maybe 80 percent side quests and 20 percent story. There are the usual side quests of tracking down rare monsters and building new kinds of weapons. But there are also other kinds of side quests, such as collecting herbs for a scientist. The combat system is unique and original- it's not like any other Square Enix RPG you might play.It is an immersive game that requires a high time commitment. A lot of the dungeons take a good long while to get through. This is offset by the ability to save wherever you want anywhere you can bring up the menu. The game accepts input from a keyboard or a USB controller. I've used both and found that in spite of twelve to fifteen keys being available for use, I only ever use five of them (besides my number pad).The characters are mostly developed through battle. It's a little easier to tell what they're thinking when they vocalize in Japanese. The voice acting is original and accurate. There's a weird little frog man with orange skin and a high pitched voice. There's a bulky white whale person with a deep, gruff voice. And there's a female knight who doesn't take any crap from anybody. It feels like an old Super Nintendo game with better graphics. Highly recommended.

Also, when your team can heal, you ALWAYS get the option, despite what some noob below wrote. ;)The story is freaking awesome, the characters are lovely (I mean, come on, a Duke guy who's not a♥♥♥♥♥♥to you? The main boss guy's voice (original, that is) acting makes you want to join him instead of trying to pöwn his butt, etc. It's fun, it's funny, it's sad, sometimes it's hilarious, and it's pretty easy to understand.The music? Amazing. Perfect. You can feel the place all around you if you just close your eyes and listen to it ^^

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												The Last Remnant. JRPG ala final fantasy buatan square enix yang diport untuk xbox360 dan PC windows. Sebelum Final Fantasy XIII dirilis untuk PC, mungkin The Last Remnant adalah satu-satunya JRPG dengan grafis modern di PC.Cerita (7/10)Biarpun mungkin terlihat sederhana, namun cerita TLR sebenarnya cukup rumit bila kita memainkan semua side quest yang diberikan. Seperti asal usul suatu tempat dan runtuhnya kerajaan kuno. Semuanya diberikan sepotong-sepotong. Kalau kita hanya mengikuti alur cerita mungkin akan terasa banyak lubang di cerita ini.Gameplay (8/10)Gameplay TLR sangat unik. Tidak hanya 3-4 karakter yang bisa jadi anggota party kita tapi sampai 18 karakter! Eksekusinya cukup mudah berdasarkan union yang terdiri hingga 5 karakter. Kita bisa mengelompokkan union mana yang melakukan combat art (serangan fisik), mystic art (serangan mystic) support atau healing. Penggunaan formasi juga berpengaruh dalam menghadapi boss tertentu. Grafis (4/10)SIsi grafis cukup menyedihkan. Dunia dalam TLR sebenarnya sangat indah dan detail, sayang sekali penggunaan Unreal Engine tidak maksimal. Hal paling menyedihkan adalah saat pindah scene ada jeda 2-3 detik untuk loading texture. Sangat menyedihkan.........

content:
Posted: September 3, 2013
												Oh boy, where do I begin. While on steam I have only logged in a bare minimum of time, I seriously no-lifed this game when I borrowed a friends console. This is perhaps one of Square-Enix's crowning triumphs, which is ironic since they did it as an offshoot idea under the name of one of their mini-producers. This game brought a unique twist to turn based combat rpg by combining some strategy as well as seperate squads and heroes. The storyline was long (as to be expected from anything Square-Enix is involved in) and very satisfying. The graphics were gorgeous, and after the ending I felt many emotions, the 3 main ones being triumph at victory, sadness for having come to the end of a long journey, and an unsatable desire for more! My only complaint for this game is that the pc edition is literally the console version slapped onto a computer, so everything (and I mean EVERYTHING) is set up assuming you have a controller. For this reason I recommend getting a controller to play this with just to make life easier. Even with this minor setback though, on a scale of 1-10 I can willingly rate this a 9 maybe even a 9.5. I had hoped for a sequel, but alas it seems that will not be.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2013
												Archetypal three-out-of-five star game. Probably at least 100 hours to finish everything, but the constant re-use of dugneons and areas fosters a "why bother?" kind of attitude.The writing and story fall dead center into the average of what you'd expect from a smaller-budget JRPG -- it poaches and steals from every trope you can imagine, leaving no stone unmolested. Even the moldiest old concept is trotted out a few dozen times throughout the storyline. So if you've seen and liked it in a JRPG before, you'll probably see it again in The Last Remnant, just this time in a worn-out-STD-infected-completely-trashy kind of way,In some ways this game makes me want to hire a skywriter to tour Japan and paint the heavens with a simple message: "<Blank> did <insert bad thing> to my <blank> is NOT AN ACCEPTABLE STORY." Because somehow, even in 2008, Square Enix appeared to believe that their customers could be hoodwinked into giving hafl a damn about some characaracter whom we were just introduced to 2 seconds ago, and the bad thing that happened to her. If you find this kind of lazy writing to be offputting, I implore you: stop reading right now, back out of this game's store page, and never let its pixels illuminate your screen again.The art direction is okay, and the graphcis are decent for a game first released fairly early in the Xbox 360's lifespan. It runs well on a modern PC. If you hate the way Unreal Engine 3 games look, you'll probably hate the way this game looks.The combat system is fairly atrocious. It wants to look complex, but anyone with half a brain can figure the ins-and-outs within a short period of time and turn the game into a mindless slog from start to finish. Also, 52353253242345 unwanted fights while backtracking. And believe me, there's some backtracking in this game.I freely admit that I didn't beat this game. I actually enjoyed it a lot of the time, and might finish it one day. But that's just because I'm into this terrible-but-enjoyable kind of game.Recommended to hardcore must-play-everything gamers, serious JRPG fans, and the mentally disturbed.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2013
												The Last Remnant was part of an experiment by Square-Enix to make two new Japanese RPG IPs with the Unreal Engine 3 side-by-side with the development of Final Fantasy XIII. In my honest opinion, this experiment was much more successful than the experiments they made with Final Fantasy XIII itself.Final Fantasy XIII gave almost no player freedom while The Last Remnant allows players to make choices. Final Fantasy XIII had no towns and thus lost its sense of a cohesive and defined world while The Last Remnant has multi-sectioned town hubs ala golden-era Final Fantasies and tends to reward going off the beaten path. Final Fantasy XIII has a combat system that relies mostly on auto-battle with occasional 'paradigm shifts' and healing while The Last Remnant has a legitimately challenging combat system, even for vetern JRPG players. Lastly, Final Fantasy XIII had a story needlessly convoluted by invented words with no proper explanations to define them that essentially boiled down to 'we're cursed, we don't know why, let's pad out 40 hours talking about it amongst ourselves and then kill God' while The Last Remnant's story is more focused and explains itself better, allowing for a much better experience than looking up words in an in-game encyclopaedia.That said, the main character, Rush Sykes, annoys me in this game almost as much as Tidus from Final Fantasy X, but the mechanics in this game really save it from me placing it in the same category as FF X, which I hate immensely.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2016
												I don't understand this game. Why is it trying to keep you away, from a truly epic ending, by any means necessary?Annoying main character, that i only liked once, in the very end of the game. Forgettable sidekicks/companions, expect for a few, particularly Dave, he really reminds me of King Cailan, from Dragon Age, and i'm glad he didn't die, in some "epic" plot twist.Cheating. Yup, i said it. The game cheats. I don't have a problem with a tough challange, but i hate when a game is either buged, or so ridiculously keen on punishing you, that it resorts to dirty tricks.Some say this game is like Dark Souls. But that game requires skill, this heavily relies on luck, not skill, or tactical foresight.Repetitive luck-based battle system, backed by repetitive music, and aimless wandering around the map, to connect all of this.After some point, i realized, the only reason i start this game up, is because i want to be done with it as fast as possible. I rushed and exploited my way through half of the game, to be done with it.Would i start a new game+? No. Why would i? To grind through the same linear story, and risk the possibility of a brain aneurysm? No thank you.You might have more luck with this game, than i had, but i definitely recommend reading a few guides before starting. So go ahead, the beautiful scenery, and climactic ending, might be worth the hussle.5/10

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
												Where to start?TLR Is a prime example of a unique and interesting idea executed poorly but even so, It's still a decent game if you can ignore all of the issues.The isn't much beyond your typical JRPG style here and this is both good and bad. Firstly the music, oh my dear god what fresh hell is this? It's as if square have taken the old school way of "Just repeat 5 seconds of music over and over" from their old FF titles and thrown it in to a modern (at the time of release) game.There's really no variation in it. The battle music is the same no matter the enemy or the area, it is always the same and after a couple of hours you get so damn sick of hearing it. Every area has its own music while exploring but don't expect anything memorable or creative because these little pieces of music are the same five seconds stuck on a seemless loop that quite frankly drives me insane to the point where I had to turn the music volume down to 0.The voice acting is about what you would expect from any square game really. The voice actors were quite clearly ripped from older titles and some random anime by the sounds of it, the dialogue is cheesy (Who doesn't love a bit of cheese?) and you hear the characters talk in combat too. That in itself is a neat idea but that dialogue is as repetative as the music they are talking over but luckily square give you an option to disable the combat dialogue all together, thanks square.The combat is the unique idea that was executed poorly. It could of been so much more than what it is. You feel like you can do so much but the reality is you can't really do anything at all other than sit there with your fingers crossed hoping the enemy you encounter will have an option for you to use a specific attack.You group your characters in to units, you attack with a single unit by selecting an enemy unit but you have no controll over what attacks the characters in said unit will use which is pretty damn stupid when in order to "Level up" it's the "Gain expereince by doing" approach so the more you use a skill, the more powerful it will become.That's awesome and all but doesn't have much merit when you have no control over what skills are being used in the first place. You have to wish that the enemy unit you have selected lets a character use a specific attack. Healing in this game is also pretty redundant to be honest because if you want to heal a lot you have to break off from your engagement. You'll get max health back but then an enemy unit will ambush you in to a "Raidlock" which means you take more damage and the enemy unit does more damage making all of that healing you just did completely pointless.Why have I given this game a thumbs up even though I have all these issues with it? Because it's still fun.The world they drop you in is interesting, you can tell there's a decent amount of lore there but you'll never learn any of it. It does feel like an old school JRPG in a modern style with a unique but somewhat pooryl executed combat system. It's cheap as hell so I say give it a go and if you don't like it? Steam refunds are a thing.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												One of the wierdest games I've ever played, but still a very interesting twist on JRPGs.VERY unusual in graphical style (primarily the Remnants), story, creature design, combat and concept.Its quite a slog to get through and gets a little boring in places but picks up after the half-way point.This is a rare example of a game, originally developed for console (XBox 360) that wasn't intended as a PC release, but not only gets an awesome PC port, its better than the original console version!Special Kudos to the cut-scenes (both pre-rendered and real-time) is deserved, they are all well designed and developed. This is especially true for a certain spectacular duel between one of the Heros and one of the Villains about 2/5 of the way through the game, and I do mean it when I say 'spectacular'!Would certainly now place this in the category of 'Greatest RPGs of all time', but it is definitely one worth playing if you want something out of the ordinary.Note to those who prefer the Japanese dubs: Although a Japanese game, this was originally made in English, while the PC version does have the Japanese dub, it was done after the English was completed and so does not match the cutscenes very well. The English dub isn't bad though.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2012
												Great improvement from the 360 version with better optimization and less bugs. Loaded with secrets and has a Suikoden-sized cast of party members. The PC version works great as long as you force v-sync and use JP dub with subs because the english voice acting is awful. The combat is... "unique", to put it nicely. Early on it is frustrating because it feels slow with small squads and later it feels frustrating because your units like to do stupid things if you don't micro between fights. So basically, combat is uniquely rage inducing and worth playing just for that. Combat scales based on your average level except for certain storyline bosses. Difficulty is all over the place but usually challenging when you expect it to be. Overall this is a decent JRPG/strategy game but definitely not for everyone.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2012
												The easiest way to tell if you will enjoy this game is to take this simple test, stop reading if you answer "no" since this game is not for you. Do you like JRPGs? Do you enjoy a difficult challenge (really stressing the difficult here). Do you enjoy  unique combat systems and large casts of characters, several of which have very detailed backstories. If you have answered yes to the aforemented, buy this game, now. No seriously do it, its one of the most enjoyable and simultaneously frustrating games I've ever played (due to its difficulty). The main selling point in this game for me was the battle system, you fight with large squads in a 3 dimensional battle zone where numerous variables often mean the difference between victory or defeat. With the game having a maximum of 18 player characters in a single battle, in up to 5 squads, its understandable to see how it can be a confusing and complex battle system where sometimes you are not given the options you want when you want them, this can be handled with tweaking abilities before a fight as I learned later on, but it is an incredibly complex battle system which is well beyond anything Square Enix or any developer I'd wager has done. The story is the typical serving from Square Enix, although much more like their older titles (as in focused on single story and world but giving you lots of free reign to explore and expand the story with relevant side missions). The general premise for the game is hard to explain, and for that I'd refer you to the game itself as it is told quite well and it evolves as you progress through the game, one thing leads to another etc. The music is good as are the graphics for this title, with only some details being loaded delayed (could be my end). The voiceacting and dialogue is a mixed bag, with sometimes it being well scripted and logical, while other times it is random and idiotic (sometimes in a good way). In summary I give a full recommendation, its  one of the true JRPGs on steam at this time, if not the only one. It isn't for everyone, however if you are a JRPG fan, and have the time to sit down and dive into the masterpiece which is The Last Remnant, I fully recommend it.

number of helpful: 9 of 21 people (43%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 1
												Just...No.This game looks pretty, has a pretty positive rating, and has an interesting battle system, but that same battle system is also what killed any interest I had for this game.In the game, when you win a battle, you have a chance for something called your Battle Rating (BR) to increase in level. This sounds good, but just wait.The game alters the difficulty based on your BR. This is especially true for bosses, who can become impossible to defeat if your BR is over a certain number. Meaning that, if you decided to go out and grind a little, thinking it wouldn't hurt, you may very well be doing away with any chance you had at defeating an upcoming boss.How do you make the game playable? That's simple: You avoid every battle that you can possibly slip past. No random encounters, no mobs in the field, nothing. You can't even grind unless it's in certain parts of the game, and at certain times, unless you want to risk ruining your chances at progressing. That keeps your BR at a low number, which means bosses become 'easier' (I say it this way because, really, they're still ridiculously overpowered). "But this game has so many positive reviews!" you might be saying, as your cursor hovers over the BUY button. That would be because most of the people who have played this and beaten it are either 'hardcore', don't know the difference between a poor design choice and a good one, or are just masochisitic. You can sink eight hours into the game, and find yourself unable to even beat a single random encounter, simply because you wanted to level up your party members.Unless you've got some sort of demented craving for an overly difficult game, or you're seriously wanting to spend money on something you may never play, my advice to you is this:Stay. Away. If you value your sanity, you'd do well to give this game a wide berth. It's not worth spending hours trying to even understand how or why this game is even out on the market.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												It's Final Fantasy; same gameplay, same mechanics, same character design and a typical Final Fantasy storyline. If you like Final Fantasy, then you will probably like this.As is typical for Final Fantasy games, all in-game controls are shown as controller buttons rather than as mouse or keyboard buttons. This game was meant to be played with a controller. Not being able to just click on what I want to do and having to scroll through options one at a time instead is too much for me to bear, but I suspect this type of control is fine to those who find Final Fantasy games enjoyable in the first place.There are a lot of cutscenes and I don't think they can be skipped (at least I couldn't figure out a way to do so). If you aren't into the story, then the cutscenes could be a chore for you. They were for me, so I won't be returning to the game.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2016
												Square Enix's attempt to mix deeper turn-based JRPG combat with a new intellectual property and story.As such it only fails the second half.The outcropping of standard JRPG combat to fit combat concepts in to the rather mundane grind of the average SQE game. Long range vs. Short range, morale, party formations, and enemy flanking are a few examples of this attempt.The game doesn't fail its execution of those mechanics, but it does fail in preventing the usual JRPG combat from feeling repetitive and exhausting. Enemy encounters are won differently from other SQE titles, but fought the same within the game, and as such becomes as samey and boring as the games it tries to differ itself from.Lots of hidden uncalculative stats and functions operating in the background, only serve to prove how ashamed it is of it's combat and micromanagement, which is unfortunate.The story is♥♥♥♥♥♥ and the japanese VO is weeb-level laughable.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2011
												Ok, this is a tale about saving the world. It has an anime flair, and it is a tactical RPG in the sense that when you fight you have to use tactics and not simply mash an attack button. The graphics are nice, the music becomes annoying after awhile, and in general combat can become repetative.The biggest complaint that I have with this game is that the combat system is simply not explained at all. The game relies on synergy between teammates while they are grouped in squads, you do not get to pick exactly what skill your character will use, it is dependant on how many action points they have and who their teammates are and what skills they have to use. This means that fights can seem random and when you think you can win a fight with a certain skill, it may not be available. The factors deciding who does what in combat are simply not explained in game and make much of the strategy and tactics that this game really does well pointless. Better than Final Fantasy combat though.

number of helpful: 7 of 18 people (39%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												As much as i\'d like too, i can\'t really find a good reason to recommend this game. Last Remnant brings some interesting ideas on the table, but also have some very serious flaw that drags him down. The unions battle system doesn\'t really deliver the strategic feeling it should; too much RNG screwing up battles, sometime in your favour, sometime not.  You can\'t command action freely for every member; RNG will decide if you get a good command or not. You can\'t decide when and if the QTE for critical strikes will trigger; RNG will decide if you get a chance for a damage increase or not. Same thing for the special attacks that certain characters can use. Heck, you can\'t even freely change any of your party members equipment! There is simply no excuse for this, it\'s just bad design. For the majority of the game, the outcome of every battle that is not faceroll easy will be decided solely on rng dodges, rng parries, rng crits, rng special commands, and so on. As a result, you will not find any form of satisfaction within the gameplay, not even when you win. As for the rest:Video: visuals are nice considering the release date, but level design sucks, with the same halls and corridors that repeat themself over and over. Every location has it\'s flair of course, but just one, with almost zero variations within it. Animations works fine within battle and in most of the cutscenes, outside of them tend to be kinda crappy and unrealistic. The game also presents some technical problems: costant screen tearing (you can turn the vsync on editing the .ini file, but it will not work regardless) and texture-popping are the most noticeable. There are some partial fixes around the web, though.Audio: OST is good but without any kind of personality. Also, many locations have shared music. Narrative: the story is nothing special - but good enough to grab your attention \'till the endgame, even if some part of it seemed like rushed, some almost absurdly so. Characters are generally well designed, but the protagonist can be very, very annoying at times.________________If you are searching for a jrpg with an unique feeling, and you are capable of keeping your cool even after dying again, and again, and again just because of bad luck, then maybe you can consider to buy this game. The price is low afterall, especially on sale, and the title can keep you busy for a lot of hours. If not, then it\'s probably better to spend your money on something else.

number of helpful: 7 of 19 people (37%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
												It pains me to write this review. I am a big fan of square enix and of the games produced by them. When I saw this title on steam, i thought 'ah, cool. An rpg by one of my favorite video game companies.'After playing for about two hours, my initial reaction was completely turned around. While the game does have 3d animation comparable to the time it was produced, the remainder of the game is sub-par from what I have seen of other titles by square enix.The battle system is extremely boring and repetative. While it is easy to learn, it doesn't make sense. Instead of controlling a single character or issuing commands to multiple characters, you issue orders to squads, or "unions" as they are called in the game. And the types of commands are limited to the circumstances of the battle, but are limited to [basic attack], [special attack], [magical attack] and even more rarely [heal]. Once you give the orders, the characters are pretty much left to their own devices, attacking whichever creature they so choose and in whatever fashion they want, which can and has in my case not gone in favor of a winning battle. Not being able to plan and strategize a battle plan with all your characters makes fights far more difficult than they should be, given all that you can input in the commands.I could have seen past the battle system if the storyline and/or voice acting/dialogue were good. Sadly, that was not the case either. I felt like I was watching a really poorly written anime. The main character, who is perhaps 15, I am guessing, meets an important nobleman and suddenly becomes part of the army, fighting shoulder to shoulder with top level generals and no one raises a fuss. The characters seemed very stiff, almost no emotion going into the dialogue. The bad guys are easily spotted and are cliche'.Overall, I am dissappointed in this title.

content:

One should not require the wiki to understand a basic game mechanic.Storyline seems good, but the horrible battle system and poor difficulty scaling make this one game I will not be seeing through to completion.

												A clear demonstration why the JRPG industry is on a downward path.- Stereotypically badly written characters- Offensively basic dialogues- Boring story- Mediocre english voiceovers- Main quest not tracked in journal- Amateur and uninspiring level design- Empty map designs- Artificially overcomplicated combat system- Completely unbalanced game difficulty- Confusing, underdeveloped and in the end needless slow time enemy engage system- Tedious and long fights- Healing, ressing and units micromanagment is an exercise in patience- Lack of hints on combat formation variations- Sidequests with auto teleport to location- PC port offers nothing worth the titleBarely worth 5 bucks.

number of helpful: 3 of 13 people (23%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												I so wanted to finish this game, but it's seriously broken and flawed. Combat is difficult across the board, and you'd think with a JRPG that the more your grind and the more powerful your characters become the easier battles will become : NOPE! That's not true with this game and it's infuriating.Added to this, the battle system is sadly random and I found myself winning bigger fights by shear luck - if I died in try #1 I reloaded and during try #2 I suddenly was able to summon or cast a ultimate spell, or I'd just manage to win more quick-time-events and block an attack, where sometimes by blocking you can do an insta-kill. But, like I said, it's 100% random.The most inexcusable thing to me, was that I found my level 50 group had the ability to summon big monsters who would act as a tank for us. So I had a boss battle which I could ALMOST win at level 50 and I decided to grind a bit to get to level 57. Suddenly, my level 57 group could no longer summon, and the bosses I was fighting at level 50 could suddenly perform completely different and way more powerful attacks than what they were throwing at me before, essentially making my MORE POWERFUL group of characters LESS EFFECTIVE and at more a disadvantage.Encounters are limited to maybe 12 different creatures, mostly spiders and wasps, the odd dragon here and there. Don't even bother trying to fight the rare monsters (usually a spider or wasp with a different colour and name) because you'll do 1million damage to them without denting them.I wanted to finish this game, but I just ended up rage quitting.

number of helpful: 5 of 18 people (28%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 11
												STAY AWAY FROM THIS GAME. HONEST REVIEW COMES AFTER THE SHORT RANTAbsolute piece of garbage game, not worth it even if it is free. DO NOT WAST YOUR MONEY. And here's why:The plot is complete garbage with so many holes, inconsistencies, unexplained parts, and head scratching "wtf's"The supporting characters are ok, but barely fleshed out and merely serve as meatshields, the main character is absolute trash, cliche Japanese hero who is an idiot, brash, doesn't think anything through, yet is mysteriously gifted with "awesome" powers.There is no "clear" leveling system and stat increases are sometimes randomly awarded after battle.The combat system is a cool concept but terribly unbalanced causing for most of the fights to be super easy, or a boss fight where you get lucky or get one shotted.Maps are needlessly large yet somehow still linear and empty.NO CUSTOMIZATION, I mean seriously, homeboy MC is wearing casual Friday outfit when fighting a fire breathing dragon...Overall 1/10 It just isn't worth the time, there are a hundred other games like it that are better. Try any Final Fantasy Game if you want similar combat/story type, try Bladestorm 100 Years war if you want similar larger feel/raid battles, try Dynasty Warriors if you want a good game.

number of helpful: 8 of 26 people (31%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												Horrible console port for mediocre game  Want change key bindings or mouse sensitivity no problem just save game, quit to tile screen menu where you can access most options, change something, load game test changes and repeat until it will work like you want it.You playing using keyboard - don't worry game will show you on screen what key on gapepad use to do something, want to know how to do this using keyboard? easy just save, go to tile screen check keys, look for what was just introduced and find appropriate key, load game test it and you are good to go. Pure pleasure! :)About gameMain character is unlikable from the start and this alone make it hard to enjoy when you don't like character you controllinggameplay is slow and boringwalking on maps are very clunky, controlling camera and overall feel are like from decade ago, pretty horriblelevel design are bad, repetitive, empty and uninterestingbattles are very chaotic and almost automatic at the same time, probably intention was to make it dynamic but it is hard to see whats is going on on battlefield when on every attack everybody running from different directions, camera changes and in the end you don't know what is going on and who is where. There is some very limited strategy in battle but because of whole  "dynamic" system it doesn't really matter that much and battles itself after a short while gets boring and very repetitivevisually isn't stunning but it is console port from 2009 so hard to expect something good looking Story/ dialogues and voice acting are also very mediocre, whole idea about kid/ teenager easily get to army and fight side by side with generals is very naive and childish, look like poor story for kids.Creatures design are actually quite good, shame that engine and console limitation crippled character artists on that :/
