content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												This game isn't even worth the ♥♥♥♥ing 9 dollars it costs...you try to build a party at a guild...then you go into a certain map, and that party is NO WHERE TO BE FOUND! So you take on these stupid quests with townsfolk...you end up in a dungeon with said townsfolk...with your party NO WHERE TO BE FOUND. Beating side quests seems impossible. Where did my ♥♥♥♥ing party go once I assigned them at a guild? WHERE?! Is this one of those games you have to grind for hours in a low level area to be able to take on side quests? I mean where is my ♥♥♥♥ing party!? I assigned them at a guild! WHY AREN'T THE IN MY PARTY?! Don't play this. It's only a few years old but the graphics seem circa 2001...there is only voice acting during cut scenes...the rest you have to READ! Imagine, an xbox360 game where you have to read the ♥♥♥♥ing quest dialogue...pathetic.Edit: I found out how to take the party you create into a map...but that didn't make the experience much better...this game requires old school exp grinding to make it anywhere. I find myeslf dying from one group of regular monsters...despite fully understanding the combat system. It's just a really unbalnced game. I ground for hours to beat ONE rare boss mob in an early cave area. Still impossible to beat it. I understand the combat....my characters are well leveled. This game got very good reviews when it was first released...I have a feeling the company that made this game paid handsomely to get these positive reviews...something big companies are known to do.Dated graphics for a 2009 release, minimal voice acting...strange unbalanced combat system...zero phsycis, Completely linear, Trite, cliche story...forgetable characters, mandatory exp grinding and a whole host of other problems. Androgenous heroes. ♥♥♥♥, the females in this game look more manly than the males...I don't need a ♥♥♥♥ing lesson in androgeny. Square Enix, has lost their luster...and then some. When the company was Squaresoft...they were shining. This game is a clear example of how Squaresoft sold out. Don't believe me? Pay the 9 dollars yourself and find out.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 14
												I've played and beaten this game on xbox multiple times and have gotten mostly through the PC version. This game is seriously flawed. The only reason that I'm recommending it is because it's fairly cheap and does have its upsides, but I'd still wait until it's on sale. Pros:-Interesting and numerous sidequests.-Interesting concept-Great battle music-Lots of arts-Some cool animationCons:-Battle system is extremely random, if you play the same fight twice you can get absolutely destroyed the first time and completely slaugher them the second time doing pretty much the same thing.- Punishes you for leveling up (strangley enough the surest way to beat this game is to avoid fighting as much as possible)-Punishes you for trying several weapons (you will wind up downgrading your nimble/mighty arts unless you stick with those types of weapons.)- Characters and story are pretty generic and boring.- 99% of important stats and exp happen off screen.- The game does not teach you how the battle system works, you need to look it up and study it.- Morale system doesn't work well, if your winning by a landslide this just makes it easier, if your getting beaten down this just makes it worse, and some enemies will constanly lower morale gauge regardless of how you are doing.- Area attacks and some status ailments are horribly broken. Area attacks basically do normal damage times however many units you have in a union and may even hit other unions. This will often oneshot you and they use them VERY often. Some status ailments in this game are easy to deal with (silence, burn) while others are pretty much a death sentence (poison, curse).All in all this game isn't amazing and somtimes it feels like the bad outweighs the good but you might like it so it may be worth dropping a few bucks on. Still wait for a sale though. Also if you do get this game make sure you turn on autosave, it's not the default setting and you really need it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 3
												This JRPG has one of my favorite battle systems in any JRPG. It's not perfect, by any means but it's very fun to be able to recruit a mercenary army and go to town on an entire squad of enemies while still having a turn based style system.I'm not really a fan of the Battle Rank system which doesn't make much sense. Basically, the enemies in the game scale based on how many strong monsters you kill, so grinding actually hurts you. So does... killing pretty much any mobs apparently, unless they are incredibly weak. That said, it's interesting to have an RPG that -encourages- speedrunning instead of requiring you to grind a lot!It also has one of my favorite JRPG soundtracks with some incredible battle and area music. The game would be a lot more boring without its stellar soundtrack adding some personality to the areas.These days the graphics look a little dated. The art design is somewhat generic, with many of the enemies having a stereotypical look to them, though I do like how many different sentient species there are in the game's world. The character design is hit or miss, though some of the characters do look pretty badass. Hint: It's probably not Lord Davide.The storyline is just enough to make the game interesting, but isn't amazing. The main character, Rush, behaves really weirdly like he has the personality and impulse control of a 10 year old, which can break suspension of disbelief. There are more interesting and cooler characters in the game though, like Davide's generals and Emma Honeywell. The overall story about the Remnants isn't explained too well, and the Remnants end up feeling like big Macguffins with no rhyme or reason to their existence.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 29
												This here is one of the 'lost' JRPG's in my opinion. It's a great game from the makers of Final Fantasy, yes that's right they make RPGs Other than FF. The interesting thing in this is two fold, first it's on the Unreal Engine, not a in house engine. Second it's M rated for blood. Now the blood is pretty old school, especially by todays standards. We aren't talking dismemberment gore here, just people get hit and blood splashes out of a non-existant wound. The graphics aren't horrible, they were good when it was new. The interesting mechanic here is the combat, it's turn based but more strategic than just waiting for your turn. The gameplay is actually quite a lot of fun, and in typically JRPG fashion the story is convoluted and extremely long, with lots of little hidden things to find around towns, cities and caves. Overall, if you're a JRPG fan, I recommend giving this a shot if it's at a price you like. HOWEVER, there is one IMPORTANT catch, this game uses one of those awful 'keep up' leveling systems from what I've been told, the higher you level up your characters the stronger the game becomes, your true 'power' comes from the skills you obtain and they can be obtained in many cases at any time. Like most games as complex as this one, you're better offer doing a lot of research before you even start to know exactly what you should do and how to go about it, NOT pursuing certain things right away and trying to power level your character ever will really really hurt you. The old enjoyable act of running around leveling to gain an edge is ruined with this design. Now if you don't enjoy old school RPGs and like a game that keeps pace with your level, this should be your thing. If you like old school RPGs though where you level up and eventually feel like a super Hero, this might be a struggle. You NEED to follow a guide that explains everything, because becoming powerful is about keeping your level low while doing everything to enhance your skills. You also have to recruit nearly an army, since in this combat is between squads of characters and not one on one.
